fields.title: TehConnection Wiki

[center][size=5][color=#4682b4]Welcome to the TehConnection Wiki![/color][/size][/center]


[i]On this page you'll find links to several key articles to help you better understand and enjoy your experience on this site. Follow the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=browse&letter=1]Browse Articles[/url] link for all of the articles. If you want something added to the Wiki, ask in the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewforum&forumid=16]Help[/url] forum.[/i]

fields.title: Am I connectable?
fields.body:
[size=3][b][u]Am I connectable?[/u][/b][/size]

You can check with TC's [url=https://tehconnection.eu/user.php?action=connchecker]connection checker[/url] or with [url=https://canyouseeme.org/]CanYouSeeMe.org[/url].


[size=3][b][u]What does it mean to be connectable, and why do I want it?[/u][/b][/size]

Being connectable means your ports are forwarded properly and your computer is able to initiate contact with others. If you are connectable, you can seed to or leech from anybody in the swarm - if you are not, you are restricted to those who are.

If you are not connectable, you should still be able to download because most good seeders are connectable. However, you will have difficulty seeding because you will only be able to seed to connectable leechers.


[size=3][b][u]I am not connectable, what do I do?[/u][/b][/size]

For most people, there are three general things to do in order to become connectable. 

First, you must make sure your torrenting computer will always have the same IP with your router. To do this, either setup a static IP from your computer, or lease an IP to your computer from your router.

Second, you must configure your router and/or modem to properly forward the port on which your torrent client is running to your computer. Most router control panels are accessible via one of the following local IP addresses:
https://192.168.1.1
https://192.168.1.254
https://192.168.0.1
https://10.0.0.1

If your internet connection looks like this:
Internet -> Modem/Router -> Your computer
You need to tell your modem/router to forward your torrent port (check your client's settings to find/set this) to your computer's local IP.

If you internet connection looks like this:
Internet -> Modem/Router -> Router -> Your computer
You need to tell your modem/router to forward your torrent port to your router's local IP, and then tell your router to forward your torrent port to your computer's local IP.

Third, make sure any firewall running on your torrenting computer is allowing the port through.

https://portforward.com has specific guides for most if not all of these steps, and even specific guides for most routers/modems.

[i](More detail/specifics will be added later. If you feel like writing, go ahead.)[/i]

fields.title: Inactivity
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What is Inactivity?[/b][/size][/color]

Inactivity is something we want to discourage at TehConnection. As such we have rules which can affect your account if you choose not to make use of the site. The following account classes are subject to our inactivity rules:

[list]
[*] User
[*] Member
[/list]

Accounts will be disabled if they meet [b]both[/b] of the following criteria:

[list]
[*] Eight ([b]8[/b]) weeks without logging in and browsing a page.
[*] Two ([b]2[/b]) weeks without seeding.
[/list]

To prevent inactivity pruning you must visit the site at least once every six ([b]8[/b]) weeks or keep something seeding.  You can exempt yourself from these rules by donating or reaching 'Fanatic' [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=2]member class[/url]. You can read more about donating by reading [url=https://tehconnection.eu/donate.php]here[/url] or clicking 'Donate!' at the top of any page.

If you know you'll be going away for an extended period of time and be unable to use your account please send a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url] and we'll be able to assist.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What Can I Do If My Account Has Been Disabled For Inactivity?[/b][/size][/color]

If you find that your account has been disabled for inactivity you will need to come and chat with us in the #TC.Support channel on IRC. More information on our IRC network can be found [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=85]here[/url]. Access to our IRC support channel is also available from our account recovery page.

fields.title: List of Applications for Ripping, Encoding and Subtitles (All Platforms)
fields.body:
This list of software is intended as a resource for those who would like to know what software exists for encoding on all operating system types. There is a discussion [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=625]thread[/url] for anything you think needs adding or modifying.

[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]

[size=5][color=yellow]Platform Independent[/color][/size]

[size=3][color=red]x264[/color][/size]

x264 is an open source H.264/MPEG-4 AVC encoder. It is by far the best AVC encoder in existence and is used for all user encodes on this site.

There are several places to get the latest builds of x264 and each is preferred by different people. It is recommended for our internal encoders to use techhouse's builds but this is by no means a hard and fast site rule.

     [b][url=https://x264.nl/]x264.nl[/url][/b] - 'vanilla' x264 builds which have no additional patches added.
     [b][url=https://x264.tk/]x264.tk[/url][/b] - techhouse's x264 builds


[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]

[size=5][color=yellow]Windows[/color][/size]

  [size=3][color=red]Ripping[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/DVD_Decrypter]DVD Decrypter[/url][/b] (coupled with [b][url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/RipIt4Me]RipIt4Me[/url][/b])
DVD Decrypter enables you to decrypt and copy DVDs to your HDD, Demultiplex DVDs to separate audio, video and subtitle streams. This program is no longer developed.

RipIt4Me is a freeware utility that helps you backup your copy protected DVDs. RipIt4Me is fully automated and the wizard will guide you through all the necessary steps involved. If you prefer, there is also a true "1-Click" mode that will perform all the involved steps automatically for you. By coupling both of these programs you can have a completely free DVD ripping solution which can cope with [i]nearly every copy-protected DVD[/i], with the exception of maybe 1 or 2 out of hundreds.

     [b][url=https://www.dvdshrink.org/]DVDShrink[/url][/b]
DVDShrink is a great tool for backing up DVDs. Make sure to backup the data to a HDD folder and disable ALL compression. Note that DVD Shrink only handles CSS copy protection.

     [b][url=https://www.slysoft.com/en/anydvd.html]AnyDVD[/url][/b]
AnyDVD works in the background to automatically remove the copy protection of a DVD movie as soon as it's inserted into the drive, allowing you then to backup the movie via a simple right click on the AnyDVD tray icon.

---+---

  [size=3][color=red]Encoding[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://handbrake.fr]Handbrake[/url][/b]
Handbrake is a free and open source x264 encoding GUI. Great for the beginning encoder. DO NOT use the presets for uploading here.

     [b][url=https://sourceforge.net/projects/megui]MeGUI[/url][/b]
MeGUI is the most comprehensive GUI based ISO MPEG-4 solution. It suports MPEG-4 ASP (xvid), MPEG-4 AVC (x264), AAC, MP2, MP3, Vorbis, AC3 and Aud-X audio and various common containers support (MP4, MKV, AVI).

     [b][url=https://avisynth.org/mediawiki/Main_Page]AviSynth[/url][/b]
AviSynth is a powerful tool for video post-production. It provides ways of editing and processing videos. AviSynth works as a frameserver, providing instant editing without the need for temporary files.

     [b][url=https://avisynth.org/qwerpoi/]AvsP[/url][/b]
AvsP is a text editor built for AviSynth, it makes using AviSynth much easier.

     [b][url=https://neuron2.net/dgmpgdec/dgmpgdec.html]DGMPGDec[/url][/b]
DGMPGDec, DGIndex is an MPEG-2 decoder suite. It is used to decode MPEG-2 streams from such sources as DVD .vob files and Blu-Ray, captured transport streams, DVB/HDTV streams, *.mpg, *.m2v, *.ts, *.m2ts files, etc. Based on DVD2AVI and MPEG2Dec it can also demultiplex to video and audio files.

     [b][url=https://www.bunkus.org/videotools/mkvtoolnix/]mkvtoolnix[/url][/b]
mkvtoolnix is a set of tools to create, alter and inspect Matroska files under Linux, other Unices and Windows. They do for Matroska what the OGMtools do for the OGM format and then some.

     [b][url=https://forum.doom9.org/showpost.php?p=1234822]Lord Mulder's GUI[/url][/b]
Note that this application is for more experienced encoders and has several dependancies. See echohead's encoding guide for more information.

---+---
     
  [size=3][color=red]Subtitles[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/Subrip]SubRip[/url][/b]
SubRip is an optical character recognition (OCR) program for Windows which rips (extracts) subtitles and their timings from video files on DVDs, recording them as a text file.

     [b][url=https://www.afterdawn.com/software/video_software/subtitle_tools/vobsub.cfm]VobSub[/url][/b]
VobSub is a plug-in for VirtualDub that allows you to rip subtitles from DVD .vob files and to use the provided DirectShow filter for DivX playback with subtitles. VobSub only outputs subtitles into .sub/.idx format which is not preferred on TehConnection.

     [b][url=https://www.aegisub.net/]AegiSub[/url][/b]
Aegisub is an advanced subtitle editor for Windows, and UNIX-like systems, such as Linux, Mac OS X and BSD. It is open source software and free for any use. This software is still under development and should mainly be used for editing subtitles and translating (mainly Cyrillic and Greek text). [url=https://www.aegisub.net/2009/02/kumaji-explained.html]Kumaji[/url] will be the tool to use for ripping subtitles when it is ready.


[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]


[size=5][color=yellow]Apple Mac OS X[/color][/size]

  [size=3][color=red]Ripping[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://ripdifferent.org/]MacTheRipper[/url][/b]
It is a pain in the ass getting a LEGAL copy of this software (v3.0) so grab one from your local torrent site. I recommend looking on a private tracker because you're less likely to get a virus/crap. Its main advantage is a very easy method for ripping DVDs to a single .vob file. This is useful for encoding. Version 2.6.6 is easy to get hold of but is slightly dated.

     [b][url=https://ripitapp.com/]RipIt[/url][/b]
Good looking and simple DVD Ripper.

     [b][url=https://www.metakine.com/products/fairmount/]Fairmount[/url][/b]
Fairmount is a free tool which allows on-the-fly decryption of DVD content for convenient access. Fairmount does not perform the actual decryption, it simply forwards the data to VLC Media Player, which is used for the decryption. Hence, VLC Media Player must be installed for Fairmount to work.

---+---

  [size=3][color=red]Encoding[/color][/size]

     [url=https://handbrake.fr/][b]Handbrake[/b][/url]
Handbrake is a free and open source x264 encoding GUI. The PPC and Intel supported builds are here too. Also you can get the source and compile it yourself. Great for the beginning encoder. DO NOT use the presets for uploading here.

     [b][url=https://xdot.command-q.org/]X●[/url][/b]
[s]A pretty nice MPEG-4 AVC encoder for Mac.[/s] Unfortunately this turned out to be vaporware. Here is to hoping for a better Mac encoding GUI.

---+---

  [size=3][color=red]Subtitles[/color][/size]

     [url=https://www.aegisub.net/][b]Aegisub[/b][/url]
Aegisub is an advanced subtitle editor for Windows, and UNIX-like systems, such as Linux, Mac OS X and BSD. It is open source software and free for any use. This software is still under development and should mainly be used for editing subtitles and translating (mainly Cyrillic and Greek text). [url=https://www.aegisub.net/2009/02/kumaji-explained.html]Kumaji[/url] will be the tool to use for ripping subtitles when it is ready.

     [b][url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/D-Subtitler]D-Subtitler[/url][/b]
D-Subtitler is a little program which will let you extract subtitles from your DVD into a .srt file. To use D-Subtitler, open a ripped DVD from your HDD (usually a VIDEO_TS folder). Choose the subtitle track to extract and click on the green button.


[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]


[size=5][color=yellow]Linux[/color][/size]

[i]Most software here can be compiled for the various Linux distributions (this may require some Googling).[/i]

  [size=3][color=red]Ripping[/color][/size]
  
	 [b][url=https://www.dvdshrink.org/]DVD Shrink[/url][/b] under [b][url=https://www.winehq.org/]Wine[/url][/b]
DVD Shrink is a great tool for backing up DVDs. It also happens to work perfectly under Wine. Make sure to backup the data to HDD folder and disable ALL compression. Note that DVD Shrink only handles css copy protection.

     [b][url=https://www.mplayerhq.hu/design7/news.html]MPlayer[/url][/b]
MPlayer is a free implementation of the major media decoding/encoding libraries. It is a command line tool and has a built in encoder as well. Very versatile but as a command line tool is not for those new to Linux.

     [b][url=https://vobcopy.org/projects/c/c.shtml]vobcopy[/url][/b]
vobcopy copies DVD .vob files to hard disk, decrypting (if you have libdvdcss installed) them on the way (thanks to libdvdread and libdvdcss) and merges them into file(s) with the name extracted from the DVD. It checks for enough free space on the destination drive and compares the copied size to the size on DVD (in case something went wrong during the copying). Supports libdvdcss2.

     [b][url=https://www.exit1.org/dvdrip/]dvd::rip[/url][/b]
dvd::rip is a full featured DVD copy program written in Perl. It provides an easy to use but feature-rich Gtk+ GUI to control almost all aspects of the ripping and transcoding process. It uses the widely known video processing swissknife transcode and many other Open Source tools. dvd::rip itself is licensed under GPL / Perl Artistic License.  dvd::rip should only be used to rip a DVD to your HDD, it cannot encode video using the x264 CODEC so its of no use to us after ripping the DVD.

     [b][url=https://untrepid.com/acidrip/]AcidRip[/url][/b]
AcidRip is a Gtk2 : Perl application for ripping and encoding DVD's. It neatly wraps MPlayer and MEncoder. AcidRip should only be used to rip a DVD to your HDD, it cannot encode video using the x264 CODEC so its of no use to us after ripping the DVD.

---+---

  [size=3][color=red]Encoding[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://handbrake.fr/]Handbrake[/b][/url]
I'd recommend grabbing the source and compiling it yourself. Great for the Beginning Encoder. DO NOT use the presets for uploading here.

     [b][url=https://untrepid.com/acidrip/]AcidRip[/url][/b]
AcidRip is a Gtk2 : Perl  application for ripping and encoding DVD's. It neatly wraps MPlayer and MEncoder, which I think is pretty handy, seeing as MPlayer is by far the best bit of video playing kit around for Linux. As well as creating a simple Graphical Interface for those scared of getting down and dirty with MEncoders command line interface.

---+---

  [size=3][color=red]Subtitles[/color][/size]

     [b][url=https://ksubtile.sourceforge.net/]Ksubtitle[/url][/b]
This is an editor for the KDE environment to edit, make and save subtitles in the SRT subtitle format. It is made by Tom Deblauwe and it is completely GPL.

     [b][url=https://www.aegisub.net/]Aegisub[/url][/b]
Aegisub is an advanced subtitle editor for Windows, and UNIX-like systems, such as Linux, Mac OS X and BSD. It is open source software and free for any use. This software is still under development and should mainly be used for editing subtitles and translating (mainly Cyrillic and Greek text). [url=https://www.aegisub.net/2009/02/kumaji-explained.html]Kumaji[/url] will be the tool to use for ripping subtitles when it is ready.

[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]

fields.title: How to Connect to TehConnection's IRC Network (XChat)
fields.body:
[i]Many thanks to mephistopheles for this guide.
Discuss and ask for help [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=267]here[/url].[/i]


In order to connect to more than #TehConnection, you'll need an IRC client. We strongly recommend [url=https://xchat.org/]XChat[/url] for Linux.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Installing XChat[/b][/size][/color]

If you're using Ubuntu, Kubuntu, Xubuntu, Linux Mint, or any other Debian based flavour, use this command to install:
[br /]
[indent][pre]sudo aptitude install xchat[/pre][/indent]

If you're on Arch Linux, you'll have to type in this:
[br /]
[indent][pre]sudo pacman -Sy xchat[/pre][/indent]

Fedora Core / CentOS works a bit different:
[br /]
[indent][pre]sudo yum install xchat[/pre][/indent]

And finally, Gentoo works like this:
[br /]
[indent][pre]sudo emerge xchat[/pre][/indent]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Configuring XChat[/b][/size][/color]

Now that X-Chat is installed open it by typing [b]xchat[/b] in your terminal or [b]xchat2[/b], depending on your version.

Click XChat -> Network List (or press Ctrl-S). This should open up a new window with several (irrelevant) servers and some text boxes.

Start by filling in these:

[b]Nick Name:[/b] The nick you'd like to go by in #TehConnection, your site nick is recommended.
[b]Second Choice:[/b] Alternate nick if your preferred choice is taken.
[b]Third Choice:[/b] Third alternate, just in case.
[b]User Name:[/b] Your TehConnection username
[b]Real Name:[/b] This shows up when someone uses the /whois command on you, so either put something witty here or your TehConnection username as well.

Your window should now look like:
[br /]
[center][img]https://i42.tinypic.com/69qiwy.png[/img][/center]

Now, click [b]Add[/b] and it will give you a new entry, name it "TehConnection" and click edit. This will bring up another menu, modify it to look like this:
[br /]
[center][img]https://i43.tinypic.com/5ujln5.png[/img][/center]

Now, click close, then connect. You will now connect to our server!

If you want to join our main channel, you'll need to register your nick. Wait a few minutes to allow nickserv to settle. It does not like brand new users sometimes. Now perform this command:
[br /]
[indent][pre]/msg NICKSERV REGISTER PASSWORD EMAIL[/pre][/indent]

Replace PASSWORD & EMAIL with your details. The e-mail is irrelevant, enter anything there. The password is very important to remember though, so be careful.

You should now be logged in under your nick, so head over to the main channel by typing this where [b]SITE NICK[/b] is your TehConnection site nick and [b]IRC KEY[/b] is the key set in your profile (Click 'Edit' up above, where your stats are):
[br /]
[indent][pre]/msg Zooey AUTH SITE NICK IRC KEY

/join #TehConnection[/pre][/indent]

The next time you join the server, you'll need to login by using this command, you can add this command to the "Connect command" field to make it automatic:
[br /]
[indent][pre]/msg NICKSERV IDENTIFY PASSWORD[/pre][/indent]

If you scroll up to the images there is a nickserv field, you can put your password there and your client will automatically identify you and join you to the channel if it's in the "Favourite channels" field.

You can also specify multiple channels to join by adding to the [b]Favourite channels[/b] field. It follows the form #channel1,#channel2,channel3 etc...

For detailed IRC Network Information and channels available see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=104]here[/url].

[i]Many thanks to mephistopheles for this guide.
Discuss and ask for help [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=267]here[/url].

fields.title: Uploading Torrents
fields.body:
Some of you may find this laughable, but we all know that not everyone is at the same level, and we all started at the beginning. I threw this guide together to help out some of our newer users, and maybe boost the "Everyone upload one movie" idea. So let's get started:

1. Before we do anything with uTorrent, we need to find our personal announce url. To do this, Click the Upload link on the user toolbar. Your personal announce url is in the yellow box.

[img]https://i44.tinypic.com/ip772o.jpg[/img]

Copy it to a text file. Now we're ready to make the torrent:

2. Open up uTorrent. Click File->Create Torrent.

[img]https://i41.tinypic.com/2s8l2it.jpg[/img]

3. Click Add Directory, and browse to the folder that contains the movie you want to upload.

[img]https://i41.tinypic.com/5l8eox.jpg[/img]

4. Paste your personal announce url in the Trackers box.

[img]https://i41.tinypic.com/2mywwsp.jpg[/img]

5. Tick the Initial Seed and Private checkboxes. Initial Seed means that uTorrent will start seeding the torrent as soon as you're done, and you won't have to load it manually. (You also don't have to redownload the .torrent file after you upload it to the site.) Private means that it will disable DHT and Peer Exchange, which aren't allowed on Private Trackers as it makes it harder to track ratio, as well as possible to share to unregistered users. You can also add a comment at this point if you like. Something along the lines of "Upped by (yournamehere)" or similar if you choose. This can be left blank. Leave skip files alone, as well as web seeds, and keep piece size at auto detect.

[img]https://i39.tinypic.com/qyemmo.jpg[/img]

6. Click Create And Save As, then browse to your torrent file folder (where your actual .torrent files are stored that you've downloaded, or another location if you so choose.) In the new dialogue, your torrent name will default to the name of the directory. You should just leave it be.

7. Upload your newly made .torrent file to TehConnection, and clap giddily at the beautiful new torrent description page you made.

8. Right click the new torrent in uTorrent and click Update Tracker. This will let the tracker know that you've uploaded the torrent to the site and start adding users to the swarm.

9. Seed til the internet dies!

fields.title: Freeleech: Everything You Need to Know
fields.body:
Freeleech is our way of messing with the ratio system here on TehConnection. A torrent marked 'Freeleech!' means that the download credit you would normally accrue is not counted for the period that the torrent is freeleech. In addition to this, any upload credit you get is still counted so downloading freeleech torrents is an excellent way to increase your ratio.

You can tell a torrent is freeleech if you see 'Freeleech!' after the torrent details:
[br /]
[center]
[img]https://imgur.com/mmyZj.png[/img]
[/center]

If a torrent does not have 'Freeleech!' after it then it is not freeleech and if you download it you will impact your ratio. Unless specifically set by staff, the only freeleech torrents on Tehconnection at present are the current [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=20]Movie of the Week[/url].

In addition to freeleech, TehConnection has an innovative system is known as [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=115]Seeder Surge[/url] which encourages leeching torrents with a small number of seeders. Please ensure you read the linked article as Seeder Surge works slightly differently to traditional freeleech.

If you run into issues with download statistics being counted against you on freeleech torrents make sure to check that the freeleech didn't end while you were still downloading. If you believe that freeleech has not worked for you in some way contact staff via [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url].

fields.title: How to Play H.264/MPEG-4 AVC Files On Your PC (Windows, Mac & Linux)
fields.body:
[i]This article is a work in progress and I'd encourage all users to post in this [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=713]thread[/url] with things which have been forgotten or glossed over (there will be quite a few). Ideally we will all contribute and make this a comprehensive yet easy to understand guide.[/i]


H.264 / MPEG-4 AVC is the new standard for video compression superceding MPEG-4 ASP (DivX/Xvid). All of the H.264 content you will find on TehConnection will be stored in the Matroska container due to current limitations with the .mp4 container. 

What is a Matroska (.mkv) file? If you're reading this you have most likely come across one or two during your trawls around TehConnection. Matroska is an modern open standard media container: think of it as an envelope which allows you to put different video and audio streams inside it (you can even add subtitle streams and chapters). You can learn more about Matroska and what it is able to do from [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matroska]Wikipedia[/url], [url=https://forum.doom9.org/showthread.php?t=54306]Doom9[/url] and the [url=https://www.matroska.org/]Matroska[/url] website.

Other than computers (Windows, Mac or Linux) there isn't a lot of standalone hardware support for the Matroska standard yet. We have tutorials on converting and playing these files for other pieces of hardware such as Apple TV (tutorial coming...), Playstation 3 ([url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=90]Ubuntu[/url], [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=94]Windows[/url]) and Xbox360 ([url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=1236]Windows[/url]).

If you're interested in standalone support you can start by looking at the [url=https://www.wdc.com/en/products/products.asp?driveid=572]WDTV[/url] ([url=https://wdtvforum.com/main/]forum[/url]), [url=https://www.popcornhour.com/onlinestore/]Popcorn Hour[/url] ([url=https://www.networkedmediatank.com/index.php]forum[/url]) and the [url=https://netgear.com/Products/Entertainment/DigitalMediaPlayers/EVA9150.aspx]Netgear EVA9150[/url]. Of course building your own media PC is also an option ;-)

The more important concern, however, is how to play these files on your PC. There are a few methods, some better than others but I'd suggest finding which one which you find the best.


[align=center]---------------------------+|||+---------------------------[/align]


[b][size=5][u]Windows[/u][/size][/b]

There are two ways to gain Matroska playback in Windows. Use a media player which relies on DirectShow CODECs to be installed or install a media player with its own CODECs.

It is far better to choose the second option for a number of reasons:

 - Programs which include their own CODECs will actually playback 99.99% of all media files in existence with no need  for any other sort of CODEC pack at all meaning the number of programs you need to have installed is greatly reduced.

 - Although this isn't so common anymore, installing multiple filters and CODECs can possibly cause conflict and break support for certain types of media playback.

The following media players are examples of payers which include their own CODECs.

 - [b][url=https://www.videolan.org/vlc/]VLC[/url][/b] - A Cross platform media player and streaming server.

 - [b][url=https://kmplayer.en.softonic.com/]KMPlayer[/url][/b] - A free multi-format media player.

The Haali Media Splitter is one of the best filters for Matroska file playback. This can be found [url=https://haali.cs.msu.ru/mkv/]here[/url]. Installing this will ensure best possible Matroska playback results. Take a look at echohead's excellent [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=871]guide to installing KMPlayer and Haali[/url].

If you really must use a DirectShow based player it is strongly suggested you use Media Player Classic Home Cinema ([url=https://mpc-hc.sourceforge.net/]MPC-HC[/url]). There is also a 64 bit version of MPC-HC and when combined with the 64 bit version of Haali can greatly improve playback performance on 64 bit systems (guide coming...).

If you are having trouble playing back high definition Matroska files because of your hardware then [url=https://www.coreavc.com/]CoreAVC[/url] could help. CoreAVC is an extremely efficient software H.264 decoder which has been known to allow slower machines to play H.264 video much more smoothly. The drawback with this software is that it is payware and doesn't produce as nice looking playback as Haali.



[b][size=5][u]Mac[/u][/size][/b]

As with most Mac software Matroska playback is fairly easy to enable. There are three main ways to play Matroska files on your Mac:

[b][url=https://www.videolan.org/vlc/]VLC[/url][/b] - A Cross platform media player and streaming server.

[b][url=https://mplayerosx.sttz.ch/]MPLayerOSX[/url][/b] - The Movie Player. This is an excellent media player because it supports multi-threaded decoding (FFmpeg-MT, as of Rev. 8).

[b][url=https://perian.org/]Perian[/url][/b] - A plugin for QuickTime which supports many popular video formats.

[b][url=https://code.google.com/p/movist/]Movist[/url][/b] - Movie Player for Mac OS X based on QuickTime & FFmpeg. Extremely lightweight and fast scrubbing. Freeware.



[b][size=5][u]Linux[/u][/size][/b]

Enabling Matroska support for Linux is fairly easy too.

[b][url=https://www.videolan.org/vlc/]VLC[/url][/b] - A Cross platform media player and streaming server.

Ffmpeg (Coming Soon...)

Gstreamer (Coming soon...)

fields.title: Reviews
fields.body:
'Reviews' is a handy feature on TehConnection. They are all written by users of this site and provide a place for users to rate and give feedback on films they have watched. In order to browse all the current reviews click the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/reviews.php]'Reviews'[/url] tab at the top of any page.

Any user can contribute a review for any movie. In addition, movies can have multiple reviews by different users. In order to see the reviews for a movie you find on the site while browsing, click the reviews link under the film's poster in the top right. To add a new review, use the reviews tab.  Then click the reviews menu in the top left next to the help menu. Under that you will find the add review link. Alternatively, if you're on a film page already you can click 'Torrent Menu > Review This Film'.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Why should I write a review?[/b][/size][/color]

This site is more than just a way to download movies. One of the site's goals is to help its members discover new film that they would be interested in but otherwise might not have ever discovered. Reviews are a great way to tell your peers about the greatest new movies you have seen.

[color=red]NOTES:[/color]
[list]
[*]Do [b]NOT[/b] copy and paste a review written by anyone but yourself. This is plagiarism, and is unfair to the other users of the site. It is not allowed on the tracker, and you will be caught for it.
[*]Do [b]NOT[/b] sign your review. Your name goes next to the review anyway, there's no need to plaster it all over the place![/list]

fields.title: Movie of the Week (MotW)
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]The 'Movie of the Week'[/b][/size][/color]

Every week here at TehConnection, a movie is picked as Movie of the Week (MotW). 

We use the MotW as a way to showcase what we believe is great cinema. We realise that everyone has different tastes and what is considered great by one person is not necessarily so to another. As such, we make an effort to vary our choices and have a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=967]forum thread[/url] dedicated to taking suggestions from everybody. For more information on how the MotW is chosen see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=153]this article[/url].

As an added bonus, the MotW is freeleech for the entire week! This means you can download and watch the film with no penalty if you haven't heard about it before or are unsure if it is worth your time.

Staff change the MotW weekly, usually around 1200 GMT Sunday. There is deliberately no absolute set time for this change.

A Montage which includes all past MotW can be found [url=https://tehconnection.eu/montage.php?id=11]here[/url] and a discussion board for all past the MotW is [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewforum&forumid=30]here[/url].

fields.title: Release Groups
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Scene and p2p Release Groups[/b][/size][/color]

All encodes are [b]NOT[/b] created equal. Some are so close to the source that you physically cannot see the difference between the two (this is known as "transparent" encoding) and some are so bad you might be better off watching a VHS tape. The rest are somewhere in the middle. TC [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=94]believes[/url] that quality is important, so we aim to archive the very best encodes, made from the best available sources.

There are many groups of people who encode films and release them to the file-sharing world (often known as "encoding groups" or "release groups"), and they all have different motivations and priorities. A group's name is normally denoted at the end of the file or folder for any particular release after the hyphen. For example, head over to our [url=https://jumpcut.to/something11770]Inception film page[/url] and open one of the 720p torrent descriptions. Depending on which one you opened you notice that the release group responsible for the torrents is either 'CROSSBOW' or 'ESiR'.

Groups that are part of the [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warez_scene]Scene[/url] follow a basic set of rules, but their goal is to release an encode before any other group which often means quality consideration is less than it could be. Peer to peer (p2p) groups are any groups not part of the Scene. They are commonly found on private trackers but can also release to public trackers, forums, DDL boards or even to FTP sites.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]How to Tell What's What[/b][/size][/color]

If you aren't sure whether the release you have is Scene or p2p, a fast method of finding out is to search for the release in a public [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pre_channel#Pre_database]pre database[/url]. If the release is in the database it is Scene, if not then chances are it is p2p.

There is no complete database of every Scene release ever released but many of the public ones come fairly close with several million records being available. Some of the better pre databases online include [url=https://pre.corrupt-net.org/]Corrupt-Net[/url], [url=https://predb.me/]PreDB.me[/url], [url=https://www.orlydb.com/]orlydb[/url], and [url=https://www.srrdb.com/]srrdb[/url].

In addition to these databases, TC maintains an up-to-date(ish) [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=147]list of Scene groups that release films[/url].

p2p releases can come from anyone not part of the Scene and therefore not subject to their rules, so there is a lot of variance in encode quality. Every encode should be judged on its own merit; however, in the course of moderating TC's large selection of torrents, we have observed some trends. You may find this [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=148]commented list of p2p groups[/url] to be useful in your search for quality.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Fake Groups[/size][/b][/color]

Sometimes encoders will tag their releases with fake group names.

[b]Example[/b]: The.Number.23.UNRATED.DVDRip.XviD-NUMBER23

These group names are usually part of the movie name itself, and change from release to release. If you find one of these, you will obviously not recognize the group name, so you should look for it on a predb to determine if it is a Scene release or not. If you are still lost, send a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url].

fields.title: BBCode Text Formatting
fields.body:
Welcome to the TehConnection BBCode page! As of [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=2821]update #3[/url] we have a powerful BBCode parser implemented by our awesome coders. This page documents all the available text effects you are able to include in your forum posts, torrent comments, reviews, PMs, montages and anywhere else you can write on site.

Firefox users may find the [url=https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/bbcodextra/]BBCodeXtra[/url] add-on useful.

[size=4][b]Text Styles[/b] (b, i, u, s, sup, sub, spoiler, acronym, size, color, font)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]b]...[[i][/i]/b][/color]
The [[i][/i]b] tag formats its contents using [b]bold text[/b].

[color=red][[i][/i]i]...[[i][/i]/i][/color]
The [[i][/i]i] tag formats its contents using [i]italic text[/i].

[color=red][[i][/i]u]...[[i][/i]/u][/color]
The [[i][/i]u] tag adds an [u]underline[/u] to its contents.

[color=red][[i][/i]s]...[[i][/i]/s][/color]
The [[i][/i]s] tag adds a [s]strikeout[/s] to its contents.

[color=red][[i][/i]sup]...[[i][/i]/sup][/color]
The [[i][/i]sup] tag formats its contents as [sup]superscript[/sup].

[color=red][[i][/i]sub]...[[i][/i]/sub][/color]
The [[i][/i]sub] tag formats its contents as [sub]subscript[/sub].

[color=red][[i][/i]spoiler]...[[i][/i]/spoiler][/color]
The [[i][/i]spoiler] tag formats its contents as a [spoiler]spoiler[/spoiler]

[color=red][[i][/i]size=n]...[[i][/i]/size][/color]
The [[i][/i]size] tag lets you control the size of your text. The size given must be a number from 0 to 7:

[size=0]This text is size 0 (tiny).[/size]
[size=1]This text is size 1 (very small).[/size]
[size=2]This text is size 2 (small).[/size]
[size=3]This text is size 3 (normal).[/size]
[size=4]This text is size 4 (large).[/size]
[size=5]This text is size 5 (very large).[/size]
[size=6]This text is size 6 (huge).[/size]
[size=7]This text is size 7 (ridiculous).[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]color=n]...[[i][/i]/color][/color]
The [[i][/i]color] tag allows you to control the text color. You can specify the color as either a three-digit hex code, like #069, or as a six-digit hex code, like #E34715, or as a standard HTML color name, like red. For example, [[i][/i]color=red]Red[[i][/i]/color] will appear as [color=red]Red[/color], and [[i][/i]color=#069]True blue![[i][/i]/color] will appear as [color=#069]True blue![/color]

[color=red][[i][/i]font=n]...[[i][/i]/font][/color]
The [[i][/i]font] tag allows you to alter the text's typeface. You may use specific font names, like Times New Roman, or generic font names, like cursive. Note that if you want to use a name that contains spaces, like Times New Roman, you should surround it in quotation marks, like this: [[i][/i]font="Times New Roman"]...[[i][/i]/font].

Note that the [[i][/i]font] tag allows you to separate font names with commas, just like CSS does, so that if a given font is not available, your choice of fallback fonts can be used instead: [[i][/i]font=Arial,Helv,Helvetica,sans]...[[i][/i]/font]

The [[i][/i]font] tag also recognizes the five standard CSS "generic" font names:
[list=circle]
    [*] serif - A serifed font, like Times or Roman
    [*] sans-serif - A sans-serif font, like Helvetica or Arial (also sansserif, sans serif, and just sans)
    [*] cursive - A cursive font, like Zapf-Chancery
    [*] fantasy - A "fantasy" font, like Western
    [*] monospace - A fixed-width font, like Courier (also mono) 
[/list]


[size=4][b]Links[/b] (url)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]url=n]...[[i][/i]/url][/color]
The [[i][/i]url] tag allows you to insert links to external documents. Note that if you paste a URL anywhere on the site it will automatically convert it into a clickable link.

[[i][/i]url=https://www.google.com/]Google![[i][/i]/url]   -->   [url=https://www.google.com/]Google![/url]


[color=red][[i][/i]img]...[[i][/i]/img][/color]
This tag inserts an image into your document. You should provide a URL to the image between the start and end [[i][/i]img] tags. The URL must end with .jpg, .png or .gif; for example:

[[i][/i]img]https://static.tehconnection.eu/styles/hadronic/images/logo_small.png[[i][/i]/img] would give:

[img]https://static.tehconnection.eu/styles/hadronic/images/logo_small.png[/img]


[size=4][b]Alignment[/b] (left, right, center, indent)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]center]...[[i][/i]/center][/color]
The [[i][/i]center] tag causes its contents to be broken into a separate block and aligned horizontally to the center of the page:
[center]Centered text![/center]

[color=red][[i][/i]left]...[[i][/i]/left][/color]
The [[i][/i]left] tag causes its contents to be broken into a separate block and aligned horizontally to the left of the page:

[left]Left-aligned text![/left]

[color=red][[i][/i]right]...[[i][/i]/right][/color]
The [[i][/i]right] tag causes its contents to be broken into a separate block and aligned horizontally to the right of the page:

[right]Right-aligned text![/right]

[color=red][[i][/i]indent]...[[i][/i]/indent][/color]
The [[i][/i]indent] tag causes its contents to be broken into a separate block and be to indented, to have an approximately half-inch margin on the left side:

[indent]Indented text![/indent]


[size=4][b]Tables[/b] (table, tr, td)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]table]...[[i][/i]tr]...[[i][/i]td]...[[i][/i]/td]...[[i][/i]/tr]...[[i][/i]/table][/color]
Tables will adjust their width based upon the text entered.

Code:
[[i][/i]table]
[[i][/i]tr]
[[i][/i]td]This text appears in the first cell on the first line.[[i][/i]/td]
[[i][/i]td]This text appears in the second cell on the first line.[[i][/i]/td]
[[i][/i]/tr]
[[i][/i]tr]
[[i][/i]td]This text appears in the first cell on the second line.[[i][/i]/td]
[[i][/i]/tr]
[[i][/i]/table]

Output:
[table]
[tr]
[td]This text appears in the first cell on the first line.[/td]
[td]This text appears in the second cell on the first line.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]This text appears in the first cell on the second line.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]


[size=4][b]Containers[/b] (code, quote, pre)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]code]...[[i][/i]/code][/color]
The [[i][/i]code] tag is designed for representing content from various programming languages without requiring use of special formatting to display it. Every character between [[i][/i]code] and [[i][/i]/code] will be copied directly to the output, with whitespace including newlines and tabs, retained and preformatted. The only exception to this is that the first newline after the [[i][/i]code] tag will be removed, and the last newline before [[i][/i]/code] will be removed, just to keep the output from having wasted blank lines in it.

[code]
def foo():
    print("Here's some code!")
[/code]


[color=red][[i][/i]quote]...[[i][/i]/quote]
[[i][/i]quote=John]...[[i][/i]/quote][/color]
The quote tag is fairly self explanatory but it has been flashed up to give us the ability to add links. Clicking the 'quote' button on an forum post will quote a user like this [[i][/i]quote=sitenick]contents of quoted post[[i][/i]/quote] which gives us:

[quote=sitenick]contents of quoted post[/quote]

[color=red][[i][/i]pre]...[[i][/i]/pre][/color]
The [[i][/i]pre] tag is designed to display preformatted text on a web page. This tag will display text in a fixed width font and preserve any spaces and line breaks which otherwise might be stripped out by our forums.

[pre]Hello,  I  am  a  sentence  constructed  entirely  from  preformatted  text.
   Look,
      I
         see
            a
               boat![/pre]


[size=4][b]Lists[/b] (list)[/size]

[color=red][[i][/i]list]...[[i][/i]*]...[[i][/i]*]...[[i][/i]/list]
[[i][/i]list=type]...[[i][/i]*]...[[i][/i]*]...[[i][/i]/list][/color]
The [[i][/i]list] tag is designed for creating lists of things. In its default form, where no type is given, it creates a simple bullet-point list, like this:

[table]
[tr]
[td]
[[i][/i]list]
[[i][/i]*]John
[[i][/i]*]Mary
[[i][/i]*]Bill 
[[i][/i]*]Sue 
[[i][/i]/list]
[/td]
[td]
[list]
[*]John
[*]Mary
[*]Bill 
[*]Sue 
[/list]
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

Notice that while you do need to have an ending [[i][/i]/list] tag, you don't need to have an ending [[i][/i]/*] tag for each [[i][/i]*] tag; this makes creating lists somewhat simpler.

You can also create numbered lists by specifying what type of list you want; for example, if you want a numbered list, use type "1", or for an alphabetic list, use type "A", or for Roman numerals, use type "i". All possible list types are listed below:

[list]
[*] For an ordered list using Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3...) use [[i][/i]list=1]...[[i][/i]/list]
[*] For an ordered list using Arabic numerals with a leading zero (01, 02, 03...) use [[i][/i]list=01]...[[i][/i]/list]
[*] For an ordered list using capital letters (A, B, C...) use [[i][/i]list=A]...[[i][/i]/list]
[*] For an ordered list using lower case letters (a, b, c...) use [[i][/i]list=a]...[[i][/i]/list]
[*] For an ordered list using capital Roman numerals (I, II, III...) use [[i][/i]list=I]...[[i][/i]/list]
[*] For an ordered list using lower case Roman numerals (i, ii, iii...) use [[i][/i]list=i]...[[i][/i]/list]
[/list]


This concludes your lesson with BBCode and TehConnection; go forth and make your text sexy!

fields.title: How to Upload An Untouched DVDR (DVDFab)
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DVDFab Platinum[/b][/size][/color] ([url=https://www.dvdfab.com/]https://www.dvdfab.com/[/url])

This is a simple program to use. Although it has lots of options, it should not be used to do re-encoding to Xvid or x264, or even re-encoding to DVD5, but to rip the disc to an untouched DVD9 it's intuitive and removes almost all protections in the market.

First, this is what it looks like when you open it:[br /]

[center][img]https://img38.imageshack.us/img38/7987/1552009225322.jpg[/img][/center]

If DVD is not the default option, you should choose 'DVD to DVD' on the left hand menu and then 'Full Disc'.

After that, choose to see the options (the green button on top right) and ensure they look like this:[br /]

[center][img]https://img36.imageshack.us/img36/214/1552009225342.jpg[/img][/center]

Remember to select all of the protection removal options. Next find out which region your DVD is; this is usually specified on the packaging. Change the "To Remove RCE, specify the disc region's code" option to the one needed for your disc. This is step is important to make sure the DVD will play in any region. If your DVD is R0 (all regions), leave the 'Any' option checked.

These are the only options you might need to change. After that, click OK and go back to the main interface. Now insert the DVD:[br /]

[center][img]https://img38.imageshack.us/img38/7340/1552009230832.jpg[/img][/center]

It will do some checks to discover the DVD size, protections, and features available. When it finished that, you will see something like this:[br /]

[center][img]https://img35.imageshack.us/img35/6307/1552009225738.jpg[/img][/center]

Below the 'Source' option you can choose the target folder for the rip. You can choose between two options:
[list=circle]
[*]Rip to a Folder; yellow icon on the right: If you choose the folder, the DVD will be ripped to: [folder path here]/FullDisc/DVD name (Volume Label) with the VIDEO_TS and AUDIO_TS folders inside.
[*]Rip to an ISO image file; white option with a disc icon: this will create an image of the DVD so it can be burned right away.
[/list]

TehConnection encoders prefer Ripping to folder so it's easier to encode. If you wish to have your rip encoded, it's better to choose this option. Anyway, choose which one you prefer and continue.

If you can choose all the options, it's important to do this:
[list=circle]
[*] Copying: All [u]Enabled[/u]
[*] Removing: All [u][b]Un[/b]-checked[/u]
[*] Navigation: All [u][b]Un[/b]-checked[/u] (you might want to remove the FBI warnings, but in this case I suggest you to leave it un-checked, so the DVD is really untouched, and to prevent possible playback problems)
[/list]

Leave the volume label as it is.

Now the most important step:

Change the last option to [b]DVD9[/b] and see if [b]Quality: 100%[/b] is displayed.

This will make sure no re-encoding is done, and the DVD will remain untouched and identical as it is on the disc.

Review all the options to make sure everything is right. After this, you are ready to begin the ripping process. Choose 'Start'.[br /]

[center][img]https://img34.imageshack.us/img34/8334/1552009225911.jpg[/img][/center]

When it ends (this usually doesn't take a long time, as it's almost just a copy and paste thing) click 'Finished' and close the program.

Your untouched DVD rip is ready. Check if it's okay and play it with your player of choice. If possible, burn the rip before uploading to make sure it's 100% working.

Now upload it to TehConnection and make everybody happy. We need more Untouched DVD-R's.

fields.title: Avatars
fields.body:
First, find an image that you like, and that is within the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=88]rules[/url]. Its width should not be any more than 150 pixels (152 actually), but it will be [i]automagically[/i] resized if necessary.

You will then have to find a place to host it, such as [url=https://photobucket.com/]Photobucket[/url], [url=https://imgur.com/]Imgur[/url] or [url=https://imageshack.us/]ImageShack[/url]; however, there are many other image hosting alternatives, all of which are perfectly acceptable.

Once you have uploaded the image to the site of your choice; all that is left to do is to copy the image URL to the avatar field in your Edit Profile page; click [b]Edit[/b] next to your username to see it.

Make sure that the URL you copy from your image host is one that ends with the file extension of your image (.png, .jpg, .gif etc...) otherwise it will not work.

Please do not make a forum post just to test your avatar. If everything worked ok, you should see your avatar in your profile page.

If you do not want to see avatars on site check the option to disable them in your Edit Profile page.

fields.title: Backing up all torrent files used by uTorrent
fields.body:
Most of us have come across the situation where we must back up our data, switch over to another system, etc. Since we are all seeders here, we must have a practical way of backing up everything that's seeding. It's relatively simple.

1. Locate your application data folder. If you are using Windows Xp, it should be located in C:\Documents and Settings\[b]%Username%[/b]\Application Data. In Vista: C:\Users\%Username%\AppData\Roaming Or you could just type "%AppData%" in the address bar.
[img]https://img88.imageshack.us/img88/1035/51184915qj7.jpg[/img]

2. Located in that folder should be all your torrents. uTorrent makes a read only copy of every torrent you load into it.
[img]https://img257.imageshack.us/img257/5149/85898338sy6.jpg[/img]

3. Now just copy over the entire folder to a backup location, then when you reinstall uTorrent, over write the new folder with the backup.

Of course this will only backup the ".torrents" not the actual downloaded and seeded files.

fields.title: BitTorrent
fields.body:
BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer file sharing (P2P) communications protocol. BitTorrent is a method of distributing large amounts of data widely without the original distributor incurring the entire costs of hardware, hosting, and bandwidth resources. Instead, when data is distributed using the BitTorrent protocol, each recipient supplies pieces of the data to newer recipients, reducing the cost and burden on any given individual source, providing redundancy against system problems, and reducing dependence on the original distributor.

The protocol is the brainchild of programmer Bram Cohen, who designed it in April 2001 and released a first implementation on 2 July 2001. It is now maintained by Cohen's company BitTorrent, Inc.

Usage of the protocol accounts for significant traffic on the Internet, but the precise amount has proven difficult to measure.

There are numerous compatible BitTorrent clients, written in a variety of programming languages, and running on a variety of computing platforms.

fields.title: BitTorrent: Becky's Beginner Guide
fields.body:
Hi guys! Sadly, the original and "official" Beginner's Guide to BitTorrent has been lost forever due to the tragedies of 10/23/07 (Unless someone had a backup lol?). Anyway, here's a replacement..I even remade some of my glorious stick figure drawings.

[size=5]Becky's Beginner Guide to BitTorrent[/size][size=1]
[i]*** I use uTorrent in my screenshots, which is the client I recommend, however, there are plenty of torrent clients around.
I don't support the illegal downloading and uploaded of pirated materials. BitTorrent is perfectly legal, FYI.
[b]This is a BEGINNER guide, aka read this if you have NO idea what BitTorrent is, or what it does. There are more technical guides out there, but this is for those who are not very tech savvy.[/i][/size]
[u]
Table of Contents
[/u]
1.What is BitTorrent?
2.How does it work, exactly?
3.What's a tracker?
4.How do I download something?
5.What are ratios, and why should I worry about them?
6.What clients are available for me to use?
7.Defining "connectable" or "clever" (SOLVES 90% OF UPLOAD ISSUES)
8.End Notes
[/b]

[size=4]
1.What is BitTorrent?[/size]

        Let's look to our trusty Wikipedia and what it has to say on BitTorrent...

        [i]"BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer file sharing (P2P) communications protocol. BitTorrent is a method of distributing large amounts of data widely without the original distributor incurring the entire costs of hardware, hosting and bandwidth resources."[/i]

        Wow, that is a mouthful...let me try and paraphrase this in laymen's terms...

        [i]"BitTorrent is a type of P2P protocol which people can use to send and receive large files without putting too much pressure on a particular server.[/i]

        Much easier, right? BitTorrent is a medium between people who want to share data with each other, whether it be music, a program, or the latest update on a game. It also saves space and bandwidth for site owners who don't want to put so much on their server. You use a BitTorrent client (program) which connects to a tracker (explained later), which then lets you connect to other people and get the data you need.
[size=4]
2. But how does it work, exactly?[/size]

        BitTorrent really isn't that complicated once you see how it works, but we'll start out simple. First, we need to define a few terms.
        If you have downloaded the ENTIRE torrent to your PC, or if you were the person originally uploaded it, then you are a seeder. If you are still downloading any part of it, you are a leecher. All of the leechers and seeders together make up the swarm.
        Data is transferred from the seeders to the leechers, as shown here...

[img=https://img48.imageshack.us/img48/7528/33926898ex8.png]

        As you can see, the seeders are sending what they have to the leechers...they aren't sending anything to each other though, since they finished the torrent.
        But wait, there's more! In order to make the downloading/uploading way more efficient and quicker, leechers also send data to each other to finish everything faster than just the seeders sending data.
        Let's say for example, you're downloading an album, and so is Bob. Both you and Bob are getting data from seeders, but not at the same rate. Bob gets Song 5, but doesn't have Song 4. You have Song 4 but not Song 5...so you send it to each other! Everyone is working together to get the download done.

[img=https://img155.imageshack.us/img155/4913/93231886pl0.png]

        So yeah, not that complicated, right?
[size=4]
3. What's this tracker I keep hearing about?[/size]

        Well, obviously people don't just randomly connect to each other computer wise, right? They need something to start the process. The tracker acts both as a "door" of sorts to other people and as a bouncer at the same time. In those pictures, you could almost think of that black line seperating the seeders and leechers as the tracker, in a way.
        Trackers do more than help people connect, though. Many trackers nowadays are equipped with anti-cheating systems that kick people trying to fake downoading/uploading in a swarm " - they also find and detect people who are trying to send bad (and possibly malicious) data to other people.
        You see, in order to connect to a tracker you need a .torrent file. The .torrent file contains, in a way, exactly what should be on that torrent. If a peer tries to send bad or false data to the tracker or other peers, they get cut off.
        So trackers are a good thing!

        Q. But what data are they getting about me personally?
        A. Well, a tracker should only be getting a few things, that being your IP and your upload/download stats*. Your peers will get the same thing " - I know, it seems uncool to have your IP plastered all over a swarm, but in this case having people's IP is a good thing " - if someone is trying to send bad data and the tracker isn't catching them, you can block the IP.
        *The tracker collects certain data too, like what client your using, header files, etc...but trackerlog information is pretty meaningless unless you're an admin looking for cheaters, so I wouldn't worry about it too much.
[size=4]
4. Alright, so how do I download something?[/size]

        I know I know, you're itching to get going, I'm sure. Well, let's crack open uTorrent here...once you've got a .torrent file on your PC, double click it, and you should get something like this...

[img=https://img90.imageshack.us/img90/3091/40740752go6.png]

        The button with the three dots (...) lets you choose where you want the downloaded file to go. Specify a location, check or uncheck what you want in the box below, and hit OK. It should start downloading right away unless something is up with the tracker..

[img=https://img137.imageshack.us/img137/914/92520209wh3.png]

        That's it. Make sure to keep your torrent running once it's finished! If you have to ask why, read on to the next section...
[size=4]
5. What are ratios, and why do I care?[/size]

        Remember, BitTorrent only works because there are seeders to send the data around. If everyone simply leeched and left (a "hit and run", as they say), there wouldn't be any seeders...and eventually, the torrent would die! Now we don't want that, do we?
        Your ratio is the amount of data you've uploaded divided by the amount downloaded. So if you upload the exact amount you download, you have a ratio of 1.0...if you don't want to seed something forever, at least getting your ratio to 1.0 is a nice goal. That way you've gotten the chance to share something.
        But, if you upload LESS than what you take, then you have a bad ratio...and in some torrent sites, the site records your ratio " - in many cases, if you have a really poor ratio, you're kicked off the site!

        [size=3]Remember: Sharing is caring![/size]

[size=4]
6. What clients can I use for BitTorrent?[/size]

        There are dozens and dozens, but in terms of Windows, my first and only choice is uTorrent. It is light on resources, easy to install, and easy to navigate. https://www.utorrent.com/
        *I do not like the person that bought uTorrent over this past year, so I have stopped upgrading once the new owner came into place. I use, and recommend, the 1.6 builds.

        As for Macs, I definitely recommend Azureus. Although it can be a bit heavy since it's using Java, it's certainly one of the most stable of clients for Mac PCs. https://azureus.sourceforge.net/

        Before you choose a client, do your research! Some websites BAN certain clients, and you can get your account killed for using a banned client! But most of, if not all sites , will allow uTorrent or Azureus, so your best bet is probably with one of those.
[size=4]
7. What is "connectable" or "clever", and why do I need to be...?[/size]

        Okay, so you may have noticed that you aren't connecting to many people...or that you belong to a site where they list you as unconnectable or "Not clever". But what does this mean?
        Let's pretend you and your friend are on two sides of a door. Your friend has a key, but you don't. You might be able to open the door, but it would require a lot of banging and attention to get your friend to know to do so.
        Now, let's say neither of you have a key. How can you open the door? Exactly, you can't.
        Basically, when you aren't connectable, you are unable to receive requests to connect to peers. You can send out some, and hope that connectable people there accept it. But if no one in the swarm is connectable...how are

        Take a look at www.portforward.com and it's hundreds of tutorials on how to get your PC or router set up correctly if you need to.
[size=4]
8. End Notes
[/size]
        That's about it. Those that remember the original tutorial know this is lacking in a bit, but hey, what can yah do?

        Anyway, feel free to ask me whatever, here or via PM...if not me, there's always other people around to help. Just try not to ask a question that's plainly answered in the tutorial, please? That just shows you didn't actually take the time to read it, which is not cool.

        [i]Yours Truly,
        Becky[/i]

Well, there we go. Sad. I miss my original. I might get around to making my Port Forwarding guide again sometime, and my other tutorials, but we'll see.

Tutorial made by [url=https://what.cd/user.php?id=4074]Becky[/url]

fields.title: Definitions of commonly misunderstood terms
fields.body:
[b]Seeding[/b]: Many people confuse this term with the term uploading.  Seeding means that you are letting the tracker know that you can begin uploading data whereas uploading refers to transferring data to other people in the swarm.  You get nothing for seeding alone but you get upload credit for uploading.  It is important to make this distinction when asking for help because they are two entirely different things.

[b]Snatch[/b]: This term is often confused with leeching as in the sentence, "I'm snatching a torrent." In reality a snatch refers to completing the download.  So it is proper to say "This torrent has 20 snatches" but it is not proper to say "There are 20 people snatching this torrent."

[b]Peers[/b]: This is a term that is commonly misused throughout the BitTorrent community.  In many clients peers is misused to refer to what are actually leechers.  The term actually refers to both the seeders and the leechers. 
  
[b]Passkey/password/IRC key[/b]:  Your passkey is something that is embedded in the torrent files you download and upload to ensure that you get credited accordingly.  Your password is what you use to login to the site or authenticate with nickserv on IRC.  The passwords for IRC and the site do not have to be the same nor must they be different.  Your IRC key is something you set in your profile so that you can join members only channels like #TehConnection.

[b]Connectable[/b]: It is often thought that if you are not connectable you can't upload to anybody or you can't seed.  However, connectable actually doesn't mean that at all.  If you aren't connectable the only thing you can't do is connect to other people that are also not connectable.  You will still be able to connect to people that are connectable.

fields.title: Distributed Hash Table (DHT): Disable in Azureus & uTorrent
fields.body:
DHT - Distributed hash table

Distributed hash tables (DHTs) are a class of decentralized distributed systems that provide a lookup service similar to a hash table: (name, value) pairs are stored in the DHT, and any participating node can efficiently retrieve the value associated with a given name. Responsibility for maintaining the mapping from names to values is distributed among the nodes, in such a way that a change in the set of participants causes a minimal amount of disruption. This allows DHTs to scale to extremely large numbers of nodes and to handle continual node arrivals, departures, and failures.

DHTs form an infrastructure that can be used to build more complex services, such as distributed file systems, peer-to-peer file sharing and content distribution systems, cooperative web caching, multicast, anycast, domain name services, and instant messaging. Notable distributed networks that use DHTs include BitTorrent (with extensions), eDonkey network, YaCy, and the Coral Content Distribution Network.

[u]Why is it important to disable DHT[/u]

If you have enabled DHT you could be uploading to people who don't even have access to the site so you won't be receiving the proper credit for your uploads & downloads. You will be sharing data out of the tracker and those ghost peers will be using your bandwidth to download from you.
That's why you are forced now to re-download your torrents from the site if you didn't create the torrent file properly.
But there is another problem with DHT, it opens way too many connections to your computer and it could cause many problems ... for example your router could run out of memory and freeze often, or your connection becomes very slow.
One of the first processes that fails is DNS relay, which is why existing connections  continue to work but new connections, like web browsing, starts failing.



[b]In Azureus:[/b]

1. Tools/Options/Connection (Tab)/ under "Peer Sources - Select the default permitted sources for peer connections" only check "From a tracker" and [b]uncheck[/b]:  
- Decentralized tracking     
- Supplied by another peer
- Added by a plugin

2. Tools/Options/Plugins/Distributed DB/ [b]uncheck[/b]: - Enable the distributed database

3. Tools/Options/Plugins/Distributed Tracker/[b]uncheck[/b]: -Only track normal torrents when their tracker is unavailable
4. Tools/Options/Tracker/Sharing/[b]check[/b]: - Private torrent - only accept torrents from the tracker 
(This should automatically grey out the option bellow: "Allow decentralized tracker when tracker is unavailable")

Click on the Save button and restart Azureus.
You should see a red dot and "Disabled" on the bottom of the main Azureus window.


[b]In uTorrent:[/b]
Options/Preferences/BitTorrent/ [b]uncheck[/b]:  
- Enable DHT Network 
- Enable DHT for new torrents

Click OK to save changes.
You should see "DHT: Disabled" on the bottom of the main uTorrent window.

fields.title: Bittorrent From Multiple Locations/IPs
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Am I Able to Download/Seed From More Than One Computer?[/b][/size][/color]

Yes, you may. TehConnection permits up to three ([b]3[/b]) simultaneous IP addresses to connect per account. This means that you may have three ([b]3[/b]) different computers connected to the tracker at any one time. Any more than three ([b]3[/b]) connections at once will result in a warning, or worse.

The tracker will not be confused and will track statistics correctly. This is because, like most private trackers, TehConnection uses a passkey system.

Each user has unique passkey associated with their account. Each torrent file you download is auto-generated to be unique to this passkey. When you download a torrent file, you are not downloading the same torrent file as another user downloads - each torrent file is auto-generated for each user. No matter what IP Address you connect from, the tracker will recognize your account based on your unique passkey instead of your IP address.
[br /]
[indent][i]Note: sharing your torrent files among friends is forbidden for this reason. All download and upload activity is recorded against your account.[/i][/indent]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]I Am Currently On a Different IP Than My Usual One, But I Want to Log In to the Site. Is This Allowed?[/b][/size][/color]

You may log in from as many IPs as you like. You should avoid download or upload from many different locations as it will raise red flags on your account.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]My Friend and I Have Accounts Here. Could My Friend Log In to the Site With My Computer Or From My Network?[/b][/size][/color]

Be careful when logging in from a friend's computer or vice versa if your friend also has an account. Both your account and your friend's account will be linked forever. If one of you violates the rules, you can both end up being disabled along with any other accounts linked to either account.

fields.title: Paranoia Level
fields.body:
The paranoia level setting in your profile allows you to hide various levels of information from other members on site. This setting is accessible from your Edit Profile page; click [b]Edit[/b] next to your username.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Levels[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[indent][list=circle]
[*] Level 0 - Hidden: Nothing is hidden! ([b]default[/b]).
[*] Level 1 - Hidden: [b]seeding[/b] and [b]leeching[/b] torrents.
[*] Level 2 - Hidden: [b]Level 1[/b] plus [b]snatched[/b] torrents.
[*] Level 3 - Hidden: [b]Level 2[/b] plus [b]uploaded[/b] torrents.
[*] Level 4 - Hidden: [b]Level 3[/b] plus [b]uploaded/downloaded[/b] amounts.
[*] Level 5 - Hidden: [b]Level 4[/b] plus the [b]Last Seen[/b] field and [b]Ranks[/b].
[/list][/indent]

At Level 3 your username will be replaced by [b]Anonymous[/b] when you upload a torrent in the main site IRC channel. This can be useful if you plan on uploading lots of torrents and do not want continuous highlights while idling in that channel.

Please keep in mind that due to the nature of the Bittorrent protocol we are not able to hide your IP address within the swarm and changing these settings will not hide it; nor do thee setting actually protect your privacy (except from other members of TehConnection) so please do not think of this feature as a privacy measure.

fields.title: Port Forwarding
fields.body:
[size=4][b]Help! My ports are blocked![/b][/size]
You've probably arrived at this guide to help solve that problem. The goal is to fix your blocked ports and rid your torrent client of its "NAT Errors".

This page, for the most part, will assume that you're connected to the internet like this:
[pre]Cable/DSL modem -> Router -> Computer[/pre]
It is irrelevant whether or not your computer is connected wirelessly, or if your router and modem are one unit.

[size=4][b]But what's a NAT Error?[/b][/size]
A NAT Error means that other computers on the internet are unable to connect to yours. This is normal, because most routers block all incoming connections by default.

Your router has an [b]external[/b] IP address. You can see it at [url=https://www.whatismyip.org/][u]WhatIsMyIP[/u][/url] or [url=https://www.ipchicken.com/][u]IPChicken[/u][/url]. Your router assigns your computer an [b]internal[/b], or [b]local[/b], IP address. This internal IP address will be in one of the following formats:
[pre]192.168.X.X
172.16.X.X
10.X.X.X[/pre]
The idea is to set your router to take any incoming connections directed at it, and forward them to your internal IP address.

[size=4][b]How do I forward my port?[/b][/size]
PortForward.com hosts many [url=https://www.portforward.com/routers.htm][u]excellent guides[/u][/url]. Find your router on the list and follow the instructions.

[b]What ports do I forward?[/b]
Look for a "Listening port" or something similar in your torrent client's settings. You should not have it set from 6881-6889, because many ISPs throttle or block traffic on those ports. It is good to just choose a random port between 10000 and 65535.

[b]What IP address do I put in the port forwarding settings?[/b]
You put your [i]internal[/i] IP address into your router's port forwarding settings. Here is how you find your internal IP address:
In [b]Windows[/b], go to:
Start -> Run -> [b]cmd[/b] -> (Press Enter or click OK) -> [b]ipconfig[/b] -> (Press Enter); It will be listed as [b]IP Address[/b]

In [b]Mac OS X[/b], go to:
System Preferences -> Network -> (select the network connection with the Green dot) -> Configure

[b]Do I choose TCP or UDP?[/b]
You will be presented with the option to forward your port on TCP or UDP, or both. You definitely do want to forward TCP, because that's what all torrent traffic travels over. UDP is optional, and [u]does not affect torrents on private sites such as this one[/u]. UDP is used for your client's DHT service that allows you to find more peers on public torrents. Forward UDP as well if you use DHT and public torrents a lot.

[size=4][b]What's this about a static IP address?[/b][/size]
If your port forwarding guide mentioned that you should have a static IP address, then read this.
Your router automatically assigns your computer an internal IP address, like 192.168.1.101. But sometimes it will assign your computer a different IP address, such as 192.168.1.102. This often occurs because another computer connected to the router has already taken .101. This presents a problem because, for example, if you have your listening port forwarded to .101 and your IP address changes, it will no longer be forwarded correctly and you will receive a NAT Error. It is recommended that you follow [url=https://www.portforward.com/networking/staticip.htm][u]this guide[/u][/url] in order to assign your computer a static internal IP address. In Windows, if you find that only one DNS server is listed, then leave the Alternate DNS Server box empty or throw in an [url=https://www.opendns.com][u]OpenDNS[/u][/url] address like 208.67.222.222 as backup.

Contrary to what the guide says, though, you should set your static IP address to a relatively high number, so that other computers on your network never have a chance of being assigned that number automatically (causing a conflict). For example, if your IP addresses are currently ending with .101 or .102, you should set yours to .244 or something, in order to avoid any conflict (.255 max).
[b]A word of warning:[/b]
When you set your static IP address, you had to specify the DNS servers. In the future, your ISP may change these addresses. So if you ever have connectivity problems, change back to a non-static IP address and see if your DNS servers need to be changed to new addresses.
[b]Oh no it killed my internet[/b]
99% of the time, when your internet connection stops responding after setting a static IP address, it means that there is a typographical error somewhere. You incorrectly typed in the IP address, Subnet Mask, Default Gateway, or DNS Server(s).

[size=4][b]Port Test[/b][/size]
Make sure that a torrent is running, then use one of the following links to test whether your port is now open or not (replace 12345 with your listening port):
[url]https://www.utorrent.com/testport.php?port=12345[/url]
[url]https://www.grc.com/x/portprobe=12345[/url]
[url]https://www.canyouseeme.org/[/url]
[url]https://www.checkmyports.com/indexen.php?doscan=yes&port=12345[/url]

[size=4][b]My port isn't open. It said:[/b][/size]
[b]Stealth/Blocked, with timeout/Connection timed out/Error!/Locked[/b]
Are you sure that you clicked the Save Settings button after setting the port forwarding rules?
Are you sure that you forwarded the correct port to the correct internal IP address?
Does your modem also have a built-in firewall that must be configured?
Are you sure that you had a torrent running and listening on the port that you tested?
[b]Closed/Actively Blocked/Error!/Locked[/b]
Are you sure that you forwarded the correct port to the correct internal IP address?
Are you running any software firewalls (such as Norton Internet Security, ZoneAlarm, or Sygate) that could be blocking incoming connections? Note that the free version of ZoneAlarm does not allow you to open your ports under any circumstances.

fields.title: Port Forwarding with AirPort Extreme 802.11n (rectangular)
fields.body:
All the tutorial stuff I'm finding on portforward.com and blue skies.com involve mapping ports using the [i]AirPort Admin Utility[/i], which does not support the newest version that comes with this base station.

This is a pictorial guide to getting clever using the new [i]AirPort Utility[/i], assuming you already have the network set up and running (Named, Connected to your ISP, etc.) and are running at least Tiger (OSX 10.4).

[b]Open the AirPort Utility: Applications ->Utilities ->AirPort Utility[/b]
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/AirportUtility.png]

[size=3][b]1) Choose Manual Set Up:[/b][/size]
This button is in the lower left
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/ManualSetUp.png]

[size=3][b]2)Enable NAT:[/b][/size]
Far left tab within the Internet pane:
Check the box:Enable NAT Port Mapping Protocol
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/NATenabled.png]

[size=3][b]3)Map Ports:[/b][/size]
Second tab within the Advanced pane:
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/PortMaps.png]

[size=3][b]4)Choosing the [i]Add[/i] button gives a dialog box listing the services allowed for port mapping:[/b][/size]
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/PortMapService.png]

Choosing one of the services fills in an automatic entry into one or many of the port options. Personal Web Sharing is the service used for torrent clients.

[size=3][b]5) Personal Web Sharing[/b][/size]
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/PortMapSettings.png]
[b]Default settings are seen as:[/b]
Public TCP Port(s): 80
Private TCP Port(s):80
Private IP Address: Automatically fills in with the current IP address that is found in the System Prefs>Network Panel

If you have not already given your computer a Static IP, Go to [b]System Prefs[/b]> [b]Network[/b] pane and select your Airport
[*]Change the [b]TCP/IP[/b] settings to [b]Configure IPv4:[/b] Using DHCP with Manual Address
[*]Now assign your computer above the limit of DHCP IP's your station will dole out [color=green](< 10.0.1.200)[/color]
[*]Those limits are set in the Airport Utility, Internet Pane, DHCP tab if you want to double check that you are outside those limits

[size=3][b]6) Defining Ports[/b][/size]
[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/PersonalWebSharingPorts.png]
All the Port options must be filled in, and must be the same port
I entered the port [color=red](51655)[/color] that I have set within my Azureus client as both the Incoming TCP/UDP Listen Ports

There can be no more than one named service type (e.g. cannot be two Personal Web Sharing port services), and filling in ports where default values are not already given disables the continue button until all ports have been filled in.

Click [b]Continue[/b] in order to name these settings

[size=3][b]7) Naming your Port[/b][/size]
