[img=https://i239.photobucket.com/albums/ff117/servemethesky/PortMapName.png]
The above settings are then saved under whatever name you choose to save them as and can be edited in the same pane

Update your AirPort Utility settings to finalize your changes and you should be port forwarding in no time.

Tutorial made by suprprofundo

fields.title: Port Forwarding: Becky's Beginner Guide
fields.body:
Prenote: This is not the exact copy of the tutorial I had on OiNK. I just rewrote it. In any case, this is a *beginner's* tutorial, which means the technical jargon is kept to a minimum - it's meant for the newbies :)

[size=6]Beginner's Guide to Port Forwarding[/size]a

So you've just learned how BitTorrent works but then after all your hard research you download stuff, wait to upload, and what? Nothing's uploading? Chances are, if you are behind a router, you need to do some portfwarding. This is what happens when on the torrent pages, you are listed as â€œ[b]Not Connectable[/b]â€�
[b]
1.How Routers Work
2.Internal vs External IPs
3.Static vs Dynamic IPs
4.How Ports Work
5.Putting it All together
6.Now What?[/b]
[size=5]
How Routers Work[/size]

Before we can get into all that good junk, I think it's best to explain just how routers work.

Let's say you have multiple PCs under one roof...rather than have a modem for every single PC to connect to the internet, you have one modem, and one router. With the router every PC in the house can connect to the internet, using a wireless connection. 
[size=5]
Internal vs External IPs[/size]

The router has what's called an external IP address that â€œmarksâ€� who you are. You, me, and everyone that's connected to the internet has an external IP â€“ when you go to Google and do the â€œWhat's my IP?â€� thing â€“ that's your external.

However, only one IP address is assigned for one household (unless you pay for it assuming your ISP offers...unlikely), so what happens when 3 different PCs are under one router? Well, they all have the same external address, but each individual PC has an internal IP address.

[img=https://img182.imageshack.us/img182/5971/tut1pm1.png]

The internal IP address identifies each computer on the network. It's normally something like 192.xxx.x.xxx. For example, my internal IP address last time I checked was 192.168.1.160. Don't worry, nobody can see your internal address unless they're on the same network as you.
[size=5]
Static vs Dynamic IPs[/size]

Don't worry, we're getting to the good stuff soon. But you need to know this info in order to understand how port forwarding works. This is pretty easy though.

A [i]dynamic[/i] IP address will change, most of the time randomly. This could apply to external or internal IPs, but for port forwarding you have to pay attention to the internal IP address. When does it change? It depends. Sometimes it'll change every time you reconnect, sometimes if you get rebooted...it just depends on the router.
 
A [i]static[/i] IP address never changes; you set it to a specific IP and it stays there until the router is either set back to factory defaults or you change it. 
[size=5]
How Ports Work[/size]

When a packet is sent to a computer â€“ when information is sent to a computer that is â€“ it travels through an open port. Your PC does this all the time without you even knowing! Common ports are used daily, for things like the internet, instant messaging, etc.

For example, it might be that your instant message client uses port 5555, and your IP is 987.654.321. When you are sending a message, the data is sent from 987.654.321:5555. The : designates the port number to be used.

But the rest of the ports on your connection are closed, unless you open them. This is all leading up to our next section...
[size=5]
But what IS port forwarding? Why do I care? What does this have to do with my slow uploads!?[/size]

When you don't have a port open for your BitTorrent client, it makes connecting to people extremely difficult. [b]When your ports are not forwarded, you can send a request to connect to a peer, but you can't receive any.[/b]

What?

Ok, let's say Bob, Sally, and Joe are all on a torrent. Bob is the only one that is connectable (ports forwarded). Sally sends a request to connect to Bob, which he can accept and they're fine. Joe does the same. However, Joe then sends a request to connect to Sally, but guess what? They aren't going to connect. Why? Because Sally can't receive any incoming connections.

Now imagine if all three weren't connectable. [b]Nobody[/b] would connect! People would be sending requests left and right, but nothing.

So if you've noticed lately that you aren't connecting to any leechers (or seeders), and there are a LOT OF BOTH, then you need to do some port forwarding. Opening your ports will also greatly help your upload /download speed itself.
[size=5]
So how do I do that?[/size]

Well first you need to set up a static internal IP, what we were talking about earlier. Why is this? Because in order to forward your ports you have to assign a â€œruleâ€� in your router settings to keep that port open. You assign the rule based on the internal IP â€“ that way the router knows which PC it's talking about.

Have you seen the problem yet? If you have a dynamic static IP, every time your dynamic IP changes you have to go into your router settings and change it. Again. Sounds annoying, doesn't it? But if you make your IP static, all will be resolved :)

A link to making your IP static can be found here (yes, for Macs too and even xbox 360): https://www.portforward.com/networking/staticip.htm

Those directions are real easy, just follow them and you'll be good.

Once you've set up your static IP you need to pick a port to open up for your BT client. Assign this in your client settings, and then assign a rule in your router.

Don't panic! I know that was no help. Portfoward.com has literally a guide for almost any router you can think of. Just go to https://www.portforward.com/english/routers/port_forwarding/routerindex.htm , find your router, and then find your client in the list that pops up. 99% of the time those guides are very straight forward and simple.
[size=5]
Once that's done...[/size]

You're done! Restart your client and you should be good! If you're not sure if it's working, go look at the peer list on one of the torrents you might be seeding/leeching â€“ it will have â€œYesâ€� or â€œNoâ€� under connectable.
[b]
The Most Common Reasons for the Port Forwarding Not Working:

1.No static IP
2.Typo in the router settings
3.Typo in the client settings
4.Firewall not given permission[/b]

That's right, I almost forgot to mention! Your [b]firewall[/b] software, if you run it, is very similar to what a router does. In fact I don't even use a firewall because my router does just fine. But if you do use one, you have to go to your firewall settings and give your torrent client permission to receive and send data/connections. 

That's about it! If you have any questions feel free to PM me whenever, I'd be glad to help. Just please, be sure that you've actually read this first so you don't seem rather silly for asking me something that's clearly answered in the guide! Thanks for reading :)
[i]
Yours Truly,
Becky[/i]

---

Aha, I rewrote another one. I still have like four other tutorials that were lost thanks to the raid. Here is number two. Only one stick figure like drawing this time, damn. I'm losing touch. If I can find the time I'll work on the other ones I will.

Tutorial made by Becky

fields.title: Requests
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]How does the Request system work?[/b][/size][/color]

To create a request, you must be a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=81]donor[/url] or in the 'Member' [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=2]user class[/url] or higher.

First of all, when you create a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/requests.php?action=new]request[/url], it takes two hundred fifty ([b]250[/b]) MB of upload credit to create it. When you make your request, two hundred fifty ([b]250[/b]) MB is deducted from your upload statistics. Whenever anyone creates or votes on a request, 50% of it is removed as a 'tax' by the system, to discourage people from dumping too much credit and screwing up ratios.

After the request is made, the initial bounty is one hundred twenty-five ([b]125[/b]) MB. The other 125 - 50% of 250 MB - is taken out as a tax.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Custom Bounties[/b][/size][/color]

Members can vote on any request, which costs two hundred fifty ([b]250[/b]) MB. one hundred twenty-five ([b]125[/b]) MB of this is subtracted as the tax, and the other one hundred twenty-five ([b]125[/b]) MB is added to the request total bounty.

To vote on a request easily you can click the small plus symbol next to each request in the 'Votes column. The number in that column simply denotes the number of votes each request has received.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Custom Bounties[/b][/size][/color]

You also have the option of adding custom bounties in the request details page; click on the name of the film on the requests page.

Say I have 1274 MB of upload credit I'm willing to give to a particular request. I click on the plus symbol on the requests page and my ratio is deducted two hundred fifty ([b]250[/b]) MB. At this point, because of the tax, the request now has an added one hundred twenty-five ([b]125[/b]) MB of bounty attached to it. I go ahead and click on the request name and add the other 1024 MB to it via the 'Custom Bounty' box. 50% of it is removed as a tax, so 512MB of it is taken and the other 512MB is added as bounty. At this point I would have 1274 MB deducted from my upload credit and the request would have an added bounty of 637 MB of bounty added to its total.

Next to the 'Custom Bounty' box are two radio buttons denoting whether the request amount should be measured in MB or GB. Be careful with these as accidentally contributing 250 GB can be much more painful than accidentally contributing 250 MB.

When the request is filled, everyone that has contributed ratio to the bounty is notified, whether the original requester or a voter.

When someone fills a request you've made or voted on, no more credit is removed from your stats. The only time that happens is when you make or vote on a request.

[b]NOTE:[/b] at no point is your download amount affected, only your upload stats, ever. Also, if you delete your request, you will not get the bounty back.

It is not possible to remove a vote you have placed on another users request. There is a strict no refunds policy on requests.

fields.title: rtorrent on OSX: Installation and Configuration
fields.body:
This is a basic guide to getting rtorrent up and running for OSX users. If you're looking for a client that's feature rich (i.e. not Transmission), but doesn't hog resources (i.e. not Azureus) I highly recommend rtorrent. It's a fairly easy install, but it differs depending on if you are running 10.5 or Tiger or lower.

[size=4]Fink[/size]

The first step is to install Fink (macports is also able to install rtorrent, however, this will not be covered in this tutorial). 

If you are running Tiger (10.4) or lower, you can jump down to the section for 10.4 users. 

[size=3]10.5 Users[/size]

If you are running Leopard (10.5) then you must compile Fink from source. 
Download the latest source code from https://www.finkproject.org/download/srcdist.php
The next part is covered by the INSTALL file in the tarball, so to be brief, open a terminal window and do as follows:
cd (wherever the tarball was downloaded to)
tar xvf fink-0.27.8.tar.gz
cd fink-0.27.8
./bootstrap

This will then take you through the install. It will ask you where to install fink, the default is to use /sw for the installation, and this tutorial will assume that Fink was installed to /sw. It will ask you what mirrors to use, the defaults are usually fine, or you can select whatever you want. The only important question it will ask is whether or not to enable the unstable tree.  For this select yes and continue with the installation.

Once the script has finished installing there is just one more step.
Assuming you have installed Fink to /sw, run: '/sw/bin/pathsetup.sh'
This will set your path correctly. Now skip to the Installation section.

[size=3]10.4 Users[/size]

Tiger and below users can install Fink from the binary available on the Fink website.
Download the appropriate binary from: https://www.finkproject.org/download/index.en.php
Mount the .dmg file and install using the package installer.
After the installer finishes, you're done, with the exception of enabling the unstable tree. The Fink FAQ has a good section on this, but it's pretty simple:
run 'fink configure' in a terminal shell and when it asks about the unstable tree says yes to enable it.
Next run 'fink selfupdate' and 'fink scanpackages'
Now you're done!


[size=4]Installation[/size]

Now that Fink is set up, installing rtorrent should be quite simple.
'fink install rtorrent' in a terminal shell
Let Fink download and compile the necessary files, if you get errors, the output should tell you what you need, (for me it was the right gettext pacakge), run 'fink selfupdate' and try again (it may take a few tries).

Assuming everything went fine you've now got rtorrent on OSX!


[size=4]Configuration[/size]

You'll need a configuration file to set things up.
The rtorrent homepage has a good example of a .rtorrent.rc file. https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/browser/trunk/rtorrent/doc/rtorrent.rc?rev=latest
Save that file in your home directory (~/.rtorrent.rc) and uncomment the options you want.

You probably want to make a session directory too (I put mine at ~/.rtorrent)

You are now done! Go to a terminal and type 'rtorrent' and add your torrents etc...

Good Luck!


If I left anything out, please post about it, this is my first tutorial, but I know there are a lot of people running OSX who are unhappy with their clients, so I thought I would write this up.

Tutorial made by kardia

fields.title: rTorrent: Installing On Linux
fields.body:
[b]** updated 10/30/2007 with links to newest versions **[/b]

Since rtorrent is now the recommended Linux client on many trackers, it's time for a tutorial to help those not so familiar with installing stuff on Linux. This will cover everything you need to get rtorrent up and running.

You might be able to get everything you need from your distro's official repositories, but there are too many distros for me to cover how to do that, and most of the time they contain extremely outdated versions. So I'll show you how to compile and install the newest versions.

For this tutorial, I will assume that you already have new enough versions of the standard software/libraries needed to compile and install programs on Linux, such as GCC/G++, pkg-config, OpenSSL, automake, etc. Sorry, I will not cover how to upgrade/install these, but your distro's official repositories should have all of these (even if they are not the latest versions, they should still work).


[b][color=blue]Before you start, make sure you are logged in or SU'd to root. If you don't know what this is then learn more about Linux before continuing.[/color][/b]

[b]Prerequisites[/b]
First of all, install the prerequisites for rtorrent. At the time of this writing, they are:

    * libsigc++ >= 2.0.x
    * libcurl >= 7.12.x 

1) Head over to the libsigc++ official website ([url]https://libsigc.sourceforge.net/stable.shtml[/url]) and download the sources.
[quote]root@beast:~# wget https://ftp.gnome.org/pub/GNOME/sources/libsigc++/2.0/libsigc++-2.0.18.tar.gz[/quote]

2) Extract the files
[quote]root@beast:~# tar zxf libsigc++-2.0.18.tar.gz[/quote]

3) Compile and install libsigc++
[quote]root@beast:~# cd libsigc++-2.0.18
root@beast:~/libsigc++-2.0.18# ./configure
root@beast:~/libsigc++-2.0.18# make
root@beast:~/libsigc++-2.0.18# make install
root@beast:~/libsigc++-2.0.18# cd ..[/quote]

4) Now you need to install libcurl. Compiling it with c-ares support is recommended so rtorrent doesn't hang on hostname lookups. So first go to the c-ares page ([url]https://daniel.haxx.se/projects/c-ares/[/url]), dl, extract, compile and install.
[quote]root@beast:~# wget https://daniel.haxx.se/projects/c-ares/c-ares-1.4.0.tar.gz
root@beast:~# tar zxf c-ares-1.4.0.tar.gz
root@beast:~# cd c-ares-1.4.0
root@beast:~/c-ares-1.4.0# ./configure
root@beast:~/c-ares-1.4.0# make
root@beast:~/c-ares-1.4.0# make install
root@beast:~/c-ares-1.4.0# cd ..[/quote]

5) Now go to the curl page ([url]https://curl.haxx.se[/url]) and do the same, but make sure you configure it with c-ares support.
[quote]root@beast:~# wget https://curl.haxx.se/download/curl-7.17.1.tar.gz
root@beast:~# tar zxf curl-7.17.1.tar.gz
root@beast:~# cd curl-7.17.1
root@beast:~/curl-7.17.1# ./configure --enable-ares
root@beast:~/curl-7.17.1# make
root@beast:~/curl-7.17.1# make install
root@beast:~/curl-7.17.1# cd ..[/quote]


[b]libtorrent and rtorrent[/b]
libtorrent and rtorrent go hand in hand. Each one has to be installed with the other, and libtorrent must be installed before rtorrent. You must install both each time you decide to upgrade rtorrent.

1) Go to the official site ([url]https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no[/url]) and dl both stable source archives.
[quote]root@beast:~# wget https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/downloads/libtorrent-0.11.8.tar.gz
root@beast:~# wget https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/downloads/rtorrent-0.7.8.tar.gz
[/quote]

2) Install libtorrent
[quote]
root@beast:~# tar zxf libtorrent-0.11.8.tar.gz
root@beast:~# cd libtorrent-0.11.8
root@beast:~/libtorrent-0.11.8# ./configure
root@beast:~/libtorrent-0.11.8# make
root@beast:~/libtorrent-0.11.8# make install
root@beast:~/libtorrent-0.11.8# cd ..
[/quote]

3) Install rtorrent
[quote]
root@beast:~# tar zxf rtorrent-0.7.8.tar.gz
root@beast:~# cd rtorrent-0.7.8
root@beast:~/rtorrent-0.7.8# ./configure
root@beast:~/rtorrent-0.7.8# make
root@beast:~/rtorrent-0.7.8# make install
root@beast:~/rtorrent-0.7.8# cd ..
[/quote]

[b][color=blue]Installation is complete now. Exit out of root.[/color][/b]


[b]Configuring rtorrent[/b]
The rtorrent settings file is .rtorrent.rc in your home dir. rtorrent is highly customizable and there are many options. To get a list of all of them read the man page (man rtorrent) and check out the documentation on the web site. Just create a new file called .rtorrent.rc in your home dir and put your settings in there. Here are a few settings you absolutely must have for optimal performance:

[quote]
session = ~/.rtorrent
port_range = 31600-31610
encryption = allow_incoming,enable_retry,try_outgoing
[/quote]
quick synopsis of these settings:

session = ~/.rtorrent - this will store torrents and torrent data in ~/.rtorrent so in case rtorrent crashes or you need to restart it, your stats will be kept. You can change this to whatever dir you want. just make sure that the directory exists.

port_range = 31600-31610 - the port range that rtorrent will listen on. rtorrent by default listens in 6881-6889 which is blocked by most ISPs, so this is absolutely necessary.

encryption = allow_incoming,enable_retry,try_outgoing - optimal encryption settings which will try to establish an encrypted connection and if it's not possible, fail over to unencrypted/legacy.


That's all there is to it! I suggest printing out the key bindings section of the man page for easy reference. at first it looks arcane and confusing, but after a few days of using rtorrent exclusively, all the keystrokes will become second nature!

Tutorial made by Vazhin

fields.title: Throttling/Sandvining/Seeding Problems: Workaround using WIPFW
fields.body:
It would be sweet if we could get most of the Comcast users on this site to implement this workaround, so that people like me who only have the option of Comcast for their provider have a better chance at uploading and contributing to this great site. Here is a fairly simple tutorial for setting it up in Windows. There was a much better tutorial on Oink's forums, if for some slim chance someone happens to have it, you should post it here.

[quote]Step 1
Download WIPFW from https://wipfw.sourceforge.net/

Step 2
Extract the downloaded zip to C:\Program Files\WIPFW

Step 3
In the WIPFW directory, run install-deny.cmd

Warning: All Remote Desktop, VNC, Windows File Sharing, and other server apps WILL be cut off at this point. Don't worry, you can re-enable them later.

Step 4: Windows XP Only
Start -> Control Panel -> Security Center

Click on Manage Security Settings for: Windows Firewall

Select Off and click OK

Back in the Security Center, under the red heading for Firewall, select Recommendations...

Check I have a firewall solution that I'll monitor myself and click OK

Step 5
Save the following in the file C:\windows\System32\drivers\etc\protocol (no extension, replace windows with WINNT if you are using Windows 2000) 
[quote]# Copyright (c) 1993-1999 Microsoft Corp.
#
# This file contains the Internet protocols as defined by RFC 1700
# (Assigned Numbers).
#
# Format:
#
# <protocol name> <assigned number> [aliases...] [#<comment>]

ip 0 IP # Internet protocol
icmp 1 ICMP # Internet control message protocol
ggp 3 GGP # Gateway-gateway protocol
tcp 6 TCP # Transmission control protocol
egp 8 EGP # Exterior gateway protocol
pup 12 PUP # PARC universal packet protocol
udp 17 UDP # User datagram protocol
hmp 20 HMP # Host monitoring protocol
xns-idp 22 XNS-IDP # Xerox NS IDP
rdp 27 RDP # "reliable datagram" protocol
rvd 66 RVD # MIT remote virtual disk[/quote] 

Step 6
Open C:\Program Files\WIPFW\wipfw.conf in notepad.

Replace the contents with the following and change 6883 to your bittorrent port:
[quote]# First flush the firewall rules
-f flush

# Allow all internal (loopback) network communications.
add 100 allow all from any to any via lo*

# Prevent any traffic to 127.0.0.1, common in localhost spoofing
add 110 deny log all from any to 127.0.0.0/8 in
add 110 deny log all from 127.0.0.0/8 to any in

# Drop incoming packets with RST flag on BitTorrent port
# This is what thwarts Sandvine.
add drop tcp from any to me 6883 tcpflags rst

# Setup stateful filtering
add check-state
add pass all from me to any out keep-state
add count log ip from any to any

# Allow new incoming BitTorrent connections
add allow tcp from any to me 6883
add allow udp from any to me 6883[/quote]

Step 7
Season to taste with any of the following rules (append to the end of wipfw.conf)

File and Print Sharing 
[quote]# Allow Microsoft SMB file sharing
add pass tcp from any to me 135-139
add pass udp from any to me 135-139

# Allow direct-hosted SMB w/out NetBIOS
add pass tcp from any to me 445
add pass udp from any to me 445[/quote]

VNC 
[quote]# Allow VNC
add pass tcp from any to me 5900[/quote]

Remote Desktop 
[quote]# Allow RDP/Terminal Services
add pass tcp from any to me 3389[/quote]

More filters coming soon...

Step 8
Start -> Run

type cmd and press enter

Run the following two commands:
net stop ipfw

net start ipfw

Step 9
Configure your torrent client to use an outgoing port range. 

uTorrent 

The settings are hidden under the advanced options pane. First, set "net.outgoing_port" to the lower end of the port range (e.g 55259) on which you are blocking RST packets. Then set "net.outgoing_max_port" (uTorrent 1.7 and above only) to the upper end of the port range (e.g. 55395).[/quote]

If anyone has questions or problems, post here and I'll try to help out as best I can.

Tutorial made by dangerpoon

fields.title: Throttling: Workarounds for Bandwith Limitation
fields.body:
So, you're encountering issues with slow upstream speeds and it seems like the uploads level off at 0, right?  Maybe you're using Comcast or another similar ISP that is employing bandwidth shaping or using "Sandvine."  Damn your ISP!  But you aren't without options!  Here are the different methods which people use in an effort to combat these terrible nuisances... and if none of them work, feel free to switch to a different provider in protest or find a workaround that nobody else has thought of.

[color=#0000FF][size=4][b]1. VPN - Virtual Private Network[/b][/size][/color]
This will more than likely cost you some extra money a month.  You have a few options:
Relakks: https://www.relakks.com/?cid=gb
Witopia: https://www.witopia.net/personalmore.html
VPNTunnel: https://www.vpntunnel.co.uk/
Metropipe: https://www.metropipe.net
Hotspot Shield - Free but AD supported: https://www.anchorfree.com/downloads/hotspot-shield/

There are more and a simple google search can help you with this one.  Here are guides for setting up a VPN for each OS:
WINDOWS VISTA:
https://www.publicvpn.com/support/Vista.php
(ignore the stuff that's included in and after the 'Select the Connection Properties' section)
WINDOWS XP:
https://www.windowsecurity.com/articles/Configure-VPN-Connection-Windows-XP.html
LINUX:
https://www.linuxhelp.net/guides/vpn/
(not sure if this is the right guide)
MAC OS:
https://www.external.ameslab.gov/is/remote-vpn-osx.html
Replace the connection info with whatever VPN you choose for any of these tutorials and it should work.

[color=#006633][b]The upside[/color][/b]: This usually works for most people.  It's even better if you have multiple computers and just use one to seed.  If you seed with just that one computer, connect to a VPN with that computer.  This should give you a constant stream upwards and you'll get your ratio up in no time.  But don't go into this thinking it'll uncap your upstream... you can only go the max that your provider gives you up... and sometimes the VPN might limit it a bit lower, depending on the VPN you choose.
[color=#FF0000][b]The downside[/color][/b]: If you only use one computer then most VPN's tend to have sketchy service.  The downstream might be intermittent on a VPN.  Sometimes it might be hard to connect to them.  That and most of these places you have to pay 5 bucks a month or more.  I have the luxury of having a seeding computer connected to a VPN and a laptop that I just use without a VPN.

[color=#0000FF][size=4][b]2. Force encryption[/b][/color][/size]
https://www.scribd.com/doc/273456/Optimize-BitTorrent-to-outwit-traffic-shaping-ISPs

[color=#006633][b]The upside[/b][/color]: It's a free option.  It's a quick fix, if it works out for you.
[color=#FF0000][b]The downside[/b][/color]: A lot of people say it doesn't really work.  But some people swear by it... so give it a shot if you have nothing else to lose.

[color=#0000FF][size=4][b]3. Seedboxes[/b][/color][/size]
The most expensive option of the bunch, but a guaranteed success.  Here are some host names:
Vectoral, LeaseWeb, Netdirekt, Tzulo, Exportal, OLM.net -- There are more and this is a subject you'll have to research...  Basically you are renting out a remote machine that'll do the seeding for you.  You'll have massive upstream and downstream capabilities, making it easier to get a good ratio.  It's a great option if you have the cash to spend.  Here's a good launching pad on getting to know what a seedbox is: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seedbox 

[color=#006633][b]The upside[/b][/color]: Insane upstream means you'll get a great ratio (most places offer a great upstream package, just choose wisely.)  It also means that no matter what your provider does to you... it won't affect your seedbox!  Not to mention being able to store your files on a remote computer... that has great advantages.
[color=#FF0000][b]The downside[/b][/color]: Cost... These things can be as "cheap" as 50 bucks a month (if you're lucky...) but generally range around $85-$90 (US) a month... or more.  AND... Most seedbox providers have it in their TOS that they don't want you using it for illegal files.  They can shut off your service whenever they please.

[COLOR=#0000FF][size=4][b]4. SSH Tunneling[/b][/color][/size]
I list this one last because, well... I just plain don't like it.  It can cripple the servers of the SSH providers, and make those providers unreliable or force them to take measures as well.  If you REALLY want to do this option, and it will cost you at least a buck, then you can read the info over at torrent freak.  Here's the link:
https://torrentfreak.com/bittorrent-over-ssh-071014/  --  No upside and downside to this section, as I basically said it all.

[COLOR=#0000FF][size=4][b]5. WIPFW[/b][/color][/size]
This option isn't really all that great because it requires all users to have performed this function before it'll be any good.  Which is highly unlikely to occur... but perhaps it can help you anyway...  Go here https://wakarimasu.googlepages.com/home and follow the instructions provided within and it just may help you combat things like sandvine on the comcast network, but I can't speak for the other ways different ISP's throttle your bandwidth.
[color=#006633][b]The upside[/b][/color]: It's free.  It could completely combat sandvine on comcast
[color=#FF0000][b]The downside[/b][/color]: It really only works for "Sandvine" type throttling.  Sandvine throttling sends a drop signal to both the receiver and sender so if both don't have this workaround installed, this won't work.  In a perfect world everyone would unite together, but we all know that isn't happening.  Also, this method isn't fully tested yet so it's too early to tell its effectiveness.

======================

Hope this information is of use to someone, let me know your results or other workarounds you've discovered so I can add it here.  --zombieslayer (aka remisser on other sites)

Tutorial made by remisser

Note from [url=https://what.cd/user.php?id=42]?[/url] (Administrator): Be careful when using VPN's and clear it with someone at every tracker you use it on. The free ones can cause you issues.

fields.title: Transmission: Creating torrents and seeding on Mac
fields.body:
Transmission is a fairly simple torrent client to create torrents with, short and quick steps. So first when you open up Transmission, you want to go to File>Create Torrent File...
[img]https://img29.picoodle.com/img/img29/4/2/11/f_Picture1m_dca6e70.jpg[/img]

Then a window will appear asking you which file you want to make a torrent out of. Navigate to the file or folder of your choice, and click Select.
[img]https://img03.picoodle.com/img/img03/4/2/11/f_Picture2m_12c6ff0.jpg[/img]

The next window will ask you to input the tracker of your choice, any comments if you wish, where the file torrent file should be created, and if the torrent you want to make should be private or not. For this tutorial, I am going to be using the What.cd tracker. What.cd includes your passkey in the tracker, so there is no need to redownload the torrent from What when you create the torrent. Your tracker URL with your unique passkey can be found on the upload page. So copy and paste that into the Tracker box. Now in this tutorial, I will be uploading to What.cd which IS a private torrent tracker, so I will need to have the Private Tracker box checked. Also, in Transmission, there is no way to change the piece size, so we will have to leave it at the default setting. For the "Open when created" box, you can have this checked because your passkey is included in the tracker URL. After you have all of this put in, click Create.
[img]https://img30.picoodle.com/img/img30/4/2/11/f_Picture3m_947e9e8.jpg[/img]

Transmission will then proceed to create the torrent file.
[img]https://img34.picoodle.com/img/img34/4/2/11/f_Picture4m_a2cd2e6.jpg[/img]

And the torrent will appear in the Transmission window when finished if you selected "Open when created."
[img]https://img37.picoodle.com/img/img37/4/2/11/f_Picture5m_c911c7d.jpg[/img]

All that is left now is to upload the torrent, and start seeding. Your newly created torrent should show up in the Transmission window.

Go to the Upload page on What.cd, and put in all the required information about the torrent. Click Choose file, and locate the torrent file you just made with Transmission, then click Choose. Once you have all the required information in the Upload page, click Do it! at the bottom of the page, and the next window will appear saying that you have successfully uploaded your torrent.
[img]https://img34.picoodle.com/img/img34/4/2/11/f_Picture6m_a28cc7c.jpg[/img]
[img]https://img03.picoodle.com/img/img03/4/2/11/f_Picture7m_0005d00.jpg[/img]

Now go back to Transmission and click the little spiral arrow button next to the torrent. Transmission will then check the existing data, and start to seed.
[img]https://img26.picoodle.com/img/img26/4/2/11/f_Picture8m_fa81fe4.jpg[/img]

If you get an error, such as Transmission telling you the torrent is not complete and you cannot start seeding, recheck the files by highlighting the torrent in the Transmission window, and going to Transfers>Verify Local Data, and Transmission will recheck the file or folder for that torrent to make sure it is 100% complete so you can start seeding.

This concludes creating, and seeding a torrent with Transmission on Mac OS X. :)



[color=red][b]Common problems[/b][/color]

[b]When I upload a torrent, and redownload it to seed, the progress stays at 0% and tries to download instead of seed.[/b]
Make sure your download location is set to where the files are located. So for example if you have MP3 files located in "X:/Torrents/My Torrent/" go to Transmission>Preferences>Transfers, and set the "Download to:" location to "X:/Torrents/." Or you can set it to "Same as torrent file" if your torrent will be in the same location as the .torrent file (Ex: If your .torrent file is on the Desktop, your folder of MP3s or whatever you are trying to seed must be on the desktop), or set it to "Always ask me" if you want to choose the location for yourself every time you import a torrent.

Tutorial made by Symmetry1618

[color=red] [b]Issue with ripping on a mac and creating a torrent using the files from a (virtual or real) windows OS client (such as utorrent) to seed along with the mac version[/b][/color]

When you rip a CD in OSX, you will create resource forks (.filenames) that are invisible files. Most programs that are native to OSX will [b]NOT[/b] pick up these files and wrap them into the torrent that you create. However, if you use utorrent for windows or a virtual machine installation of windows (VMWARE for example) and have utorrent or any other torrent client find the files you ripped on the mac side, they [b]WILL[/b] suck them into the torrent creation and your torrent will have a lot of .filenames like so:

[quote][pre]
XXXXXXXX@XXXXXXX-desktop:/media/Ishmael/MusicLibrary/Yeah No/Swell Henry$ ls -la
total 54652
drwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-30 20:21 .
drwxrwxrwx 1 root root       0 2008-12-30 20:21 ..
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._01 She Has Four Thorns.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 7315990 2008-06-13 17:51 01 She Has Four Thorns.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._02 Last Beginning.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 6714129 2008-06-13 17:51 02 Last Beginning.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._03 Born In The Air.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 7334798 2008-06-13 17:51 03 Born In The Air.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._04 Camper Giorno.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 7765505 2008-06-13 17:51 04 Camper Giorno.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._05 Cloud Stopper.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 5364957 2008-06-13 17:51 05 Cloud Stopper.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._06 Flanked.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 2639654 2008-06-13 17:51 06 Flanked.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._07 He Has A Pair Of Dice.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 5416366 2008-06-13 17:51 07 He Has A Pair Of Dice.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._08 Dead Water.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 5853969 2008-06-13 17:51 08 Dead Water.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._09 Staircase Genius.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 4560594 2008-06-13 17:51 09 Staircase Genius.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4096 2008-12-27 04:57 ._10 Kip Files.mp3
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 2932435 2008-06-13 17:51 10 Kip Files.mp3
[/pre][/quote]

To avoid this, either create the torrent IN OSX (like above) and copy the torrent to windows, OR in your folder options on the windows side select "see hidden files" and delete the .filenames out of the directory before you create the torrent.

This will prevent messy torrents from being uploaded and you can use the torrent on both your windows and mac clients.

fields.title: Transmission: How to Create Groups in Transmission
fields.body:
Grouping your torrents is an excellent way of keeping things organized. In this tutorial, I will be teaching you how simple it is to get this going. First get a general idea of how you want to group. Some ideas to get you started is grouping by tracker or by different tags such as movies, applications, music etc. 


[b]1.[/b] Open transmission


[b]2.[/b]

[img=https://img201.imageshack.us/img201/5646/picture1jp0.png]


[b]3.[/b]

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-d24m8u1edhgib4gianimgc4xfu.png]


[b]4.[/b]  Type in your preferred group name. 

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-gea6icd3y25ap5esawgntiycha.png]


[b]5.[/b] [i](Optional)[/i] Color coding your groups is great for finding things visually which is usually quicker but depends on the person.

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-effyt84a4p4u3h2egx3kq2rs6e.png]


[b]6.[/b] If "Queue Order" is selected then you will notice that "Use Groups" is grayed out. In order to avoid this problem, select any of the options in the red box

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080804-j61iepix9jcaenxrs1njdp5sgj.jpg]


[b]7.[/b]  Now you can select "Use Groups"

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-ew2gaf4cnggk4t87xybrs9s2ex.png]



[b]8.[/b]  You will notice that there aren't any groups yet... Right click on a torrent and do this (repeat if necessary:

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080804-1ucf8auc51h5uwamcub6uc17wc.jpg]

[b]9.[/b][i](Leopard only)[/i]Now you will probably want to hide all the torrents into one group that you assigned it to. Simply click on the triangle to collapse the group:

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-gwxunujw19wn7pf8spyge398ik.png]

[b]10.[/b]And congrats! You have successfully created your own group/s 


[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-1rp5cu46122cxn965s6sj7mp3y.png]

[b]Bonus Tip[/b]
Want your group to display your bandwidth or ratio? Easy! 

[b]1.[/b]Roll your mouse over the ratio or bandwidth text and click on it

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-gs5jtp55qwhhu97ewaagjtpfkf.png]


[b]2.[/b] And BOOM! You should get this or vise versa:

[img=https://img.skitch.com/20080806-bi59uh8f15pek1hwmttbeby6mq.png]




thanks to macguy, who made this tutorial. i loved it and wanted it to be here..

fields.title: Uploading: Etiquette Guide
fields.body:
Note: This guide [b]does not[/b] deal with creating torrents.


Now, on to the tutorial...

"What is this Uploading Etiquette thing?", I hear you ask. Well, put simply, it is the torrenting equivalent of karma. Do good by uploading well-formatted and tagged torrents, and good shall come on to you (no, not that way. Get your mind out of the gutter).

[IMG]https://i27.photobucket.com/albums/c176/jezuschryzt/confused.jpg[/IMG]

"Huh? Tell me more about Uploading Etiquette, Ryz!"

Ok. As any good businessman will tell you, getting ahead in this world is all about shifting the paradigm and providing good customer service. The torrenting world is no different. It may surprise you, but people actually don't like to mess around with badly tagged and formatted files after they've downloaded them, and that's fair enough! They've put plenty of effort into gaining access to a highly-organised music pirating network, and they deserve some "me time".

[IMG]https://i27.photobucket.com/albums/c176/jezuschryzt/depressed.jpg[/IMG]

"So what you're saying is that my files may be causing others unwanted grief?"

That's right. However, by utilising some simple Workflow Synergy Knowledge Acquisition techniques, you could be everyone's favourite uploader in no time!

[IMG]https://i27.photobucket.com/albums/c176/jezuschryzt/cautious.jpg[/IMG]

"I'm listening..."

First off, start by renaming all your files to a uniform format. The generally accepted format is "Track # - Title" or "Track # - Artist - Title" for compilations. If you're a masochist, you can rename every single one of your files manually. Otherwise, use a batch tagging/renaming program such as the appropriately named [b]Tag & Rename[/b] or its free (although less powerful) equivalent [b]Mp3Tag[/b]. These programs may also be used to retag files by imputting values manually or downloading them from an online database. Avoid using umbrella genre tags such as "Alternative and Punk". Alternative is an adjective, not a genre, just like High Yield Investment Programs are legitimate financial options, not pyramid schemes.

If your files are formatted and tagged well, people can download them straight into their library (instead of making duplicate copies to seed), and will thus be able to keep seeding for a longer period of time.

[IMG]https://i27.photobucket.com/albums/c176/jezuschryzt/appreciation.jpg[/IMG]

"I see. So by putting a little extra effort into formatting my files I can increase downloads by 200% per annum without a large capital outlay?"

Correct. You can also enhance the potential downloader's experience by putting extra information on the torrent page. While I do automatically download any Insane Clown Posse album that's posted, I prefer to know a little bit about other albums before taking the proverbial plunge. A review (easily found at sites such as [b]allmusic.com[/b] or [b]music.amazon.com[/b]) or even just a few sentences that describe the album's sound do go a long way towards informing the other users' choice of whether or not to download an album. You wouldn't go to a coke party blindfolded, so why would you download an album if the only thing you know is the tracklisting?

Speaking of which, instead of posting a plain tracklisting, why not create an nfo file that also includes useful information such as bitrate, encoder, audio source, track times and sizes, and the album length. Free programs such as [b]Kleinvaag's PostAssistant[/b] and [b]NFO Sighting[/b] make it a breeze!

[IMG]https://i27.photobucket.com/albums/c176/jezuschryzt/ecstatic.jpg[/IMG]

"Wow, Ryz! Armed with that sort of info there's no telling what lofty heights I can scale! Thanks!"

No problem, buddy.

Tutorial made by Ryz

fields.title: Uploading: the same files to different private trackers
fields.body:
First of all let me say that I didn't write this guide. Thewimp from waffles.fm did(building on some posts from tich). So be sure to send thanks their way. All I did was cut and paste it because I thought it would be helpful here too. I asked thewimp first if your curious and he said sure (so much for this waffles/what animosity). Long live the hydra. 

Note: This guide is for uploading files to two trackers. If you would like to seed the same files on two trackers even though they have the same hash(when you add them you get a "this torrent is already in your client message) There are two solutions. One is to run two seperate clients, or two instances of one client. The other is to see this helpful guide:

[quote=thewimp]HOW TO UPLOAD THE SAME FILES TO 2 PRIVATE TRACKERS.

step by step guide using [b]uTorrent 1.6[/b]
by: thewimp
thanks to: Tich

introduction:
This tutorial will explain how to upload an album to two different private trackers.
I have seen some people doing things like adding 2 trackers to the same torrent job, this is a bad thing and 
will be flagged as cheating. So I decided to write this tutorial to help people do it the right way. Tich was the first to talk about that on the other thread, so the kudos go to him. :)
The tutorial was made using uTorrent 1.6, but may work with any version.

CREATING THE FIRST TORRENT

first you will need some album to upload. I'll use an imaginary one, let's call it "waffos - best hits"

[IMG]https://imageupload.se/files/071113/8008img1.PNG[/IMG]

now you have to upload it to the tracker, but first you'll need to create the torrent:
open uTorrent, click on 'create new torrent'.
a window will pop, now follow the instructions:

[IMG]https://imageupload.se/files/071113/6142img2.PNG[/IMG]

1 - click on 'add directory' and point to the folder you want to upload.
2 - paste the tracker url from waffles upload page/use your url with the passkey.
3 - since this is the first torrent you will create, it's recommended to leave this option on auto detect.
4 - UNTICK start seeding, [b]TICK private torrent.[/b]
5 - click on 'create and save as...' button, the progress bar below it will fill up, and you'll be asked where you want to save the .torrent. 

click on 'close' button.

now you can see a new job added to uTorrent, you may want to label it, or just leave it on No Label category.
click on the torrent job, you'll notice some tabs below it, click on the general tab, now you have to check the 'piece size' used by uTorrent .

this is needed because:
1 - the piece size was set to auto during torrent creation so you need to know what size was used.
2 - you will have to select a different piece size for the second torrent

pic:

[IMG]https://imageupload.se/files/071113/700img3.PNG[/IMG]

now go to the upload page on waffles and select the .torrent you have created, upload it and start seeding.

ADDITIONAL STEPS: if you have used the standard tracker url (i.e. without passkey), you may have to download the .torrent file on the upload page in order to proper seed it. To do this, just download it from the page, open uTorrent, select the new torrent job you have created, CLICK ON REMOVE BUTTON (otherwise uTorrent will try to add new tracker to existing job), add the new .torrent you downloaded and point it to your album folder (in this case: G:\waffos - best hits).

now you're done with the first torrent, let's create the second torrent to upload to what.cd tracker.

CREATING SECOND TORRENT

click on create a new torrent, the same window will popup.

[IMG]https://imageupload.se/files/071113/9259img4.PNG[/IMG]

As you can see on the pic above, the folder will be the same as the first (YOU DON'T NEED TO MODIFY THE FILES INSIDE THE FOLDER).
Now you have to use the what.cd tracker, get it from your what.cd upload page.
IMPORTANT STEP: this is the where you do the trick, you'll have to select a different piece size for the new torrent. In this example, the first torrent have a piece size of 512 kB, so I'll select a close number, like 256 or 1024 kB.
Untick start seeding, TICK private torrent.
Click on 'create and save as...' and save the new .torrent on a different location, or with a different name (otherwise uTorrent will ask to overwrite the first one). remember to keep your .torrent stored because you may need them on the future.
uTorrent will add a new job and now you can see 2 exactly identical torrents on the job list, but one is for waffles and the other is for what. I strongly suggest that you create labels for better management of your upload jobs.
upload the new torrent to what.cd and start seeding.

that's it, you now have 2 identical torrents on two different private trackers. :w00t:

please suggest corrections or additions to the tutorial.
cheers. :)[/quote]




UPDATE:
I'm going to add some things that have been discussed in the comments:
1) If for whatever reason you have managed to get two seperate torrents listed in your torrent client(seperate hashes), and you are 100% sure that each torrent is only announcing to one tracker then you are fine. I don't know how you managed to do it, but congratz. The vast majority of users cannot get separate torrents without changing the hash size.

Tutorial made by SilentFury

fields.title: uTorrent: Create and Upload a Torrent
fields.body:
[color=green][size=5]This is a tutorial for how to create a torrent with utorrent and upload it to What.cd[/size][/color]


1. [b]Open Utorrent[/b]

2. [b]Press "Ctrl N" or click the magic wand icon or select "File>Create New Torrent..."[/b]

[img=https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/magicwand.jpg]

3.[b] Within the box that pops up, add the file or directory you'd like to upload using the respective button[/b] (directory just means a folder as opposed to a single file, so that will be the route for the majority of music torrents)

[img=https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/uploadguideselectdirectory.jpg]

4. [b]In the "Trackers" box enter(copy/paste) your personal What.cd tracker announce url[/b] (your personal passkey can be found here: https://tehconnection.eu/upload.php ) pictured here:

[IMG]https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/passkey.jpg[/IMG]

5. [b]Set the "Piece Size" to auto-detect (this is the default)[/b]

6. [b] Tick both the "Start Seeding" and "Private Torrent" boxes [/b]

should look like this [if you were trying to upload Green Nuns of the Revolution - Rock Bitch Mafia :) ]:

[img=https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/createnewtorrent.jpg]

7. [b] Click "Create and Save As" to create the torrent, and save it to wherever you'd like upon its completion [/b] (It's easiest to dedicate a Folder just for torrents - they're incredibly small 20 kb files - for organizational purposes)

8. [b]Go to https://tehconnection.eu/upload.php[/b]

9. [b]Use the "Browse" button to locate the torrent file you just created[/b] (hence the need for a dedicated torrent folder)

[img=https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/browsebutton.jpg]
10. [b] Fill out the form with all the artist info/author/app info/etc and tick all applicable boxes[/b] 
       *Tracklists can be found using the [color=red]WaffleBrainz[/color]  script (available [u][url=https://vartrsk.googlepages.com/whatwafflebrainz.user.js]here[/url][/u]) which automatically fills in everything on the upload page. You'll need the [color=red]Greasemonkey[/color] script manager to run this (available [u][url=https://www.greasespot.net/]here[/url][/u]) Otherwise, you can find tracklistings at either https://freedb.org or https://gracenote.com . Of course, you're also allowed to manually type tracklists and info in, and there's no limit to creativity one can put into torrent descriptions 
        * It's also helpful and more appealing to include a pic of the album somewhere in your torrent description. Use a search engine (i.e. Google) to search images of the album you're upping, find the url of the image you'd like to use, and insert it into your description in this format, [b]without spaces[/b]: [ img=whatevertheurl ]

11. [b]Double-check for mistakes in the form, then click "Do It"[/b]
        *If uploading a music torrent, be sure to tick the "not a transcode" box

12.[size=3][b][u]Go back to Utorrent[/u], [color=blue]right click the torrent and select "Update Tracker"[/b][/color][/size]

[img=https://i300.photobucket.com/albums/nn39/sharinthegroove/updatetracker.jpg]

Tutorial made by hawkinbj

fields.title: uTorrent: Installation, Setup and Optimization
fields.body:
[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/Icon100px.png[/img]


[b]ÂµTorrent Installation, Setup and Optimization[/b]


ÂµTorrent is a powerful and efficient BitTorrent client for Windows.  ÂµTorrent has most of the features common to other BitTorrent clients, including bandwidth prioritization, scheduling, RSS auto-downloading, and Distributed Hash Table (DHT).  Additionally, ÂµTorrent supports the protocol encryption joint specification and Peer Exchange (PEX).  Unlike many torrent clients, ÂµTorrent  does not tax valuable system resources; typically using less than 6MB of memory.

This Guide will cover the "Installation", "Setup" and "Optimization" of the ÂµTorrent BitTorent Client.  I have tried to make this guide clear, concise and complete.  To this end, most settings are color coded and highlighted in the illustrations; a brief explanation is also included.  Some calculations are needed, but nothing beyond simple arithmetic.  My hope is that everyone, to some degree, will find this guide helpful.
[color=green]To make the separate sections stand out, each will be preceded by the ÂµTorrent Icon[/color]







[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/Icon100px.png[/img]



[b]Download and Install[/b]


[b]Initial Setup[/b]

     Speed test
     Connection Type and Speed Setting
     Port Check and Forwarding
     Protocol Encryption


[b]Optimizing the Internet Connection[/b]

     Tweaking the Network Settings
     Windows XP SP2 and the Event ID 4226 Patch


[b]ÂµTorrent "Preferences"[/b]

     General
     Downloads
     Connection
     BitTorrent
     Queueing 
     Scheduler
     Other
     Advanced
     Disk Cache
     User Interface
     Web UI







[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/Icon100px.png[/img] 


[b][url=https://www.utorrent.com/download.php]Download[/url] and Install ÂµTorrent[/b]

[url=https://www.utorrent.com/download.php]Download[/url] the latest stable version of ÂµTorrent.  On the [url=https://www.utorrent.com/download.php]Download[/url] Page, are two available stable versions of ÂµTorrent.  The "Installer Version" and a "Stand Alone Version".  The only difference between the two is that the "Installer Version" will create "Start Menu" and "Desktop" shortcuts during the installation process; however, on first run, the "Stand Alone Version" will ask if you would like to make shortcuts on your start menu and desktop.  This section will cover the "Installer Version" of ÂµTorrent.  (Click the thumbnails to enlarge)



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/1InstallationFolder.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/1InstallationFolderThumb.png[/img][/url]

"[b]Double Click[/b]" or "[b]Run[/b]" the ÂµTorrent installation executable



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/2LanguageWindow.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/2LanguageWindowThumb.png[/img][/url]

Choose a language and Click "[b]OK[/b]"



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/3SetupWizard.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/3SetupWizardThumb.png[/img][/url]

Click "[b]Next[/b]" to continue.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/4DestinationFolder.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/4DestinationFolderThumb.png[/img][/url]

"[b]Browse[/b]..." to a "[b]Destination Folder[/b]", or accept the default, then Click "[b]Next[/b]".



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/6StartMenuFolder.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/6StartMenuFolderThumb.png[/img][/url]

Choose a "[b]Start[/b]" menu folder, or Choose "[b]Do not create shortcuts[/b]", then Click "[b]Install[/b]"



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/7Installing.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/7InstallingThumb.png[/img][/url]

Wait for ÂµTorrent to be installed.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/8SetupComplete.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/8SetupCompleteThumb.png[/img][/url]

Click "[b]Finish[/b]" to close the Wizard.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/9Shortcuts.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/9ShortcutsThumb.png[/img][/url]

When given the option to add "[b]Shortcuts[/b]"; choose as desired.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/10TorrentDefault.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/10TorrentDefaultThumb.png[/img][/url]

When prompted to make ÂµTorrent the default application for .torrent files,
Click "[b]Yes[/b]" and torrent files (.torrent) will be automatically opened with ÂµTorrent.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/11FirstOpen.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/11FirstOpenThumb.png[/img][/url]

When ÂµTorrent is "[b]Opened[/b]" for the first time, the "[b]Speed Guide[/b]" is displayed.  
The Speed Guide will help you set your network for optimal speeds.



[url=https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/12TrayIcon.png][IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Install/12TrayIconThumb.png[/img][/url]

After the initial "Installation Start", when "[b]Run[/b]", the ÂµTorrent icon will appear at bottom right of the screen,
in the Windows System Tray.  Double Click the ÂµTorrent Icon [IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Preferences/uTorrentIcon.png[/img] to open the GUI.









[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/Icon100px.png[/img]


[u][b]Initial Setup[/b][/u]

[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/SpeedGuideMenu.png[/img]

[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/1SpeedGuide.png[/img]

After installation, ÂµTorrent will open to the "[b]Speed Guide[/b]" Window.  The ÂµTorrent â€œ[b]Speed Guide[/b]â€� will help you setup the
network settings, for optimal speed.  The "[b]Speed Guide[/b]" can be accessed at any time by navigating to
[b]ÂµTorrent[/b] > [b]Options[/b] > [b]Speed Guide (Ctrl + G)[/b]




[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/2SpeedGuide.png[/img]

[b]A)  Speed test[/b]

The settings in ÂµTorrent are directly proportional to the Maximum Upload Rate.  For the initial setup of ÂµTorrent,
you can use the "Advertised" (claimed) Max Upload Rate from the Internet Service Provider (ISP),
but by doing a speed test you can more accurately judge your current line throughput or internet connection speed.
It is advisable to do a speed test when prompted.

1)	[color=maroon]Stop all internet traffic before proceeding with the test.[/color]
2)	Visit one of the numerous speed testing sites such as [url=https://www.dslreports.com/speedtest][color=blue]DSL Reports[/color][/url], [url=https://www.speakeasy.net/speedtest/][color=blue]Speakeasy[/color][/url] or [url=https://www.speedtest.net][color=blue]Speedtest.net[/color][/url]. 
3)	Perform the test several times. Select a good median result (neither the highest nor the lowest).
4)	The value needed to proceed with the initial settings is the Max Upload Rate, expressed in kilo bits per second (kb/s)
            not kilo Bytes per second (kB/s).  [ 1 kB/s = 8 kb/s ]




[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/3SpeedGuide.png[/img]

[b]B)  Connection Type and Speed Setting[/b]

1)	Expand the "[b]Connection Type[/b]" Drop Down Menu and using the "Advertised" (claimed), or Tested Maximum Upload Rate.
              Select the listing closest to your Upload Rate in kilo bits per second, rounding down as necessary.
2)	Speed tests may not be 100% accurate due to factors outside your control, if the closest speed option
              is only slightly higher than your Maximum Upload Rate (within 10%), it's generally safe to select that option.
3)	You will notice that the "[b]Affected Settings[/b]" have adjusted to match the selected speed.
              [color=maroon]Higher settings will not yield better speeds, and may in fact make speeds worse.[/color]




[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/4SpeedGuide.png[/img]

[b]C)  Port Check and Forwarding[/b]

To get the most from your given network connection it is vital you have an open port and that it is properly forwarded through 
the Router and/or Modem.  Software ports are numbered connections that a computer uses to sort network traffic. 
A port may support incoming traffic, outgoing traffic, or both.

When a computer on the internet sends data to the external IP Address of your router, the router needs to know what to do with the data.  
Port Forwarding tells the router, to which computer, on the local area network (LAN) to send the data. 
When you have port forwarding rules set up, the router takes the data from the external IP Address / port number and sends that data 
to an internal IP Address / port number.  Port Forwarding rules are created per port, so a rule set up for port 6881 will only work for port 6881, 
and therefore a port can only be used by one program at a time!


Pick any random port between 49152 and 65535, the "Unassigned" port range and enter that port number 
in the "Current Port" field.  Click the "[b]Test if port is forwarded properly[/b]" button to check the port you have chosen.  
The Default Browser will open and test the chosen port's mapping.


[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/PortCheckOpen.png[/img]

If the ÂµTorrent Port Checker displays this message, congratulations your port is open and accepting connections.


[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/PortCheckClosed.png[/img]

If the ÂµTorrent Port Checker displays this message, the port is not "Open", go to [url=https://www.portforward.com/english/routers/port_forwarding/routerindex.htm][color=blue]Portforward.com[/color][/url]  and allow the site to guide you 
through the forwarding process.  You will need to know the Router and/or Modem manufacturer, Model and the Username and Password; 
check the manual if the passwords suggested by [url=https://www.portforward.com/english/routers/port_forwarding/routerindex.htm][color=blue]Portforward.com[/color][/url] donâ€™t work.  



[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/5SpeedGuide.png[/img]

[b]D)  Protocol Encryption[/b]

Some Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are actively interfering with P2P activities to reduce their bandwidth requirements.
This causes the download speeds of file sharing programs, to become slow.  To avoid this, ÂµTorrent and other clients
have introduced Protocol Encryption to prevent ISPs from identifying BitTorrent traffic.

Click The "[b]Enable Encryption[/b]" box to select.









[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/Icon100px.png[/img]


[u][b]Optimizing the Internet Connection[/b][/u]



[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/TCPOptimizer.png[/img]

[b]Tweaking the Network Settings[/b]

â€œTweakingâ€� the TCP stack is necessary if you wish to fully utilize the available bandwidth of your connection.
You can do an â€œOn-Lineâ€� tweak test at [url=https://www.dslreports.com/tweaks][color=blue]DSL Reports[/color][/url] or use a program like [url=https://www.speedguide.net/files/TCPOptimizer.exe]TCP Optimizer[/url].

[url=https://www.speedguide.net/files/TCPOptimizer.exe]TCP Optimizer[/url] is a free, easy, "[b]No Install[/b]" program that provides an intuitive interface for tuning and optimizing your Internet connection. 
TCP Optimizer - [url=https://www.speedguide.net/files/TCPOptimizer.exe][color=blue]Download[/color][/url]
TCP Optimizer - [url=https://www.speedguide.net/tcpoptimizer.php][color=blue]â€œOn-Lineâ€� Documentation[/color][/url]

1 )  Select the Maximum "Advertised" (claimed), or Maximum Tested Download Rate, from the "[b]Connection Speed[/b]" slider bar.
          (The maximum available bandwidth, in kilobits per second [kb/s]).
2 )  Choose your "[b]Network Adapter[/b]", or check to "[b]Modify All Network Adapters[/b]".
3 )  Check "[b]Optimal settings[/b]" 
4 )  Click "[b]Apply changes[/b]", and reboot when prompted by the program.






[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/utorrent%20Speed%20Guide/EventID4226Patch.png[/img]


[b]The Event ID 4226 Patch[/b]

Windows Vista, Windows XP SP2 and Windows 2003 Server SP1 limit the maximum concurrent half-open connections (SYN) to a maximum of 10 
(the previous limit was over 65,000).  The drawback to this connection limit is that network intensive applications can be slowed, including Peer-to-Peer (P2P) clients like ÂµTorrent.  

To change the limit on maximum concurrent half-open connections, effectively editing the [b]TCPIP.SYS[/b] file, use the Event ID 4226 Patch.
  
A complete guide can be found here:  [url=https://www.bitmetv.org/forums.php?action=viewtopic&topicid=21662][color=blue]Windows XP SP2 and the Event ID 4226 Patch[/color][/url]
Windows XP SP2 and Windows 2003 Server SP1 [url=https://lvllord.de/?lang=en&url=downloads][color=blue]Download[/color][/url]
Windows Vista [url=https://www.yaronmaor.net/repair.htm][color=blue]Download[/color][/url]

Once the [b]TCPIP.SYS[/b] file, has been patched, open ÂµTorrent and navigate to:    

Options > Preferences (Ctrl+P) > Click "Advanced" > Click â€œnet.max_halfopenâ€� > Enter "[b]50[/b]" in the "Value" Field > Click "Set" 

[color=maroon]Do not change the â€œnet.max_halfopenâ€� value, without first patching the [b]TCPIP.SYS[/b] file, using the [b]Event ID 4226 Patch[/b][/color].

To truly optimize ÂµTorrent, set the limit to 50 and use ÂµTorrent normally; periodically check the [b]Windows Event Viewer[/b] for Event ID 4226 errors; 
if these errors are found, raise the limit by 50, continuing this process, until these errors are no longer logged.

To access the Windows Event Viewer, navigate to:    â€œStartâ€� > "Run" > Enter " [color=green]eventvwr.msc[/color] " > Click "Ok"

[u][b]Connection[/b][/u]

Connection Preferences allow the user to properly configure the connections port, proxy and bandwidth settings.  To optimize a given connection it is vital to have an open port and that it is properly mapped (forwarded) through the Modem and/or Router


[b]Listening Port[/b]

[b]Port used for incoming connections:[/b] - Specifies the port ÂµTorrent uses to listen for incoming connections; this port must be open to firewalls.
[color=green]If you have manually forwarded the ÂµTorrent port, enter that port number in the field provided[/color].  

[b]Random port button[/b] - Selects a random port between 10000 and 65000
 
[b]Randomize port each time ÂµTorrent starts[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will select a random port between 1024 and 5000 to use at startup.
[color=green]This option may conflict with manual port forwarding; If you have manually forwarded the ÂµTorrent port, disable this option[/color].
 
[b]Enable UPnP port mapping[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will use the "Universal Plug and Play Device Host" Windows Service (UPnP) to communicate with the router and automatically forward a port.  Some devices do not support UPnP, therefore it may still be necessary to manually forward the ÂµTorrent port.  Disable UPnP if this is the case.
  
[b]Add ÂµTorrent to Windows Firewall exceptions[/b] - Allows ÂµTorrent to add an entry to the Windows Firewall exceptions list that lets it bypass the firewall. This is useful only if you actually have Windows Firewall enabled. Note that this option works only on Windows XP with at least Service Pack 2 (SP2) installed.


[b]Proxy Server[/b]

While a Viable option, the use of a Proxy Server will inhibit Peer-to-Peer (P2P) file transfers

[b]Type[/b] - Choose the Proxy Server type from the drop down menu.  "HTTP" proxies cannot be used for Peer-to-Peer connections.
 
[b]Proxy[/b] - Enter the proxy's URL or IP address.
 
[b]Port[/b] - Enter the proxy's port.
 
[b]Authentication[/b] - When enabled, this setting allows for automatic log in on Secure Proxy Servers. 

[b]Username[/b] - Enter the "User Name" as required for authentication.

[b]Password[/b] - Enter the "Password" as required for authentication.

[b]Use proxy server for peer-to-peer connections[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will communicate and transfer data with peers through the proxy. By default, this option is disabled, and ÂµTorrent only uses the proxy, to communicate with trackers. 
Note:  Peer-to-Peer communication cannot be used with HTTP proxies. 


[b]Bandwidth Limiting[/b]

The settings in ÂµTorrent are directly proportional to the Maximum Upload Rate (MUR).  To properly optimize ÂµTorrent, or â€œSet for Best Speedsâ€� it is vital to have an accurate measurement of the MUR.

To get the most accurate reading on your system, do numerous tests, from various testing sites, to diverse testing servers, at different times of the day.  After getting these speeds, take an average and use this average, expressed in kilo bits per second (kb/s), as your MUR.
  
        [color=green]Maximum Upload Rate[/color] (kb/s) = ( test 1 + test 2 + test 3 +â€¦ test n ) / n          Where "n" is the number of tests in the "Average" 

To do a â€œSpeed Testâ€�, [color=maroon]Stop all internet traffic before proceeding[/color] and use one of the numerous speed testing sites such as [url=https://www.dslreports.com/speedtest][color=blue]DSL Reports[/color][/url], [url=https://www.speakeasy.net/speedtest/][color=blue]Speakeasy[/color][/url] or [url=https://www.speedtest.net][color=blue]Speedtest.net[/color][/url].  Please note, Internet Service Providers (ISP) â€œAdvertiseâ€� speeds in kilo bits / sec (kb/s) and ÂµTorrent speeds are set and reported in kilo Bytes / sec (kB/s).  1 kilo Byte  / sec (kB/s) = 8 kilo bits / sec (kb/s)


[b]Global maximum upload rate (kB/s): [0: unlimited][/b] - The maximum upload rate for all active torrents combined.  If this speed setting is too high, the internet connection can quickly become choked.  75% of MRU (rounding down) is generally accepted as "Optimal".  This setting is the upper limit, all adjustments should be made downward.

        [color=green]Global maximum upload rate[/color] (kB/s) = 0.75 ( Maximum Upload Rate (kb/s) / 8 )

[b]Alternate upload rate when not downloading (kB/s):[/b] - When enabled, allows the user to define an alternate upload rate, when no torrents are in downloading mode (only uploading). Other than the context in which it is active, this upload rate limit behaves exactly like the "Global Maximum upload rate".

[b]Global maximum download rate (kB/s): [0: unlimited][/b] - The maximum download rate for all active torrents combined.  While 0, or "Unlimited" is the default and usual setting, it is suggested that 95% of the maximum download rate in kB/s will result in a more stable network connection.

[u][b]BitTorrent[/b][/u]


[b]Number of Connections[/b]

[b]Global maximum number of connections[/b] - The maximum number of connections ÂµTorrent will make at any given moment for all active torrents.  The optimal setting is by coincidence the Maximum Upload Rate (MUR) expressed in (kb/s)

        [color=green]Global maximum number of connections[/color] = Maximum Upload Rate (kb/s)

[b]Maximum number of connected peers per torrent[/b] - The maximum number of peers ÂµTorrent will connect to, at any given moment for each separate torrent.  The optimal setting is the Maximum Upload Rate (MUR) expressed in (kb/s) divided by eight ( 8 )

        [color=green]Maximum number of connected peers per torrent[/color] = Maximum Upload Rate (kb/s) / 8

[b]Number of upload slots per torrent[/b] - The maximum number of peers ÂµTorrent will upload to, at any given moment for each separate torrent.  This setting is always at the very least, one (1) and can be expressed as the [u]Global[/u] Maximum Upload Rate in (kB/s) divided by four (4).

        [color=green]Number of upload slots per torrent[/color] = [u]Global[/u] Maximum Upload Rate ([u]kB/s[/u]) / 4

[b]Use additional upload slots if upload speed < 90%[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will open more upload slots if the current total upload speed is less than 90% of the â€�[b]Global maximum upload rate[/b]â€�.



[b]Additional BitTorrent Features[/b]

Distributed Hash Table (DHT) and Peer Exchange (PEX), are an alternate means of getting peers, from other peers instead of through the tracker; this is particularly useful on poorly seeded torrents, or when the tracker is unavailable. 
 
DHT and PEX should always be disabled when using a private tracker, since they can become problematic.  Some problems which may occur are the leakage of personal information and connecting to â€œunregisteredâ€� clients, which will result in invalid statistics. 


[b]Enable DHT Network[/b] - When selected, the Distributed Hash Table (DHT), will be enabled.

[b]Enable DHT for new torrents[/b] - When selected, ÂµTorrent will check for peers from the DHT network on each newly added torrent.  This option only works if the DHT Network is enabled, and if the 'Private' flag is not set in the .torrent file. 

[b]Enable Local Peer Discovery[/b] - When selected, ÂµTorrent will attempt to discover local peers via multicast.  If a peer is considered local, transfer rates with the peer will not be limited unless Limit local peer bandwidth is also enabled.  Local peers will not be added to the peer list for .torrent files with the 'Private' flag set. 

[b]Ask tracker for scrape information[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will â€œscrape the trackerâ€� (Request new Peer and Seed information).  By default, the tracker is scraped only when the torrent job is started, but this can be changed using the â€œbt.scrape_stopped:â€� setting in â€œAdvanced Preferencesâ€�. 

[b]Enable Peer Exchange[/b] - When selected, Peer Exchange (PEX) for each newly added torrent will be enabled, provided the 'Private' flag is not set for that .torrent file. 

[b]IP/Hostname to report to tracker[/b] - Enables the user to specify the IP address when reporting to the tracker.  This is used when the IP address is not reported correctly to the tracker; in example when using a proxy server.  A hostname may be entered in this field; therefore if a dynamic DNS service is in use, the domain can be entered here.


[b]Protocol Encryption[/b]

[b]Outgoing:[/b] - There are 3 Protocol Encryption modes available in the dropdown menu.  All modes will accept incoming encrypted connections, and the encryption is 2-way.
 
        [b]Disabled[/b] - ÂµTorrent will attempt to establish only unencrypted outgoing connections.

        [b]Enabled[/b] - ÂµTorrent will establish encrypted and unencrypted outgoing connections, depending on how the peer responds to the handshake.  
        This is the recommended option, as it allows ÂµTorrrent to connect to the largest number of peers. 

        [b]Forced[/b] - ÂµTorrent is â€œForcedâ€� to establish only encrypted outgoing connections.  Any peer that doesn't support encryption
        will not be connected to.  It is recommended that this option be â€œEnabledâ€� unless the ISP actively searches for 
        unencrypted incoming connections.  This can significantly impair the ability to connect to peers. 

[b]Allow incoming legacy connections[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will establish unencrypted incoming connections. If disabled, any incoming connection that is unencrypted will be ignored.  It is recommended that this option be â€œEnabledâ€� unless the ISP actively searches for unencrypted incoming connections.  This can significantly impair the ability to connect to peers.
