[b]Queueing[/b]

Queueing Preferences, allow the user to set parameters, at which torrents will start, stop and the speeds at which the torrent will seed. 


[u][b]Queue Settings[/b][/u]

[b]Maximum number of active torrents[/b] - The total maximum number of â€œunforcedâ€� active torrents, before placing torrents in the queue.  Torrents are counted regardless of whether they are uploading, or downloading, as long as the speed is at least 1 kB/s.

This is a personal preference setting, but a certain amount common sense and restraint is needed.  The total available connection bandwidth will be split between active torrents, therefore the maximum connection upload and download speed must be taken into account.

[color=green]Four (4) is a good, general use number, with which to start[/color].  If you have numerous sporadically seeded torrents the number can easily be raised, or â€œForced Startâ€� can be used.

 
[b]Maximum number of active downloads[/b] - The maximum number of â€œunforcedâ€� downloading torrents, before placing torrents in the download queue.  This option only applies to torrents that are downloading or are to be placed in downloading mode. 

Using the same reasoning as stated in the â€œMaximum number of active torrentsâ€� section, a low number is suggested.  A valid strategy is to keep this setting low and allow the torrents to â€œQueueâ€�; as one torrent finishes, another will start.

[color=green]One (1), or two (2) at most, to start[/color].  If for some reason a higher number is desired, â€œForced Startâ€� can be used.


[b]Seed While [Default values][/b]

[b]Ratio is: <=___%[/b] - This setting enables the user to select the ratio at which ÂµTorrent will stop, or throttle the speed of seeding torrents.  Setting the ratio to -1 is equivalent to setting it to unlimited.  A value of zero (0) will cause ÂµTorrent to ignore the ratio parameter and use the â€œor seeding time is:â€� setting only.  This value is interpreted as a percentage, please enter it as such.  ÂµTorrent will throttle the seeding process only after both this and â€œor seeding time is:â€� have been reached. 

[b]or seeding time is:[/b] - This setting enables the user to select the maximum amount of time you wish a torrent to continue seeding, at normal speeds after it has finished downloading.  ÂµTorrent will throttle the seeding process, only after both this and the ratio threshold have been reached. 

[b]Seeding tasks have higher priority than downloading tasks[/b] - When enabled; seeding tasks will have a higher priority than downloads.   If the maximum number of active torrents is reached, and a torrent reaches seeding state, the downloading tasks will not force it into a queued seeding state. 


[b]When ÂµTorrent has reached the seeding goal[/b]

[b]Limit the upload rate to [use 0 to stop torrent]:[/b] - This setting enables the user to select the speed at which ÂµTorrent will throttle a torrent when it reaches the seeding goal. A value of zero (0) will stop the torrent.  This value is expressed in kB/s. 
Force Start takes the selected torrent job(s) out of queue order (makes it ignore queueing) and forces it to start immediately, even if the maximum number of active torrent jobs and/or downloads has been reached. Forced torrent jobs will not stop even if they reach the seeding goals.

[u][b]Scheduler[/b][/u]

[b]Scheduler Table[/b]

â€¢	Each square in the table represents, horizontally each hour per day and vertically the day of the week.  The color can be changed by left-clicking these boxes.  It cycles through dark green, light green, and white.  To get light red (Seeding Only), hold Shift while left-clicking on the box. Left-click-dragging will cause all time blocks that the mouse passes over to change to the new color. 

â€¢	If the box is dark green, it is Full Speed, which means that ÂµTorrent will adhere to the global upload and download rate limits during that hour. 

â€¢	If a box is light green, it means the upload and download rates are â€œLimitedâ€� and will be bound by the rate limits set, in the "Scheduler Settings" section. 

â€¢	If a box is light red, it means â€œSeeding Onlyâ€�, and all â€œUnforcedâ€� torrents which are downloading, will be stopped.  
    Seeding torrents will proceed to seed as usual. 

â€¢	If a box is white, it means that all torrent jobs that are not â€œForcedâ€� will be set to â€œStopâ€�.

[b]Limited download rate (kB/s):[/b] - The â€œGlobal Maximum Download Rateâ€� for all torrents when operating under â€œLimited modeâ€�.  Other than the context in which it is active, this download rate limit behaves exactly like the global maximum download rate.  

[b]Disable DHT when turning off[/b] - When â€œCheckedâ€� DHT (Distributed Hash Table) is disabled, when the scheduler is operating under â€œLimited modeâ€�.

[u][b]Advanced[/b][/u]

Advanced Preference settings are not intended for the casual user.  Unless the consequences are fully understood, Advanced settings, should not be modified.  Advanced Preferences settings, have two types of editable "Values",  Numerical and Logical (True & False).  To change values, use the "Set" button.  To return a value to the default setting, use the "Reset" button.


[b]gui.compat_diropen[/b] - Enables a different directory open window for those having problems seeing directories with the default directory browser.

[b]net.bind_ip[/b] - Makes ÂµTorrent use a specific LAN adapter for incoming connections only. Specify the IP address of the adapter.

[b]net.outgoing_ip[/b] - Makes ÂµTorrent use a specific LAN adapter for all outgoing connections only. Specify the IP address of the adapter.

[b]net.outgoing_port[/b] - Makes ÂµTorrent use a single outgoing port. This should only be used in specific cases. This can be used with full cone NAT routers, to reduce the number of NAT table entries and thus, prevent crashes. 

[b]net.low_cpu[/b] - Reduces CPU use slightly.  Unless the system is significantly slow, leave this setting off.

[b]net.max_halfopen[/b] â€“ The number of  half-open (incomplete) connection attempts ÂµTorrent will make at any one time.  Windows Vista, Windows XP SP2 and Windows 2003 Server SP1 limit the maximum concurrent half-open connections (SYN) to a maximum of 10 (the previous limit was over 65,000).  The drawback to this connection limit is, network intensive applications can be slowed, this includes Peer-to-Peer (P2P) clients like ÂµTorrent.

          [color=maroon]Do not change this setting without first changing (patching) the [b]TCPIP.SYS[/b] file, using the [b]Event ID 4226 Patch[/b][/color].

          To change the limit on maximum concurrent half-open connections, effectively editing the [b]TCPIP.SYS[/b] file, use the Event ID 4226 Patch.

          A complete guide can be found here:  [url=https://fora.demonoid.com/index.php?topic=120502.0][color=blue]Windows XP SP2 and the Event ID 4226 Patch[/color][/url]
          Windows XP SP2 and Windows 2003 Server SP1 [url=https://lvllord.de/?lang=en&url=downloads][color=blue]Download[/color][/url]
          Windows Vista [url=https://www.yaronmaor.net/repair.htm][color=blue]Download[/color][/url]

          To change the â€œ[b]net.max_halfopen[/b]" setting, enter the desired "Value" in the field provided and click "Set".

          To truly optimize ÂµTorrent, set the limit to 50 and use ÂµTorrent normally; periodically check the [b]Windows Event Viewer[/b] for
          Event ID 4226 errors; if these errors are found, raise the limit by 50, continuing this process, until these errors are no longer logged.

          To access the Windows Event Viewer, navigate to:    â€œStartâ€� > "Run" > Enter " [color=green]eventvwr.msc[/color] " > Click "Ok"


[b]net.wsaevents[/b] - Intended to address unusual firewall problems. Lower the value one by one to see if it makes any difference.

[b]ipfilter.enable[/b] - Enables or disables the use of ipfilter.dat

          [color=maroon][b]You can ban certain IP ranges in ÂµTorrent with "ipfilter.dat"[/b][/color]

          "[b]ipfilter.dat[/b]"  is a simple text file that specifies IP ranges to block.
          The format is xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx - yyy.yyy.yyy.yyy
          You can also use single IPs on a line (i.e. xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx). 
          Each new IP or IP range must be placed on a new line.

          Download the latest blocklist from Bluetack at [url=https://www.bluetack.co.uk/config/nipfilter.dat.gz][color=blue]https://www.bluetack.co.uk/config/nipfilter.dat.gz[/color][/url]. This list is updated daily, 
          and contains all known Anti-P2P organizations, trackers and peers, as well as all known Goverment & Military IP addresses.
          Once downloaded, extract and rename the file to "[color=Green]ipfilter.dat[/color]".

          To make the list available to ÂµTorrent, put it in the [color=Green]%AppData%\uTorrent[/color] folder, found at:

          [b]C:\Documents and Settings\*User Name*\ApplicationData\uTorrent[/b]  or  Start > Run > [color=Green]%APPDATA%\uTorrent[/color]. 

          [color=green]After placing the ipfilter.dat in this folder, set "[b]ipfilter.enable[/b]" to "True", and click "Apply"[/color]

          You can verify that the list has been loaded by looking under the "Logger" tab in ÂµTorrent,
          where you should see the line "[color=Green]Loaded ipfilter.dat (X entries)[/color]".
          To reload ipfilter.dat without restarting ÂµTorrent (1.7+ only), view the Peers tab, right click, and select "Reload IPFilter."


[b]dht.rate[/b] - Control setting for DHT bandwidth.  With automatic management (-1),  ÂµTorrent will limit DHT bandwidth based on the Max Upload Rate;  this limit ranges from 512 to 8192. [b]dht.rate[/b] uses your Max Upload Rate divided by 16 to determine this value, to improve DHT performance.

[b]rss.update_interval[/b] - Sets the update interval for RSS.  Values lower than 5 will be ignored, and remain at 5.

[b]gui.update_rate[/b] - Sets the refresh interval for the GUI in ms; the minimum is 500ms.

[b]gui.delete_to_trash[/b] - Sends deleted files to the recycle bin.  This can also be enabled by right clicking on the remove toolbar icon and checking "Move to trash if possible."

[b]gui.default_del_action[/b] - Sets the default remove action.  This option should not be modified directly, and instead should be modified by right clicking the "Remove" toolbar icon while holding "Shift" and choosing the "Remove" option you want to be default.

[b]gui.bypass_search_redirect[/b] - Sets ÂµTorrent to search directly on the selected search engine rather than being redirected through https://search.utorrent.com. 

[b]queue.dont_count_slow_dl/ul[/b] - Forces ÂµTorrent to not count torrents going less than 1KB/s up, or down towards the active torrents.

[b]queue.prio_no_seeds[/b] - Prioritizes torrents that have no seeds when seeding.

[b]bt.scrape_stopped[/b] - Enables or disables scraping the tracker for torrents that have been stopped (not queued).

[b]bt.compact_allocation[/b] - Allows ÂµTorrent to create files similar to the Python scripting method, to save space. Do not use this option with [b]diskio.use_partfile[/b].  This option may not work properly.  The associated error is "Element not found". 

[b]bt.enable_tracker[/b] - Enables or disables the embedded tracker.  The tracker URL is https://your.ip:port/announce

[b]bt.multiscrape[/b] - This turns on/off multi-scrape, which is sending multiple hashes per scrape. You should not have to change this option, since ÂµTorrent automatically detects when a tracker doesn't support it.

[b]bt.send_have_to_seed[/b] - Enabling this option sends a message to other seeds indicating how many pieces you currently have.

[b]bt.set_sockbuf[/b] - A debugging option to auto detect the TCP buffer size (so_sndbuf) and adjust it based on the upload speed.

[b]bt.connect_speed[/b] - Controls the number of connections per second ÂµTorrent makes.

[b]bt.prio_first_last_piece[/b] - Enabling this option prioritizes the first and last pieces of each file in a torrent.

[b]bt.allow_same_ip[/b] - Allows multiple connections from the same IP. Generally this should not be used, since it weakens the anti-leech protection.

[b]bt.no_connect_to_services[/b] - Disallows connecting to peers using a remote port of 25 or 110. This should only be used if you really, really want to keep your e-mail detection on in your anti-virus.

[b]peer.lazy_bitfield[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent does not send the complete bitfield, but a sample of it, so as to prevent blocking of seeding.

[b]peer.resolve_country[/b] - Makes ÂµTorrent use a DNSBL service to determine a peer's country.

[b]peer.disconnect_inactive[/b] - This enables or disables disconnecting from inactive peers after a set period of time (default being 5 minutes). However, it will NOT disconnect if the number of peers in the swarm is lower than the value set for maximum number of connections per torrent.

[b]peer.disconnect_inactive_interval[/b] - Sets the time interval waited, before breaking an inactive connection.   This value is interpreted in seconds and the default is 5 min.  It is suggested that a higher value may result in greater connection stability. 

          [color=green]peer.disconnect_inactive_interval[/color] = 600


[b]diskio.flush_files[/b] - Enabling this option closes file handles every minute. This helps reduce the effect of Windows managing the system cache badly for some people and causing so-called "memory leaks".

[b]diskio.sparse_files[/b] - Enabling this option allocates only the data that has been written.  This option is only availabale to hard drives partitioned as NTFS (2k/XP/2003).  This option will increase fragmentation, but save space while downloading.

[b]diskio.use_partfile[/b] - This is used to store data that is downloaded from files that marked as "Do not download." This is necessary to prevent the file from being allocated and stores the parts of the files that come with a piece, since ÂµTorrent must download and save the entire piece, which can include data for files you didn't want to download. Avoid using this in conjunction with compact allocation.

[b]diskio.smart_hash[/b] - This makes ÂµTorrent hash data from memory (if in the write queue), instead of flushing to disk, re-reading from disk, and then hashing. This should help reduce reads, especially at high speeds.

[b]diskio.coalesce_writes[/b] - Tries to minimize the number of writes to disk, by writing more data at once. It doesn't have any effect at on download speed, but might increase memory and CPU usage to achieve less disk writes.





[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Preferences/9DiskCache.png[/img]


[u][b]Disk Cache[/b][/u]

The disk cache is used to keep frequently accessed data in memory, to reduce the number of â€œReads & Writesâ€� to the hard drive.
ÂµTorrent normally manages the cache automatically, but you may change its behavior by modifying these settings.


[b]Disk Cache[/b]

[b]Override automatic cache size and specify the size manually:[/b] - Enables the user to set a new maximum memory usage for the disk cache.  Normally, ÂµTorrent automatically adjusts the cache size based on current download speed.

[b]Reduce memory usage when cache is not needed[/b] - Clears the disk cache when ÂµTorrent is not transferring data.
[color=maroon]This option should not be used if you wish to minimize disk access[/color].


[b]Advanced Cache Settings[/b]

[b]Enable caching of disk writes[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will decrease the frequency of disk writes, by storing data in memory before writing to disk.
[color=green]This has the effect of decreasing the frequency of reads from disk[/color].

     [b]Write out untouched blocks every 2 minutes[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will write to disk, 16 KB blocks of data in memory, 
     that haven't been touched for 2 minutes.  [color=maroon]This option should not be used if you wish to minimize disk access[/color].

     [b]Write out finished pieces immediately[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will write a piece to disk once it is completed in memory.
     [color=maroon]This option should not be used if you wish to minimize disk access[/color].


[b]Enable caching of disk reads[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will use the disk cache to store frequently read data into memory, from disk.
[color=green]This has the effect of decreasing the frequency of reads from disk[/color].

     [b]Turn off read caching if the upload speed is slow[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will disable read caching, if upload speed is below 40 KB/s.  
     This lowers memory usage when the cache is not needed.  [color=maroon]This option should not be used if you wish to minimize disk access[/color].

     [b]Remove old blocks from the cache[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will remove chunks of read cache data, from memory if they have not been
     accessed for 10 minutes.  [color=maroon]This option should not be used if you wish to minimize disk access[/color].

     [b]Increase automatic cache size when cache thrashing[/b] - When enabled, ÂµTorrent will increase the cache size, when the â€œReadsâ€� from disk
     increase (most often due to increased upload speeds).  If you override the automatic cache size, this option is not needed.





[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Preferences/10UserInterface.png[/img]


[u][b]User Interface[/b][/u]


[b]Actions for Double Click[/b]

[b]For seeding torrents:[/b] - This setting enables the user to select the action that ÂµTorrent takes, when double-clicking a seeding torrent, 
in the Main ÂµTorrent program window.

[b]For downloading torrents:[/b] - This setting enables the user to select the action that ÂµTorrent takes, when double-clicking a downloading torrent, 
in the Main ÂµTorrent program window.  

        [b]The following options can be set from the "Drop Down" menu[/b].

        [b]Show Properties[/b] - The â€œTorrent Propertiesâ€� window will open.
        [b]Start / Stop[/b] - Changes the condition of the double-clicked torrent (either Start or Stop).
        [b]Open Folder[/b] - Opens the â€œContaining Folderâ€� of the double-clicked torrent.
        [b]Show Download Bar[/b] - Displays a torrent information bar â€œAlways on topâ€�, on the Desktop.

        [IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Preferences/DownloadBar.png[/img]


[b]Speed Popup List[/b]

[b]Override automatic speed popup list[/b] - When enabled, the user can define the lists, of speeds displayed, when â€œRight-Clickingâ€� 
the corresponding item on the status bar, in the Main ÂµTorrent program window.  If left unchecked, ÂµTorrent will automatically generate a list, 
based on the current limit.

        [b]Upload speed list[/b] - The user defined â€œUpload Speedâ€� list.  Each value (in kB/s) must be separated with a comma; 
        no spaces should be used.  â€œ-1â€� adds a separator to the list.  Zero â€œ0â€� adds â€œUnlimitedâ€�.
        Any other positive value is interpreted normally (as that value).

        [b]Download speed list[/b] - The user defined â€œDownload Speedâ€� list.  Each value (in kB/s) must be separated with a comma; 
        no spaces should be used. â€œ-1â€� adds a separator to the list.  Zero â€œ0â€� adds â€œUnlimitedâ€�.
        Any other positive value is interpreted normally (as that value).


[b]Persistent Labels[/b]

Enables the user to specify a permanent label regardless of the number of torrents, which are actually using that label.
Multiple persistent labels may be entered, but must be separated with a â€œ | â€� (vertical pipe).  Persistent labels are given higher priority 
than normal labels in the category list, so correspondingly, they are displayed above their normal counterparts.


[b]Search Engines [/b]

Clicking the ÂµTorrent â€œSearch Buttonâ€� displays a drop down menu allowing the user to select a search engine, from this list.
To search, type the query into the â€œSearch Fieldâ€�, click the Search Button to choose the desired site and press â€œEnterâ€� on the keyboard.
The ÂµTorrent built-in Search facility will open a window or tab, in the default browser, and display the desired search.

        [*]The search engine text area, allows the user to edit the list of search engines used for the built-in torrent search.
        [*]Blank lines are displayed as separators in the search engine menu.
        [*]The search button and search field will be hidden if the search engine list is empty.      
        [*]Search engines may be added, but must be entered in the following format.



          Search Engine Format:    [color=green]Name|https://domain/path?search=[/color]

          Example:    [color=green]BitMeTV|https://www.bitmetv.org/browse.php?search=[/color]





[IMG]https://i133.photobucket.com/albums/q77/dvsdmn/uTorrent/uTorrent%20Preferences/11WebUI.png[/img]


[u][b]Web UI[/b][/u]

ÂµTorrent can be use remotely from any computer, via the ÂµTorrent Web UI (User Interface) and a web browser, through the port designated for BitTorrent transfers.  Not every feature is available to the Web UI, but most are accessible including, â€œAddâ€� by either uploading a .torrent file, or by entering the torrent URL, â€œStartâ€�, â€œStopâ€�, â€œRemoveâ€� and changing bandwidth settings.

To use the ÂµTorrent Web UI the file â€œ[b]webui.zip[/b]â€� must be placed â€œ[color=maroon]as is[/color]â€� (still zipped) in the same folder as ÂµTorrent's â€œ[b]settings.dat[/b]â€� file, by default at:

        C:\Documents and Settings\[color=green]*User Account*[/color]\Application Data\ ÂµTorrent

The file â€œ[b]webui.zip[/b]â€� can be downloaded [url=https://download.utorrent.com/beta/webui_v0.310_beta_2.rar][color=blue]here[/color][/url]; included in the â€œ[b]webui_v0.310_beta_2.rar[/b]â€� download, are webui.zip, ÂµTorrent.exe and additional instructions.

Once enabled and properly setup, the ÂµTorrent Web UI can be accessed using the systemâ€™s IP address and ÂµTorrent listening port.
From a remote location simply open the web browser and enter in the address bar "[color=green]https://Home System IP: Port/gui/[/color]â€œ 
 i.e. https://123.456.78.90:52000/gui/      If you use a dynamic DNS Service, your domain may be used instead of the IP address.


[b]Enable Web Interface[/b] - When enabled the ÂµTorrnet Web UI will be available for remote use.


[b]Authentication[/b]

[b]Username[/b] - Enables the use of a specific â€œUsernameâ€� with which to log in from a remote location, adding an additional layer of security.  
The default is â€œAdminâ€�.

[b]Password[/b] - Used to define a "Password" for the specificied â€œUsernameâ€�.  This field may be left blank if a password is not desired.

[b]Enable Guest account with username:[/b] - When enabled the â€œGuest Accountâ€� is activated.  When enabled, a â€œUsernameâ€� for the â€œGuest Accountâ€� must be specified.  A â€œGuestâ€� may view (but not edit) the torrents currently in ÂµTorrent.


[b]Connectivity[/b]


[b]Alternative listening port (default is the bittorrent port):[/b] - When enabled, the user can set a port specific to Web UI requests; this option is especially valuable when using â€œ[b]Randomize port each time ÂµTorrent starts[/b]â€�.  The "Alternative" listening port must be forwarded manually, even if â€œ[b]UPnP[/b]â€� is used to forward the normal ÂµTorrent port.  If left disabled, ÂµTorrent will serve the Web UI over the normal listening port.

[b]Restrict access to the following IPs (Separate multiple entries with ,):[/b] - Allows the user to limit the IPs which can connect to the web interface.  Multiple IPs may be specified, but must be separated by commas.  IP ranges may be set using â€œ[b]Classless Inter-Domain Routing[/b]â€� (CIDR) notation; i.e. "[color=maroon]xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx[/color]/[color=green]n[/color]" where [[color=maroon]xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx[/color]] is the IP Address and [[color=green]n[/color]] is the number of (left most) '1' bits in the mask.

Tutorial made by [url=https://what.cd/user.php?id=24354]DvsDmn[/url]

fields.title: uTorrent: Make Your Own Tracker
fields.body:
If you've got a large amount of data to transfer from one place to another, we all know BitTorrent is an extremely efficient way of doing it.

But sometimes you may want to transfer data which you don't want to (or can't) upload to a tracker on the internet.

This is where uTorrent comes in handy, because it can act as your own private tracker.

You'll need a few things before you begin:

1.  A recent copy of uTorrent.  1.7.5 is the latest version, there's no excuse not to use it.
2.  Your external IP address.  You can use https://www.whatismyipaddress.com to find this.
3.  Your listen port in uTorrent.  You can find this in uTorrent's Options > Preferences > Connection > Port used for incoming connections.
4.  You must be clever/connectable!  This won't work if you don't have port forwarding correctly configured.

Here's what you need to do.  Open up uTorrent and go Options > Preferences > Advanced.  Scroll down to find bt.enable_tracker and set it to True.  Restart uTorrent for this to take effect.

Now, create a new torrent.  As usual, browse to find the file or folder you wish to share.

For the tracker url, use the following information:

https://your_ip_address:your_listen_port/announce

So, for example, if your IP address is 123.123.123.123 and your listen port is 54321 then you would put this as your tracker url:

https://123.123.123.123:54321/announce

Remember to tick 'Start Seeding'.  Tick 'Private Torrent' to disable DHT and Peer Exchange for this torrent if you want to.

Now press 'Create and save as..' and save the .torrent file somewhere.  uTorrent should now connect (to itself) and the tracker status should be 'working'.  You'll note it has a 10 minute announce interval. 

That's all there is to it.  You can now send that .torrent file to someone, they can open it in their torrent client and start downloading the content.

Want something more fancy than an IP address?  Get yourself a domain name from somewhere like https://www.dyndns.com/services/dns/dyndns/

Troubleshooting:  If the connect times out and can't find the tracker, you've done something wrong.  Ensure you've got the correct IP address, port, and that uTorrent is definiately connectable from the outside.  You can run uTorrent's test for that by going to Options > Speed Guide and clicking Test if port is forwarded properly.  Also, ensure you have a colon separating the IP address and port number! 

Not mine, got it from azc a while back at Oink.

Tutorial made by hotemetoot

fields.title: uTorrent: Re-seeding files you have
fields.body:
First off all credit to yui (bitmetv) if you see this and mind my reposting please let me know.

For Utorrent


==========================================================

This is a noob guide. Only for those who are extremely lost.

Basic concept :

1.   Set the download location of the file to the file you have on your computer.
2.   Set the file priority to "do not download" (this is a precaution i like to take).
3.   Hash-check through the file(s).
4.   You are ready to seed!

* You might want to make a backup copy of the files as a precaution.
It is possible to lose files (ie season packs) if you aren't careful : )

==========================================================

In uTorrent :

0.   Open the .torrent file in uTorrent. You should get a dialog box as shown in the screenshot below. If not, follow this :

Quote:
Getting the "Add new torrent" dialog box to show up :

1. If uTorrent has been configured to start torrents automatically without showing the add torrent dialog box, either unconfigure it (see #3)
    or add the torrent through File -> "Add Torrent (no default save)" menu option.
2. To turn on the Add New Torrent dialog box, go to Preferences -> Downloads -> make sure "Always show dialog box on manual add" is checked
3. To display the list of files in the "Add New Torrents" dialog box, Go to Preferences -> Downloads -> and check "Show a window that displays the files inside the torrent".

(Thanks folk for the tip.)



1.   Click on the "..." button, set the download location to the file on your computer.
2.   Make sure "Skip hash check" is unchecked.
3.   Uncheck the files in the bottom box. This tells uTorrent not to download the file.
4.   Click Ok.

             [img]https://img489.imageshack.us/img489/5905/addnewtorrentmh6.gif[/img]

5.   The progress of the hash-check process will be displayed in the 'Status' column.
6.   Additional file information can be viewed by clicking on the "Files" tab.
7.   The percentage of the file which you have is displayed in the 'Done' and '%' column.

   [img]https://img304.imageshack.us/img304/4299/filestabhq6.gif[/img]


Done!

fields.title: uTorrent: Seeding Torrents With the Same Hash
fields.body:
When you download a torrent from a private tracker and uTorrent says "The torrent you are trying to add is already in the list of torrents. Do you want to load the trackers from it?", you can use the instructions below to add the torrent file separately.

[size=3]Works with any version of uTorrent on Win2k or WinXP[/size]

[IMG]https://funkyimg.com/u/4951520071211_134837.png[/IMG]

1. Take a Python interpreter here: https://www.python.org/download/ and install it.
2. Copy script from here: https://paste.uni.cc/17825 [b](v2.0)[/b] and paste in your text editor (i.e. Notepad)
3. Save as [b]seed.py[/b] to the directory where the "problem" torrent file is located (i.e. C:\torrents)
4. Go to [b]Start -> Run...[/b] , type [b]cmd[/b] and click OK
5. Change current directory to the aforementioned one (i.e. type [b]cd c:\torrents[/b])
[b]Important:[/b] Exit uTorrent and wait for its process to finish (wait for one minute to be sure, or check for the presence of utorrent.exe in Task Manager)
6. Start script with torrent filename(s) as one or more arguments: [b]seed.py "torrent filename #1" ["torrent filename #2" [...]][/b], i.e. [b]seed.py "Torrent file.torrent"[/b]
  6.1. If you have a separate installation of uTorrent (with .dat files in the same directory with utorrent.exe), input the path to you resume.dat file (i.e. "c:\utorrent\1.8 alpha\resume.dat" ) as the first argument, like this: [b]seed.py "c:\utorrent\1.8 alpha\resume.dat" "Torrent file.torrent"[/b] (but your uTorrent executable file must have a name "utorrent.exe" for the script to work)
7. Follow the instructions on screen
8. When script finishes, start your uTorrent and seed the new file as you do normally.

Update: Current version is 2.0. Older version is here: https://paste.uni.cc/17782 (for uTorrent 1.7.* only)

[b]Everyone[/b], feel free to post any questions/problems concerning this script.

Also, please note that version 2.0 is out: https://paste.uni.cc/17825
Changelog:
 + Now works with any version of uTorrent (tested on versions 1.6.1, 1.7.5 and 1.8 beta)
 + There is no need now to start/stop uTorrent for every torrent file from argument string (a window will pop up, you just need to select all files and drag to uTorrent window)
 + Works with a separate installation of uTorrent (if you input a path to resume.dat file as the first argument, the script will work with utorrent.exe from the same directory)

[b]Question:[/b] if you were not to do this, would you still be able to seed?[/quote]
[b]Answer:[/b] Technically, yes. But you shouldn't.
When you get this message: [quote]The torrent you are trying to add is already in the list of torrents. Do you want to load the trackers from it?[/quote] you must click "No", because other way uTorrent will report incorrect (bigger) upload amount to trackers, and that could be considered as cheating.

Tutorial made by [url=https://what.cd/user.php?id=10195]Oniisan[/url]

fields.title: uTorrent: WebUI Tips and Tricks
Extracting Video Information From Movie Files Using MediaInfo
fields.body:
As stated in the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=88]Uploading Rules[/url], every uploader is required to provide video information such as resolution, bitrate, etc in the torrent description. This is easy and takes less than a minute.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]GUI Instructions[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[list=1]
[*] Download [url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/]MediaInfo[/url]. Free, open-source, and multi-platform.

[*] Install, when you start the program for the first time a small window will show. Click "OK".

[*] File -> Open -> Open file(s)

[*] Browse to the movie's directory and select the movie file.

[*] View -> Text

[*] Copy then paste everything under [i]MediaInfo Output[/i].
[/list]

That's it! If you want to add this information to an existing torrent you have uploaded you can do so by clicking the '[ED]' next to your torrent on the film or browse page. If you are uploading a new torrent, paste the output into the 'MediaInfo Output' box on the upload page. If you want to add it to an existing torrent that someone else uploaded, pastebin the output and post in [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=3827]this thread[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Commandline Instructions (thanks Dacke!)[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[list=1]
[*] Download and install [url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/]mediainfo[/url].  In some cases, you may have to ask your seedbox provider to install it for you, but that shouldn't be a problem.


[*] Use the command: [b]mediainfo filename[/b]
For example on Linux/Mac/*nix:
[pre]$ mediainfo m-district9-720p.mkv[/pre]

[*] Copy the entire output of the command, or if you want to upload it directly to [url=https://pastebin.com]pastebin[/url], continue to the next step.

[*] Install [url=https://launchpad.net/pastebinit]pastebinit[/url]
On Debian, Ubuntu and derivatives:
[pre]$ sudo apt-get install pastebinit[/pre]

[*] Use the command: [b]mediainfo filename | pastebinit -b https://pastebin.com[/b]
For example:
[pre]$ mediainfo m-district9-720p.mkv | pastebinit -b https://pastebin.com[/pre]

[*] Use the pastebin link that is outputted by the command
[/list]

fields.title: Invites
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What Are Invites?[/b][/size][/color]

Invites allow you to invite new members to TehConnection. Since this is a private tracker, access is by invitation only, the only way someone joins is by being invited by someone who is already a member.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Who Can I Invite?[/b][/size][/color]

Anyone who you think will make a good member of this community. You should probably know them in real life and/or have a good sense of whether or not they'll be a good member, from other private trackers. Don't be afraid to invite someone who is new to bittorrent, but understand that you are their first source for help. If you are unable or unwilling to help them get started on becoming a good member, you probably shouldn't invite them.

[b]Warning:[/b] We have a zero tolerance policy regarding invite selling or trading. This includes giveaways on public sites. Giveaways on private trackers are acceptable on an "ask first" basis. Anyone caught violating this rule will be banned immediately. This ideal is enshrined in our site [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=94]manifesto[/url] and is not considered a minor offence.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]How Do I Get Invites?[/b][/size][/color]

On the 8th of every month:
[list=circle]
[*]'Teh Fanatic' receives +1 invites with a maximum of one ([b]1[/b]).
[/list]

On the 8th and the 22nd of every month:
[list=circle]
[*]'Teh Actor' receives +1 invites with a maximum of two ([b]2[/b]).
[*]'Teh Director/Producer' receives +1 invites with a maximum of four ([b]4[/b]).
[/list]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What Happens If My Invite Expires?[/b][/size][/color]

This can happen if you put down the wrong email address, the person you invited decided they didn't want to join, or multiple other ways. Don't worry though, your invite isn't lost! Every invite has a three ([b]3[/b]) day expiration date, so if it isn't used by then, it expires and you get the invite back. If you didn't receive your invite back when it expired, contact a staff member and they can sort it out for you.

If you have any questions that this wiki artice didn't answer for you, pay a visit to [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=104]IRC support channel[/url] or send us a  [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url] and someone will be happy to answer your questions.

fields.title: BitTorrent Jargon
fields.body:
[center][color=#FFAA00][size=6]BitTorrent Jargon[/size][/color][/center]
(Thanks to TorrentFreak for most of this. I did some grammar/spelling correction and added some extra ones as well.)

[color=#FFAA00][size=3].torrent File:[/size][/color] A .torrent fille contains all the info you need to download the file you want. For example, a torrent file has info on the size, the filename, and how to connect to other people (tracker). Another important function of the .torrent file is that it has a “hash” (sort of a digital signature) of each part of the file to make sure you don’t download corrupt or fake data but “the real thing”.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Client:[/size][/color] The BitTorrent client is the application you use to “load” the .torrent file so that you can connect to other people. There are a lot of different torrent clients available. The three most popular clients are Bitcomet, Azureus and uTorrent. If you’re new to BitTorrent I would recommend uTorrent, it’s light and has a great settings wizard to help you on your way.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Indexer:[/size][/color] Indexers are websites which list (index) .torrent files (myBitTorrent, Torrentz, Mininova etc.).

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Seeder:[/size][/color] A seeder is someone who has a complete version of the file you are downloading. If there are no seeders, you probably wont be able to get the file. So seeders are extremely important, make sure to “seed” the torrent once you finished downloading.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Leecher:[/size][/color] A leecher is someone who is downloading (and uploading) a file. You are a leecher if you do not have a complete copy of the file you’re trying to get. Note that a leecher normally is someone who’s not uploading, that’s not true in the BitTorrent jargon.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Peer:[/size][/color] A peer is the same as a leecher, but without the negative connotation.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Global Ratio:[/size][/color] The data you uploaded divided by the data you downloaded. A ratio higher than 1.00 means that you upload more than you download, which is a good thing. Most private trackers keep track of your ratio and will ban or block you if you have a bad ratio. Try to get at least a 1.00 or higher ratio.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Torrent Ratio:[/size][/color] Same as above, but for a single torrent instead of your overall data. Most places require you to seed each torrent to at least 1:1 (meaning you've uploaded as much as you've downloaded) before you can safely delete it.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Scrape:[/size][/color] Scraping means that your BitTorrent client is requesting info from the “tracker” about other people who are downloading or uploading the file. This is important because you need to know who has pieces of the file you still need.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Tracker:[/size][/color] The tracker is a server that has all the info about the people that are down- and uploading the file. The tracker itself does not have a copy of the file, it only tracks the up- and dowloaders and makes sure people are able to connect to each other. A tracker is not the same as a website that hosts torrents. Mininova for example is not a tracker, just a “torrent-site”.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Super-Seed:[/size][/color] Some clients have the option to “super-seed” (also known as "Initial seed" in some clients). Super seeding is different from seeding because it tries to send out pieces of the file that have not been sent before. So instead of sending the same piece to several peers, it tries to send a unique piece to everyone so that other peers can swap those pieces.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]ReSeed:[/size][/color] Every once in a while, torrents do die. Its sad, but we've all come across a movie we'd been looking for for ages, and there's no seeds. What do you do? Ask for a reseed. Basically, its asking the person that uploaded the movie (or someone that has downloaded the movie in the past) to make it available for download again, which means having them readd the .torrent file to their client. It will hash the data, and automatically start seeding again, since they have the full file.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Swarm:[/size][/color] The swarm are all seeds and peers that are connected together. So if your client shows 5 seeds and 10 peers then that’s your swarm.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]DHT:[/size][/color] DHT stands for “Distributed Hash Table”. DHT layers “decentralize” torrents what make them more stable and less reliant on the web based trackers. If a web based tracker goes down, the torrents stay alive because peers can act as “nodes” keeping the swarm intact.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Peer Exchange:[/size][/color] Enables trading of peer lists with other peers that support µTorrent's implementation of Peer Exchange. It is disabled if the selected .torrent file has the 'private' flag set.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Local Peer Discovery:[/size][/color] Enables discovery of local peers via multicast. It is disabled if the selected .torrent file has the 'private' flag set.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Initial Seeding:[/size][/color] Enables a more bandwidth efficient method of seeding the torrent job(s). This should be used only if you are the sole seeder in the swarm, and if there are at least 2 peers connected. Generally, this option should not be used by people with high upload speeds.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Announce:[/size][/color] Every so often the client "announces" to the tracker, asking it for new Peer information. You can do what's called a Manual Announce, which is sort of like a web browser refresh button, but it adds extra strain to the tracker and is usually frowned upon, and sometimes even punishable if done in excess.

[color=#FFAA00][size=3]Announce URL:[/size][/color] Your Personal Announce URL is a unique link that the tracker uses to credit you with your data transfer, as in how much you have uploaded/downloaded, and the data gets appended to your Global Ratio.

fields.title: Movie Sources
fields.body:
This article is intended to describe the various sources the films uploaded to our site can originate from. This can be important when considering the quality of a file. Not all of these sources are permitted for upload on TehConnection but they are here so this list is complete.

The titles of each source follow a format of [color=red]Name of Source (Tag)[/color]. The tag is how that source is represented by members of the Scene and p2p groups when naming their releases. This is what to look for when checking files for upload to TehConnection. There are multiple tags for some sources types and it is usually up to the uploader's personal preference which one they use.

This article makes an important distinction between pre-retail and retail sources. Retail sources are the best quality available and when they are uploaded to TehConnection all pre-retail formats of a particular film are immediately removed.




[center][color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Pre-retail Release Formats[/b][/size][/color][/center]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]CAM[/b] (CAM)[/size][/color]

A CAM is a cinema recording usually done with a digital video camera. A tripod is sometimes used but a lot of the time this wont be possible so the camera may shake. The seating placement isn't always ideal so it might be filmed from an awkward angle. If cropped properly this is hard to notice unless there's text on the screen but a lot of times these are left with triangular borders on the top and bottom of the screen. Sound is taken from the on board microphone of the camera and, especially in comedies, laughter can often be heard during the film. Due to these factors picture and sound quality are usually quite poor, but sometimes we're lucky, and the theater will be fairly empty and a fairly clear signal will be heard.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Telesync[/b] (TS, CAM.TS)[/size][/color]

A telesync is the same as a CAM except it uses an external audio source (most likely an audio jack in the chair for hard of hearing people). A direct audio source does not ensure a good quality audio, as a lot of background noise can interfere. A lot of the times a telesync is filmed in an empty cinema or from the projection booth with a professional camera, giving a better picture quality. Quality ranges drastically, check the sample and screen shots before downloading the full release. A high percentage of telesyncs are often CAMs that have been mislabeled.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Telecine[/b] (TC)[/size][/color]

A telecine machine copies the film digitally from the reels. Sound and picture should be very good, but due to the equipment involved and cost telecines are fairly uncommon. Generally the film will be in correct aspect ratio, although 4:3 telecines have existed. A famous example is the Jurassic Park 3 telecine. Telecine should not be confused with TimeCode, which is a visible counter on screen throughout the film.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Workprint[/b] (WP)[/size][/color]

A workprint is a copy of the film that has not been finished. It can be missing special effects, scenes and music. Quality can range from excellent to very poor. Some workprints are very different from the final print (Wolverine was missing all the special effects) and others can contain extra scenes (Jay and Silent Bob). Workprints can be nice additions to the collection once a good quality final has been obtained.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DivX Re-encode[/b] (REEnc)[/size][/color]

A DivX Re-encode is a film that has been taken from its original VCD source and re-encoded into a small DivX file. Most commonly found on file sharers, these are usually labeled something like Film.Name.Group(1of2) etc... Common release groups are SMR and TND. These aren't really worth downloading, unless you're that unsure about a film you only want a 200MB copy of it. Generally avoid.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Pay per view[/b] (PPV, PPVRip)[/size][/color]

Pay per view rips generally originate from pay television stations from which you pay for each program (movie, television episode) you watch. Generally these originate from the Far East and are often not far behind theatrical releases. The quality is usually lower than standard analogue television rips.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Video on Demand[/b] (VOD, VODRip)[/size][/color]
A rip sourced from Video on Demand services. Usually similar quality to Pay per view rips. The main difference is how the sale and distribution works in terms of the cable company and licencing.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Watermarks[/b] (WATERMARK)[/size][/color]

A lot of films come from Asian Silvers/PDVD (see below) and these are tagged by the people responsible. Usually with a letter/initials or a little logo, generally in one of the corners. Most famous are the "Z" "A" and "Globe" watermarks.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Screener[/b] (SCR)[/size][/color]

A pre-release VHS tape sent to rental stores and various other places for promotional use. A screener was commonly supplied on a VHS tape usually in a 4:3 aspect ratio, although letterboxed screeners were sometimes found. Screeners are less common now and have more or less been replaced by DVD screeners (see DVDScr below). The main draw back is a "ticker" (a message that scrolls past at the bottom of the screen with the copyright and anti-copy telephone number). If the tape contained any serial numbers or any other markings that could lead to the source of the tape these have to be blocked, usually with a black mark over the section. This is sometimes only for a few seconds but unfortunately on some copies this will last for the entire film and some can be quite big. Depending on the equipment used screener quality can range from excellent if done from a master copy, to very poor if done on an old VHS recorder through poor capture equipment on a copied tape. Most screeners were transferred to VCD, but a few attempts at SVCD have occurred, some looking better than others.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DVD Screener[/b] (DVDScr)[/size][/color]

Same premise as a screener, but transferred off a DVD. Usually letterboxed or anamorphic, but without the extras that a retail DVD would contain. The ticker is not usually in the black bars, and will disrupt the viewing. If the ripper has any skill, a DVDScr should look very good. Usually transferred to SVCD or DivX/XviD.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Region X[/b] (R8, R7, R6...)[/size][/color]

Typically these releases are high quality telecines intended for the East European market. The most commonly released are R5 and are released in Russian language only. These are an initiative to combat piracy in that region and are released very soon after a film's theatrical release. Ironically, these movies then have the English audio track from another source (such as a telesync) dubbed over them and are released. Until recently these releases have been tagged as R5 but we're starting to see similar sources from other regions tagged as R3 or R6. The number is derived from the [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DVD_region_code]DVD region[/url] the DVD is released in.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Region X (Blu-ray)[/b] (RC/3, RB/2)[/size][/color]

Blu-ray followed a similar [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc#Region_codes]region coding[/url] idea as DVD but with far fewer regions. Releases tagged as RC/3 are the Blu-ray equivalent to an R3 or an R5 DVD release.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Television Rip[/b] (TVRip)[/size][/color]

Television rips are episodes or movies capped from ordinary analogue television. They are the lowest quality television rips available.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Digital Satellite Rip[/b] (DSRip)[/size][/color]

Digital satellite rips are post air caps from a digital satellite transmission. They are roughly on par with PDTV rips.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Pure Digital Television[/b] (PDTV)[/size][/color]

Post air rips, usually from a PCI TV card that supports digital TV but not at a high definition resolution. This and HDTV are the most common formats for television releases.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]High Definition Television[/b] (HDTV)[/size][/color]

Commonly used to tag high definition television rips. Post air rips, usually from a PCI tv card that supports high definition television which is broadcasted digitally and at a very high resolution compared to regular television.




[center][color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Retail Release Formats[/b][/size][/color][/center]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]VHS Rip[/b] (VHSRip)[/size][/color]

Transferred off a retail VHS, mainly skating/sports videos and XXX releases. Fairly uncommon now as VHS has all but died.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DTheater[/b] (DTheater)[/size][/color]

DTheater, also known as [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DTheater]D-VHS[/url], is a now defunct improved version of VHS which was designed to store digital video data. The standard was expanded and this format is able to store both standard and high definition video. With the wholesale adoption of both DVD and Blu-ray this source is not very common anymore.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DVD Rip[/b] (DVDRip, DVDRiP)[/size][/color]

An encoded copy of the final retail DVD. If possible this is released pre-retail (for example, Star Wars: Episode Two) and should be excellent quality. DVD rips used to be released in SVCD format and DivX but are now exclusively released as Xvid.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]HD-DVD[/b] (HDDVD)[/size][/color]

A rip taken directly from an HD-DVD. These were common for a time before Blu-ray became the de facto standard for high definition media.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Blu-ray[/b] (Bluray, BluRay, BD, BDRip)[/size][/color]

Blu-ray Disc is an optical disc storage medium designed to supersede the standard DVD format. Blu-ray discs are in high definition format and as such are the best quality source commonly available.

fields.title: Scene Tags Information
fields.body:
Have you ever looked at something you've downloaded and not understood what part of the file or folder name means? If so, this article is for you. Most Scene & p2p groups add [i]tags[/i] to their releases in order to better describe what they have released to any potential downloaders. You may run into a few of these tags here at TehConnection because we add some of them to our site to make it clearer what has been uploaded.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/TIu4k.png[/img][/center]

The above shows where you will see certain tags added. Technically, 'Unrated' is also a tag but more on that later.

A typical Scene movie release will look this:
[br /]
[indent]
Charlie.and.the.Chocolate.Factory.PROPER.WS.DVDRiP.XViD-DEiTY
[indent]
./ CD1/Charlie.and.the.Chocolate.Factory.WS.DVDRiP.XViD.DEiTY.CD1.avi
./ CD2/Charlie.and.the.Chocolate.Factory.WS.DVDRiP.XViD.DEiTY.CD2.avi
./ Sample/Sample diety.charlie.avi
./ Charlie.and.the.Chocolate.Factory.WS.DVDRiP.XViD.DEiTY.nfo
[/indent]
[/indent]

As you can see there are a number of tags on both the folder and the files inside the folder. Typically, releases will follow the pattern [color=red][i]Movie.Name.Additional.Tags-GroupName[/i][/color]; this article will explain all the possible entries in the [color=red][i]Additional.Tags[/i][/color] fields.



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Proper[/b] (PROPER)[/size][/color]

According to scene rules, whomever releases the first DVDRip (for example) has won the 'race' for that movie. If the quality of that release is fairly poor and another group has another DVDRip (or the same source in higher quality) then the tag [i]proper[/i] is added to the folder to show that this release should be considered the winner. Proper is the most subjective tag in the scene, and a lot of people will generally argue whether the proper is better than the original release. A lot of groups release a proper just out of desperation due to losing the race. A reason for the proper should always be included in the NFO file.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Limited[/b] (LIMITED, LiMITED)[/size][/color]

A movie tagged with [i]Limited[/i] means it had a limited theater run, usually opening in less than 250 theaters, generally smaller films (such as art house films) are released as limited.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Internal[/b] (INTERNAL, iNTERNAL)[/size][/color]

A release tagged [i]internal[/i] means the particular release was not meant to be widely traded among Scene top sites. They are done for several reasons; usually at the request of a site operator or a group wanted to release a higher quality version of a classic film. Some internal releases still trickle down to IRC/newsgroups/Bittorrent, it usually depends on the title and the popularity.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Straight to Video[/b] (STV)[/size][/color]

Straight to Video. As the acronym suggests, any film that was never released in theaters should have the straight to video tag.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Aspect Ratio[/b] (WS, FS)[/size][/color]

These tags denote a films aspect ratio. They are less and less common as DVDs are rarely released in a full screen (FS) or 4:3 aspect ratio and most DVDs come in some flavour of widescreen (WS), either 16:9 or 2.35:1.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Repack[/b] (REPACK, RERIP)[/size][/color]

If a group releases a bad rip, they will release a [i]repack[/i] which will fix the problems. Rerip is a similar tag, simply denoting that a release was ripped from the source again.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Nuke[/b] (Nuke, Un-Nuke)[/size][/color]

A [i]nuke[/i] is a special case of tags applied by the Scene. These aren't applied to the file or folder and are handled by TehConnection in a special way. You will see this next to a torrent that has been nuked by the Scene.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/W3UoO.png[/img][/center]

A release can be [i]nuked[/i] for various reasons. Individual sites will nuke a release for breaking their rules (known as a local nuke) but if the film has something extremely wrong with it (no soundtrack for 20mins, CD2 is incorrect film/game etc) then a global nuke will occur, and people will stop trading it across sites. Nuked films can still reach other sources such as Bittorrent/newsgroups, but its a good idea to check why it was nuked first in case. Often nukes will occur for a group failing to provide proof that they have the retail disc despite the release being perfect in all other regards.

fields.title: IRC Basics
fields.body:
[align=center][color=#ddb205][size=4][b]IRC Basics[/b][/size][/color][/align]

[color=#ddb205][size=4][b]NickServ[/b][/size][/color]

[b]/NickServ register password email[/b]
Register your nickname with NickServ.

[b]/NickServ identify password[/b]
Everytime you log in to IRC you must identify with NickServ.

[b]/NickServ ghost nick password[/b]
If you lose your connection, a "ghost" of you may linger on the server, keeping you from taking your nickname back. Use this command to "kill the ghost."

[b]/nick nickname[/b]
Change your nickname to any specified nick.

[color=#ddb205][size=4][b]BotServ[/b][/size][/color]

[b]/msg BotServ Botlist[/b]
Get a list of available bots on a network.

[b]/msg BotServ say #channel text[/b]
Usage: /msg BotServ say #TehConnection meph is a dork!
Command to speak through the bot.

[b]/msg BotServ act #channel text[/b]
Usage: /msg BotServ act #TehConnection kicks neebs in the nuts
Command to "act" through the bot (like a /me command.)

[color=#ddb205][size=4][b]ChanServ[/b][/size][/color]

[b]/msg chanserv invite #channel[/b]
If you are on the access list for a channel that is +i (invite only) you can use this command to invite yourself back into the channel.

[color=#ddb205][size=4][b]Misc. Commands[/b][/size][/color]

[b]!access list[/b]
To get a list of all users that have been recorded to the access list for a certain channel (and their level)

[b]!k nick reason[/b]
Usage: !k optix don't be gay
Kicks a nick from the channel with the specified reason.

[b]!kb nick reason[/b]
Usage: !kb GLaDOSDan You're not welcome here anymore.
Kicks and bans a nick from the channel with the specified reason.

[b]!mute nick[/b]
Sets a soft ban on a nick so they can't send text to the channel.
(Undone with !unmute nick)

[b]/whois nick[/b]
Get whois information on a specified nick.

[b]/whowas nick[/b]
Get whois information on a nick after they've disconnected from the network.

[b]/msg nick text[/b]
Send a PM to a user without opening a separate window. (Opens a PM window on their side with your message.)

[b]/notice nick text[/b]
Send a message to another user that they'll see right in the channel window.
Example: [url=https://i40.tinypic.com/205egw2.png]here[/url]
Note: No one else can see what you're saying to eachother in the channel.

[color=#ddb205][size=4][b]If you decide to run your own channel...[/b][/size][/color]

[b]/msg ChanServ register channel password description[/b]
This command registers your channel with ChanServ as an official channel on the network.

[b]/msg ChanServ set channel founder nick[/b]
Set the founder of a channel.

[b]/BotServ assign #channel Botnick[/b]
Usage: /BotServ assign #yourchan TCBot
Assign a bot to a channel, in the event you make your own channel, etc. (Limited to channel Founder only.)

[b]/msg chanserv access #chan add nick level[/b]
Usage: /msg chanserv access #TehConnection add Winston_Churchill 3 (would give Winston_Churchill +v.)
Give a specified nick a specified level of access on a specified channel. 3 for +v, 4 for +h, 5 for +o, 10 for +a and 9999 for +q.

[b]/msg chanserv set #channel xop off[/b]
Example: !access add Winston_Churchill 3
Allows use of !access add command. The command listed above will do the same as the chanserv long hand.

[b]/msg botserv set #chan fantasy on[/b]
Usage: Allows for Fantasia commands, eg. !k, !kb, etc.

fields.title: Donations: Where Does the Money Go?
fields.body:
As a not for profit organisation, we really appreciate our donors [img]https://tehconnection.eu/static/common/smileys/heart.gif[/img]. Without them TehConnection would not exist. More information on donor benefits can be found by clicking the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/donate.php]here[/url] or the 'Donate!' button at the top of any page on site.

The donations that come into TehConnection are used to pay for the servers. At the moment we have two ([b]2[/b]):[br /]

[list]
[*] A dedicated server for the site & tracker. 
[*] A VPS for the developers to test bug fixes, create new features and so forth before they go live.
[/list]

Your funds are [b]_NOT_[/b] used to pay for IRC servers, T-Shirts or anything else. Any extra donations are used to pay for future months' server bills.

The current donation level can be viewed under your ratio information on any page.

fields.title: Montages
fields.body:
Montages can be found [url=https://tehconnection.eu/montage.php]here[/url] and is available at the top of any page on site.

This feature has been long awaited by a lot of you, and we're glad to have it here. That said, there are a few restrictions:
[br /]
[list]
[*] Only Teh Actor and above can create and edit Montages. We've done this to encourage more site participation and keep spam at bay.
[*] If you question whether or not your Montage is acceptable, please ask before you create. Montages such as "Movies that changed my life" or "Films neebs and I touch ourselves to when we hang out together" are not acceptable. Montages for Film Festivals, iconic collections (such as https://tehconnection.eu/montage.php?id=24) and the like are the kinds of things we want to see.
[*] Same rules for commenting on torrents goes for commenting on Montages. Keep it clean, no flaming, etc. If we see problems, the posts will be removed. If they persist, your posting privileges may be revoked. Stay on topic and polite to one another.
[*] Do not reorder or add to someone else's Montage without asking first, as they may have it organized a certain way that you are not aware of.
[/list]

fields.title: Site Rules
fields.body:
[size=6][color=#4682b4][b]Section 1 - Membership[/b][/color][/size]



[indent]
[size=5]Conduct[/size]
[list]
[*] Obey the expressed wishes of the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staff.php]staff[/url].
[*] Do not access the site or download data via TOR, a public proxy, or a VPN service utilising dynamic IP assignment.
[*] Do not offer invites in the forums or on IRC, outside the established invite board. Asking for invites on IRC or in the forums is prohibited.
[*] Do not spam the forums.  Spam includes any form of advertising (e.g., links to your uploads).
[*] Use common sense and courtesy.
[/list]


[size=5]Accounts[/size]
[list]
[*] One account per person.  One account per lifetime.  No exceptions.
[*] Accounts may be disabled at any time, at the discretion of the staff.
[list]
[*] You may appeal this decision in the #TC.Support channel on [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=104]IRC[/url].
[/list]
[*] User and Member class accounts will be automatically disabled if they have gone eight ([b]8[/b]) weeks without login and three ([b]3[/b]) weeks without seeding.
[list]
[*] A [url=https://tehconnection.eu/donate.php]donation[/url] or promotion to [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=2]Fanatic[/url] will provide immunity from [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=4]inactivity pruning[/url].
[/list]
[*] Selling and/or trading accounts and/or invites, or giving them away in a public forum, is strictly forbidden.
[list]
[*] Doing this will result in account termination for you and every user in your invite tree.
[/list]
[*] Avatars should not depict nudity, graphic violence, or anything else considered [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not_safe_for_work]NSFW[/url].
[/list]


[size=5]Seeding Requirements[/size]
[list]
[*] You must seed each downloaded torrent for at least 96 hours.
[list]
[*] Failure to complete this requirement within two weeks is considered a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=189]Hit and Run (HnR)[/url], and multiple HnRs will result in your account being disabled.
[/list]
[/list]


[size=5]Ratio Watch[/size]
[list]
[*] If your ratio (Data Uploaded / Data Downloaded) falls below 0.70, you will be placed on [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=187]Ratio Watch[/url].
[list]
[*] Once you are on Ratio Watch, you will have two weeks to improve your ratio before your download privileges are revoked.
[*] If you download more than 10 GB while on Ratio Watch, your download privileges will be revoked immediately.
[*] Once your ratio meets the 0.70 minimum, your download privileges will be restored
[/list]
[/list]


[size=5]Clients[/size]
[list]
[*] You must use a staff-approved BitTorrent client. Please refer to the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/rules.php?p=clients]Allowed Clients[/url] list.
[*] The use of modified BitTorrent clients to send falsified data ("cheating") is strictly forbidden.
[list]
[*] Doing this will result in account termination.
[/list]
[/list]
[/indent]



[size=6][color=#4682b4][b]Section 2 - Uploading[b][/color][/size]



[indent]
[size=5]Artistic Content[/size]
[list]
[*] If you have any doubt that what you want to upload is appropriate for TC, [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]ask us[/url] before uploading.
[*] Feature Films, Documentaries, Stand-Up Comedy
[list]
[*] One film per torrent. Movie packs and collections are not allowed.
[*] Music and concert videos with a focus on performance rather than documentary are not allowed.
[*] Sport videos with a focus on performance rather than documentary are not allowed.
[*] Instructional videos (e.g., fitness routines or cooking) are not allowed.
[*] Episodes of ongoing series (e.g. National Geographic Channel shows) are not allowed.
[*] HD-Resolution XviD content is not allowed.
[/list]
[*] Mini-Series (as listed on IMDb)
[list]
[*] Only completed, standalone mini-series are allowed.
[*] Encodes must be one file per episode.
[/list]
[*] Short Films
[list]
[*] Short film collections are only allowed as untouched sources, and the IMDb number of the first listed short film should be used for cataloging.
[*] Encoded shorts must be uploaded separately, with each short cataloged by its own IMDb number.
[/list]
[/list]


[size=5]Process[/size]
[list]
[*] If you choose to upload a torrent to TehConnection you must follow the instructions provided in the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=164]Uploading Guide[/url] and the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=98]Release Description Guide[/url].
[*] If what you want to upload does not appear in the chart below, [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]ask us[/url] before uploading.
[*] The name, structure, and content of all files and folders should be as close as possible to the torrent's original release. Do not alter, remove, or add new files or folders unless you know for a fact that you are restoring the release to its original state.
[*] At least three lossless [.png] screenshots of the film (not of blank frames, titles, credits or logos) are required for all uploads. If you need help generating screenshots,  [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=search&search=screenshots]consult the appropriate wiki article[/url].
[/list]
[/indent]


[center][img]https://tehconnection.eu/static/images/formats.png[/img][/center]


[indent]


[size=5]Trumping and Coexisting[/b][/size]
[list]
[*] Torrents that may coexist:
[list]
[*] Those with no connecting path between them in the chart.
[list]
[*] Pre-retail releases [HDTV, screeners, etc.] are trumped by releases from any other category in the chart.
[*] Multiple CAM/TS/PPVrip/VODrip releases may coexist if they are the only format available.
[/list]
[*] Sources with different extras (e.g., special features) or different [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_transfers]film transfers[/url].
[*] Sources and encodes of different cuts of a film (e.g., Theatrical and Director's Cut).
[*] Encodes that use different 3D formats (Half/Full, SBS/OU, etc.).
[*] Encodes that use different color depth (i.e., 8-bit vs. [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=137]10-bit[/url]).
[/list]
[*] Some examples of what constitutes "superior quality" for trumping purposes:
[list]
[*] Encoded from a source with unquestionably better picture (e.g., Blu-ray vs. HDTV).
[*] Increased transparency to the source, or equal transparency at a significantly lower bit rate.
[*] Inclusion of missing subtitles for dialogue in languages other than the main language of the film.
[/list]
[*] Some examples of what [i]does not[/i] constitute "superior quality" for trumping purposes:
[list]
[*] Higher bit rate.
[*] Lossless audio.
[*] Inclusion of a commentary track or a more diverse selection of subtitles.
[*] Encoded with a newer version of x264.
[*] Encoded by your favorite release group.
[/list]
[*] All trumps are at the discretion of the staff.
[/list]


[size=5]Technical[/size]
[list]
[*] Sources
[list] 
[*] Disc uploads (Blu-ray, HD-DVD and DVD) must be complete and untouched.
[list]
[*] Discs that have been compressed or stripped of extras are not allowed.
[*] Remux releases (wherein the disc's contents have been muxed into a single container file) are not allowed.
[/list]
[/list]
[*] Encodes
[list]
[*] The TehConnection Original (TCO) tag is awarded to user encodes meeting specific criteria. For more information see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=149]this article[/url].
[*] All encodes must be from an untouched source with original and unaltered video and audio streams. Transcodes (e.g. BRRips) are strictly forbidden.
[*] HD-sourced 576p encodes are not allowed.
[*] All encodes must be displayed in an aspect ratio as close as possible to that of their source.
[*] All encodes must run at the intended playback framerate of their source. If you don't know what that means, read the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=190]IVTC article[/url].
[*] All encodes must be progressive in display. If the source is interlaced, de-interlacing is required.
[*] All encodes must be [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=188]properly cropped[/url].
[*] Encodes may not be blocky, blurry, 'bitstarved', or in any way substandard due to unsuitable encoding settings.
[*] Any kind of defaced videos are not allowed. This includes any form of intro, outro etc.
[*] If the language of the film is not English, you must ensure that English subtitles are included.
[list]
[*] If English subtitles are unavailable, this must be noted in the release description.
[/list]
[*] The main audio track must be in the original language of the film.
[*] The main audio track must be one of the following formats:
[list]
[*] AC-3
[*] DTS
[*] DTS-ES
[*] DTS-HD MA
[*] Dolby TrueHD
[*] FLAC
[*] [MP3] [i](XviD only)[/i]
[*] [AAC] [i](only for Scene, WEB-DL, and encodes from sources whose main audio is 1 or 2 channel lossless)[/i]
[/list]
[/list]
[/list]

[/indent]

fields.title: How to Make a Sexy Release Description
fields.body:
[align=center][size=6][url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=3227#post64629]How to Make a Sexy Release Description[/url][/size][/align]


[color=#069][size=5]Required software[/size][/color]


[indent][url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/]MediaInfo[/url], Text Editor ([url=https://notepad-plus-plus.org/]notepad plus plus [/url]or [url=https://www.sublimetext.com/]Sublime Text[/url] etc.)[/indent]


[color=#069][size=5]Release Title[/size][/color]

	
[indent]Allow the user to quickly tell which release the torrent is this by centering it and increasing the text size to 5.

[align=center][size=5]Film.Title.Year.Source.Codec-ReleaseGroup[/size][/align]

[quote][pre][align=center][size=5]**Paste Release Name Here**[/size][/align][/pre][/quote][/indent]


[color=#069][size=5]Summary of Technical Specifications [nfo][/size][/color]


[indent]If the film you are uploading has a nfo file you can modify and clean it up so that it can be used. The objective of this portion of the description is to provide a user with a brief easy to read summary of the files Technical Specifications:
   

[indent][list][*] Video Codec & Bitrate
[*] Audio Codec & Bitrate
[*] Aspect Ratio
[*] Source
[*] Frame Rate
[*] Resolution
[*] Subtitles[/list][/indent]
	    
The iMDB url, iMDB Rating, Cast, Synopsis, Release Date, Theater Date, & Genre information often found is redundant (since it is available on the torrent page) and therefore suggested to not be included in the Summary of Technical Specifications.
	
	
[quote][pre][pre]**Paste nfo Technical Specifications Excerpt Here**[/pre][/pre][/quote][/indent]
	
	
[color=#069][size=5]Summary of Technical Specifications [no nfo][/size][/color]


[indent]Occasionally the file you are uploading did not come with a nfo file or it was lost etc. In the event of this use the MediaInfo Output to fill in the following template.
	
	
[quote][pre][align=center]| VideoCodec @ Kbps | Res. | FrameRate | AudioCodec @ Kbps |
[/align][/pre][/quote]

[i]Note: This is meant to be a Summary so it is important to only keep the pertinent Technical details. However, Subtitles are an important detail for foriegn language films.[/i][/indent]


[color=#069][size=5]MediaInfo Output[/size][/color]


[indent]Paste the entire MediaInfo ouput into this area. It is suggested that you modify the Complete Name portion, to remove any unneccesary path information and personal details. It is highly suggested that you use pre tags so that the output is easier to read; however, when doing this you will often have to modify the encoding parameters so that they do not run off the page.
	
	
[quote][pre][spoiler=MediaInfo]**Paste MediaInfo Output here**[/spoiler][/pre][/quote][/indent]


[color=#069][size=5]Screenshots[/size][/color]


[indent]It is suggested to spoiler tag screenshots, since it allows a user to choose whether they want to view them.


[quote][pre][align=center][spoiler=Screenshots]
[img]**Paste Screenshot url**[/img]
[img]**Paste Screenshot url**[/img]
[img]**Paste Screenshot url**[/img]
[img]**Paste Screenshot url**[/img]
[/spoiler][/align][/pre][/quote]
	
	
[i]For Source vs. Encode Screenshots use this:
	
[quote][pre][align=center][spoiler=Source vs. Encode Screenshots]
[img]**Paste Source 1**[/img]
[img]**Paste Encode 1**[/img]
	
[img]**Paste Source 2**[/img]
[img]**Paste Encode 2**[/img]
	
[img]**Paste Source 2**[/img]
[img]**Paste Encode 2**[/img]
[/spoiler][/align][/pre][/quote][/indent]
