fields.title: How to Create a Sample
fields.body:
This guide will show you how to make a sample from a .mkv.

What you need
-mkvmerge https://www.bunkus.org/videotools/mkvtoolnix/downloads.html Download and install it.
  - mkvmerge is a great program that lets you do many more things such as add subtitles, audio tracks, and shift audio tracks.


1) Open the program. 

[img]https://imgur.com/VSfAV.png[/img]


2) Add the movie file with the add button.

[img]https://imgur.com/0q9k4.png[/img]


3) Next click on the global tab.

[img]https://imgur.com/aGgIr.png[/img]

Find out where the sample is you want to take. Put in the timecodes as seen above. HH:MM:SS,HH:MM:SS . Then click start muxing.


4) The following window will appear.

[img]https://imgur.com/ettpT.png[/img]

After you see the second part finish writing, you can click abort as you wont need the third.


5) Now your done, rename it and you are good to go.

fields.title: KOMMANDANT MANIFESTO
fields.body:
[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection aims to be an archive site.[/color][/size]


[indent]This means that here at TehConnection, we are working towards providing a well-seeded archive of all available digital forms of cinema and film in their highest possible quality. We welcome you to upload old, outdated XviD and DivX releases, but only if a higher quality release is not already available, and know that when a superior quality release of the same format is uploaded, your upload will be removed.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection aims for quality.[/color][/size]


[indent]We therefore insist the usage of the highest quality codecs and encoders. Currently this entails the use of x264. If you are unsure how to encode content at archive quality, please refer to the Guides & Tutorials section of the forums. Users wishing to encode to XviD for the site must seek staff approval first. If you find a release that does not meet your expectations of quality, please do not hesitate to bring this to the staff's attention by reporting the torrent.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection is, above all else, a community.[/color][/size]


[indent]And not just a community within our own site, but extending among other trackers across the web. We therefore must insist that you respect the wishes of any site who wish to remain out of the public eye and do not mention any names, URLs, acronyms or any other information against the site's wishes.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection forbids the sale and/or trading of both invites and accounts.[/color][/size]


[indent]We actively work with staff at other sites to ensure that users who choose to ignore this rule, along with cheating, are banned on all private torrent trackers.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection expects maturity.[/color][/size]


[indent]To an extent. We expect you the user to treat other members fairly and politely. "Trolling" and other juvenile fun may be tolerated in small doses, however if you abuse this leniency you will be dealt with swiftly and severely. The user can expect a certain level of privacy. If a user violates the privacy of another user, they will be promptly banned. This extends to avatars as well. All avatars must be safe for work with no nudity and no graphic depictions of violence.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·TehConnection is staffed by a dedicated group of volunteers.[/color][/size]


[indent]Do not abuse the staff. They do this for the pure, unadulterated joy that comes with sharing their love of cinema and technology melded together in perfect harmony. Respect their opinions, if you disagree, do not immediately resort to slamming down on your caps lock key, instead try to calmly and rationally explain your side of the argument. There is a chance your rhetoric will persuade the staff to agree with you.[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]·You are allowed one account per lifetime.[/color][/size]


[indent]Your use of the site and of your account is not a right. You are not entitled to anything. Your account may be disabled at the staff's discretion with little or no warning. Users caught with multiple accounts will be immediately banned. If you are caught creating a new account after a previous account has been disabled for any reason this new account will be banned on sight. Sharing accounts is also prohibited, to avoid this, be aware of the strict limit of three (3) simultaneous IP addresses allowed per account.[/indent]

fields.title: Upload Description Guide
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]General[/b][/size][/color]

The goal of this guide is to describe the creation of an informative torrent description that is presented in an appealing way. You can edit your uploaded torrents by clicking on [ED] from the torrent's film group page.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]MediaInfo[/b][/size][/color]

Every x264 or Xvid torrent description must have an unaltered MediaInfo log added to the release description in the intended input box.

[indent][list=circle]
[*]Download [url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/en]MediaInfo[/url]... free, open-source and multi-platform.

[*]Install, when you start the program for the first time a small window will show. Click "OK".

[*]File -> Open -> Open file(s).

[*]Browse to the movie's directory and select the movie file.

[*]View -> Text

[*]Copy and then paste everything under MediaInfo Output. (You can edit the 'Complete Name' file path to remove any personal identifiers)
[/list][/indent]

If you need to add MediaInfo from a seedbox or similar, see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=69]this guide[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Comments/Notes[/b][/size][/color]

Any additional information that you want members to see when they look at your upload (e.g. "Hard coded English subtitles." or "Encoded from Criterion DVD" and so forth), should be centered at the top of the description, and italicized to draw attention to them.
[br /]
[indent][pre][center][i]**Add Your Comment Here**[/i][/center][/pre][/indent]

For hardcoded subtitles: [indent][pre][center][color=red][i]Hardcoded subtitles[/i][/color][/pre][/indent]
Should be placed first, on top everything else.

Notes can also be placed within a spoiler tag when they are either very long or not vital that users see them (additional technical details etc...).
[br /]
[indent][pre][spoiler=Notes]**Add Your Notes Here**[/spoiler][/pre][/indent]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Screenshots[/b][/size][/color]

Screenshots should be placed within spoiler tags, since this allows a user to choose whether they want to view them. Screenshots must be in the lossless .png format; lossy formats like .jpg are prohibited, as they misrepresent the actual appearance of the video. Screenshots must also be the same resolution as the video plays at.

[color=red]Do NOT use TDMaker.[/color]

[color=red]Do NOT use imgur for HD screenshots as they compress large images.[/color]

How to add thumbnail screenshots:

Upload your screens to an image host: [url=https://imgbox.com/]imgbox[/url] (remember to select "resized" thumbnails instead of the default "square" option), [url=https://www.imagebam.com/]ImageBam[/url] [/url] are all acceptable hosts...then copy/paste the BB-Code URLs generated.
[br /]
[indent][pre][center][spoiler=Screenshots]
*Paste image host BB-Code here*
[/spoiler][/center][/pre][/indent]

How to add 'Source vs. Encode' screenshots:

Upload screens to a gallery on an image host like SomeImage or Imagebam. Choose 250x250 pixel (Resize, Keep aspect ratio, Width). BBCode will be generated at the bottom of the page.
[br /]
[indent][pre][center][spoiler=Source vs. Encode]
*Paste image host BBCode here*
[/spoiler][/center] [/pre][/indent]

As a general rule of thumb when choosing thumbnail sizes:

[quote]
350 x 350 Keep aspect ratio -- this setting is good for solo screens
250 x 250 Keep aspect ratio -- this setting is ideal for source vs. encode screens; where you want the screens to appear side by side
150 x 150 Keep aspect ratio -- this setting is ideal for when you are comparing source vs. encode1 vs. encode2; where you want 3 screens to appear side by side
[/quote]

[color=#FF0000][b]Check upload after to make sure screens look good.[/b][/color]

[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]NFO Files[/b][/size][/color]

Short for 'information' and pronounced 'info', NFO is a file name extension used with text files which accompany a main file providing descriptions and meta-data. Used most commonly in the Warez Scene to mark files as originating from a particular release group. NFO files will often contain elaborate ASCII art along with info about the group and the particular release. These should be included, untouched, with any scene releases as they act as a calling card and give credit where credit is due while also providing important technical specifications about the release. NFO files can be opened with a text editor and the contents copied into the Release Description box in the upload form. Placing them in spoiler and pre tags will ensure the ASCII displays correctly while keeping the description neat.

How to add an NFO file:
[br /]
[indent][code][spoiler=NFO][pre]**Paste NFO contents here**[/pre][/spoiler][/code][/indent]

For an NFO file that has ASCII Art that is too wide to fit within a spoiler, use size=2
[br /]
[indent][code][spoiler=NFO][size=2][pre]**Paste NFO contents here**[/pre][/size][/spoiler][/code][/indent]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Sample, NFO & Screenshot Comparison Links[/b][/size][/color]

Often links are needed to be placed within a torrent description e.g. Sample Link, Full NFO Link and a [url=https://screenshotcomparison.com/]Screenshot Comparison[/url] link. A suggested format for presenting these links is this:
[br /]
[indent][code][center]| [url=**Link**][color=#FF045F]SCREENSHOT[/color][b][color=white]COMPARISON[/color][/b][/url] | [url=**Link**]NFO[/url] | [url=**Link**]SAMPLE[/url] |[/center][/code][/indent]


[center][i]A model example of a great release description.[/i]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/3Znjs.png[/img][/center]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DVDR Description[/b][/size][/color]

A DVDR is an exact replica of a DVD disc that can include all of the menus and extras from the retail disc and act as a source for an x264 encode in many cases. Raw MediaInfo output is not necessary for sources and the relevant information can be organized into a simple and neat form found [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=177]here[/url]. Please note that the site automatically adds this empty description template when you select DVDR as your upload type so you can fill in the details then or paste your own completed description over top of the template.

This information can be found by looking through the disc itself and using [url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/]MediaInfo[/url]. The size for a DVD5 is 4.37 GB or less, while for a DVD9 is more than 4.37 GB but usually less than 7.95 GB. If you can work out which edition of a film your DVDR came from then you may be able to find more information on sites like: [url=https://www.dvdbeaver.com/]https://www.dvdbeaver.com/[/url] or [url=https://www.dvdcompare.net/]https://www.dvdcompare.net/[/url].

How to determine the DVD format: [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=99]Guide to Anamorphic Widescreen DVDs[/url].
[br /]
[center][i]A model example of a great DVDR description.[/i]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/BD4Wk.png[/img][/center]


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Untouched Blu-ray/HD-DVD Description[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[indent][list=circle]
[*] Download & Install [url=https://www.videohelp.com/software/BDInfo]BDInfo[/url].
[*] Click the 'Browse' button and select the BD-ROM drive letter of your Blu-ray disc or mounted .ISO image. You may also select a folder containing a Blu-ray disc layout.
[*] Perform a full bitrate scan by clicking the 'Scan Bitrates' button. This operation can take a considerable amount of time!
[*] From the report screen, click the Copy to Clipboard to copy the report.
[*] Place the report within a pre tagged spoiler:
[br /]
[indent][code][spoiler=BDInfo][pre]**Paste BDInfo Report**[/pre][/spoiler][/code][/indent]

[*] From the report window, you may also choose to generate display charts of the video bitrate and frame size over time. Providing these are optional; if provided, however, treat them as you would screenshots, by placing them in a centered spoiler tag.
[/list][/indent]
[br /]
[center][i]A model example of a great Untouched Blu-Ray description.[/i]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/xSaE8.png[/img][/center]

fields.title: Guide to Anamorphic Widescreen DVD
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Overview[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[list=circle]
[*] The most common display aspect ratio standards are 1.33:1(4:3), used with VHS on 20[sup]th[/sup] century standard definition CRT televisions or 1.78:1 (16:9), used with modern high definition and widescreen LCD displays. 

[*] Standard aspect ratios for film are 1.85:1 or 2.35:1
[/list]

Common methods of conversion include:

[indent][list=circle]
[*] Enlarging the original image by the same factor in both directions to fill the display and cutting off any excess picture information. This is commonly known as 'zooming and cropping' or pan and scanning'.

[*] Adding horizontal mattes (letterboxing) or vertical mattes (pillarboxing) to retain the original film aspect ratio.

[*] Stretching the image to fill the display through scaling by different factors in both directions. This leads to distortion of the picture and should be avoided if at all possible.
[/list][/indent]

Unfortunately, DVDs became popular just prior to the switch from the older 4:3 display standard to the modern 16:9. This led to some confusion and multiple standards, especially with older DVD releases.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Anamorphic vs. Non-anamorphic[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
[indent][list=circle]
[*] Non-anamorphic (letterboxed) sources use hard-coded black bars to create frames that display a 4:3 picture. As the film's aspect ratio increases, more and more of the scan lines are devoted to the black letterbox bars at the top and bottom of the video frame instead of reproducing picture information. This reduces the amount of picture detail that can be displayed. Up to 33% of the data can be storing black pixels rather then actual video information.

[*] An anamorphic source has little to no hard coded black bars, and works stretching the image vertically to create the 4:3 aspect ratio instead. This data is digitally processed by the display device. A 4:3 display will combine horizontal rows and add letterboxing bars. A 16:9 display stretches the original square pixels into rectangles, restoring the original aspect ratio without loosing any resolution.

[*] Generally on a computer, the raw source will play in a window and only be adjusted when in fullscreen. If there are bars when viewed in a window, it is likely a non-anamorphic source.
[/list][/indent]
[br /]
[center]
[IMG]https://i.imgur.com/vt0Z3.png[/IMG]
[IMG]https://i.imgur.com/q86qr.png[/IMG]
[IMG]https://i.imgur.com/lZY9x.png[/IMG]
[/center]

fields.title: How to Generate Screenshots Using AvsP (Windows)
fields.body:
[i]Discuss or ask for help [url=https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=1316]here[/url].[/i]


This guide is designed to describe the process of generating screenshots that you can add any torrent description on TehConnection.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]DVDR Screenshots[/b][/size][/color]

You will need the following:
[br /]
[list=circle]
[*] [url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/AvsP]AvsP[/url]
[*] [url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/DGMPGDec]DGMPGDec DGIndex[/url]
[/list]

Instructions:
[br /]
[list=1]
[*] Demux the DVD with the DGIndex application and save the resulting .d2v file.
[*] Open the D2V file in AvsP and refresh the picture by clicking the arrow in the bottom left or tapping [b]F5[/b].
[*] For PAL 4:3 add the following below the MPEG2Source line: spline36resize(768,576)
[*] For PAL 16:9 add: spline36resize(1024,576)
[*] For NTSC 4:3 add: TFM().TDecimate() & spline36resize(640,480) (horizontal letterbox) or spline36resize(720,540) (vertical letterbox) on separate lines.
[*] For NTSC 16:9 add: TFM().TDecimate() & spline36resize(854,480) on separate lines.
[*] Choose an appropriate image to save and click [b]Video -> Save image as...[/b]
[/list]

Make sure that on the bottom of the window that pops up, you select the [b]Save as type:[/b] as [b]Portable Network Graphics (*.png)[/b]. Choose a location to save the file and change the name if you wish. Click save then rinse and repeat!. Generally three or four screenshots is plenty.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Encode Screenshots[/b][/size][/color]

You will need the following:
[br /]
[list=circle]
[*] [url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/AvsP]AvsP[/url]
[*] [url=https://code.google.com/p/ffmpegsource/downloads/list]ffms2[/url] (Download the one simply labeled [b]FFmpegSource 2.xx[/b] and put the ffms2.dll & FFMS2.avsi files in the AVISynth plugins folder, usually: C:\Program Files (x86)\AviSynth 2.5\plugins for most computers).
[/list]

Instructions:
[br /]
[list=1]
[*] Drag the AVI or MKV file into AvsP.
[*] Click the [b]Video[/b] tab up top then click [b]Refresh preview[/b] or tap F5.
[*] Use the bar on the bottom to scroll to a suitable image to use for your screenshot.
[*] Click on the [b]Video[/b] tab again then click [b]Save image as...[/b]
[/list]

Make sure that on the bottom of the window that pops up, you select the [b]Save as type:[/b] as [b]Portable Network Graphics (*.png)[/b]. Choose a location to save the file and change the name if you wish. Click save then rinse and repeat!. Generally three or four screenshots is plenty, especially when you're adding source vs. encode screenshots as well.

For taking screenshots of DVD x264 encodes (which have a aspect ratio modifier) paste this - https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=tdkFCZVK - into AVSP instead, change the name to the one you're taking screenshots of, and then follow steps 2-4.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Source vs. Encode Screenshots[/b][/size][/color]

You will need the following:
[br /]
[list=circle]
[*] [url=https://www.videohelp.com/tools/AvsP]AvsP[/url]
[*] [url=https://code.google.com/p/ffmpegsource/downloads/list]ffms2[/url] (Download the one simply labeled [b]FFmpegSource 2.xx[/b] and put the ffms2.dll & FFMS2.avsi files in the AVISynth plugins folder, usually: C:\Program Files (x86)\AviSynth 2.5\plugins for most computers).
[*] The AVS, D2V & VIDEO_TS source files you used while encoding.
[*] The MKV file generated during the encoding process.
[/list]

Instructions:
[br /]
[list=1]
[*] If using a DVD source, paste [url=https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=VSEBJ3h9]this code[/url] into an empty AvsP script page.
[*] If using a Blu-ray source, paste [url=https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=d5uvaUzB]this code[/url] into the AvsP script page instead.
[*] Replace [b]source.avs[/b] with the full path to your AVS file and [b]encode.mkv[/b] with the full path to your encoded file.
[*] Click [b]Video -> Refresh preview[/b] or tap [b]F5[/b]. This can take a moment to process.
[*] Choose a good frame with little blurring. Ensure it is a source frame (ffinfo will tag it as "source") and save the image; click [b]Video -> Save image as...[/b].
[*] Ensure the file type is set to [b]Portable Network Graphics (*.png)[/b] and click save.
[*] Next, press the right arrow key once to shift to the same frame from the encode and repeat the saving process. If using a blu-ray source, it is recommended to only use frames marked as 'B' (in the upper right corner) for the encode screenshots. It is also a good idea to save screenshots as [b]source#.png[/b] and [b]encode#.png[/b] where [b]#[/b] is a different number for each set being compared. This makes it easy to remember which images are which and makes uploading easier as well.
[*] Now all you need to do is upload these images to your favourite image host. We recommend [url=https://screenshotcomparison.com/]Screenshot Comparison[/url], [url=https://www.imagebam.com/]ImageBam[/url], [url=https://imgbox.com/]ImgBox[/url] or [url=https://imageshack.us/]ImageShack[/url] as hosts which will not resize high definition images.
[/list]

The script takes your source file and the encoded file and interleaves them together displaying each frame of the video stream twice. The ffinfo option displays various technical information about each frame and spline36resize is used to display the video at the correct aspect ratio to enable accurate screenshots.


[i]Many thanks to Otra, OnkelLars, guccimane for various info that forms part of this guide.[/i]

fields.title: Quality Encode Label
fields.body:
In an effort to ensure that even the most casual user is able to know for a fact that the file they are about to download is of the highest quality possible, TehConnection uses a feature to promote high quality encodes that meet minimum encoding standards. This system informs the user that the file contains video quality as close to the source as possible.

You will notice a small green check mark next to torrent listings.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/scTJAju.png[/img][/center]

This check mark tells you that the encode contained within is of a superior quality, one befitting of TehConnection. This does not mean that encodes without a check mark are unwatchable. It is simply a way for users who are not familiar with reading Mediainfo logs to be sure that what they are downloading is considered excellent quality.

The [url=https://tehconnection.eu/logchecker.php]logchecker[/url] allows encoders test to see if their uploads will automatically receive the green check of approval or not and allow them to make any corrections. As always every source is different and under special circumstances staff can manually approve torrents as "high-quality" even if they do not pass the standards test.

The minimum quality encode settings are:


[quote=Quality Checker]
[b]All Encodes[/b]
Audio Codec: 
  AC-3, DTS, or FLAC

[b]Encoding Settings[/b]
   cabac = 1
   mixed_ref = 1
   analyse = 0x3:0x133 or 0x3:0x113
   subme = 9, 10, or 11
   trellis = 2
   me = umh, esa or tesa
   rc = crf or 2pass


[b]SD Specific Encoding Settings[/b]
   bframes >= 5
   ref >= 9
   me_range >= 24 [ignored if me = tesa]

[b]720p Specific Encoding Settings[/b]
   bframes >= 5
   ref >= 9
   me_range >= 16

[b]1080p Specific Encoding Settings[/b]
   bframes >= 3
   ref between 4 and 6
  me_range >= 16
  bitrate > 8000
[/quote]

fields.title: IRC Network Information
fields.body:
TehConnection runs its own IRC chat server and we're always happy to have new members join. This page details all the information you'll need to connect to the server.

If you're looking for assistance with configuring your client we have guides available for [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=15]xchat[/url], [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=14]mIRC[/url], [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=13]Colloquy[/url], [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=165]Textual[/url] & [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=133]irssi[/url]. We also have a guide on configuring [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=158]ZNC[/url], an IRC bouncer.
[br /]

irc.tehconnection.eu

109.201.135.155
