29. Click "Finish"

Now the virtual machine will start to boot up. Simply wait... (This may take up to 5 minutes.)

30. One or more new dialogs may come up saying "VirtualBox Information", just click "Do not show this message again" and click "Ok"

After a few minutes, the booting will finish and you will be looking at the desktop for your firewall virtual machine. To the right of the window you will see some stats that look something like this:

Up: 0 k/s - Down: 0 k/s
Processes: 19
CPU Usage: 10%
RAM Usage: 16.2MB/28.8MB

etc.

Congratulations! You now have a firewall running. Now we will set up this firewall to protect you so that you can safely use TOR from your main virtual machine.
 
Next:10. Firewall Configuration ===
=== 10. Firewall Configuration ===

At this stage you should be looking at the desktop for "DSL" (Damn Small Linux). 

I need to talk about the mouse first. This particular virtual machine as well as your main operating system (windows) both want control of your mouse. Both cannot have control of your mouse at the same time however. Therefore, you have to choose whether the mouse will be used by your virtual machine, or by Windows. When you click into your virtual machine, it has the effect of passing control of the mouse to the virtual machine. That means you cannot move your mouse cursor past the boundaries of that virtual machine. In order to give mouse control back to windows, enabling you to move your mouse cursor anywhere, simply press the right ctrl key on your keyboard. That is to say, you have two ctrl keys. One on the left of your keyboard, and one on the right. Press the ctrl key that is on the right of your keyboard. This will give mouse control back to windows.

Practice this a bit. Practice clicking into the window, moving the mouse cursor around, pressing right ctrl, and moving the windows mouse cursor around. Get the feel of it.

You should see a window that looks something like a web browser, with some text in it including words such as "Getting Started with DSL". First, close that window.

(If your mouse is not working, read this mini-section.)

(First, click inside the window that your virtual machine is running in). Now try moving your mouse cursor. If you do not see the mouse cursor moving around, then press (RIGHT CTRL + I). Now move your mouse cursor again. If you notice that you are moving your "main" mouse cursor over the window, but you do not see the "DSL" black mouse cursor moving, then click again into that window. If you do this a few times, you should notice that the mouse begins to work. You may have to press RIGHT CTRL+I a couple of times to get the mouse to work.

1. Once the mouse is working inside of your virtual machine, go ahead and close the window entitled "Getting Started with DSL"

(If you cannot see the full virtual machine window, for example because your screen resolution is set so that some of the window goes too low, read this mini-section).

(First, press RIGHT CTRL+I until you have your main windows white mouse cursor back). Now, click on "Machine" in the menu at the top of the window.
(Select "Switch to Scale Mode")

( Click "Switch")

(Now you will have converted your firewall window to a smaller size, and you will be able to resize it. You may need to press "right ctrl" to get a windows mouse cursor (which you will need in order to resize this window). Now simply resize it to the size that works for you, and then click into the window to be able to use the black mouse cursor inside the virtual machine. I recommend you maximize this window to make sure you can read everything clearly.

2. Right click anywhere on the desktop, go to System (a red folder), go to Daemons, ssh, and start. 

3. Right click again anywhere on the desktop, go to XShells -> Root Access -> Transparent

4. Now you have a window that you can type in. Type exactly as shown below into this window, and hit enter:

passwd

Once you type this and hit enter, it will ask you for a password. This is a password for full access to the firewall. Make it at least 8 characters in size.

*** IMPORTANT: Do not forget your firewall password. You will need it later in the guide. ***

When you have successfully changed your password, it will say "Password changed."

5. Now type exactly as shown below, into the same window:

ifconfig eth1 10.0.3.1

6. It will not say anything after you hit enter, it will just return you back to the prompt. 

Now our firewall server is ready. We want to save this state so that we can get back to it easy in the future.
Press RIGHT CTRL+S

7. Now you will be looking at a window that says "Take Snapshot of Virtual Machine". Just click "Ok"

8. Now, let's test this out to confirm it works as we expect. Go ahead and close the virtual machine by clicking the "X" in the top right corner. A menu will come up. Select "Power off the machine" and click ok. Do NOT check the box called "Restore current snapshot".

And now you should be once again at the VirtualBox manager. You will see "Firewall (Shapshot 1), Powered Off"

9. Make sure that "Firewall (Snapshot 1), Powered Off" is selected. At the top right of your VirtualBox Manager is a button that says: "Snapshots (1)". Click it.

10. Click on "Snapshot 1", the top-most selection. This will highlight it.

11. Now right click it, and click on "Restore Snapshot"

12. A dialog box will come up asking if you are sure, click "Restore"

13. Now click the "Start" button at the top with the large green arrow.

14. Any dialog boxes that come up with a check box saying "Do not show this information again", simply check the check-box, and click ok. Do not worry about any of those.

Remember, if you do not have immediate control of the mouse inside the virtual machine, simply press RCTRL+I (press right ctrl and "I" at the same time) and click into it until you have mouse control. 

Now your firewall is good to go. Any time you need it, just go to the VirtualBox Manager and follow steps 9 through 14 above. You do not have to go through the whole setup process again at any time in the future. Your firewall is ready.

Next:11. Installing Ubuntu ===











=== 11. Installing Ubuntu ===

Now we are going to set up the main machine that you will be using TOR with. 

1. First, go to this URL: https://www.ubuntu.com

2. Click on the link "Download Ubuntu"

3. Click "Start Download" (This download should take 10-15 minutes)

4. The filename is going to be similar to: ubuntu-10.10-desktop-i386.iso

Now we wait... 

While you are waiting for the file to download, go ahead and make sure that your "hidden volume" is mounted in TrueCrypt to a particular drive letter. For example, O: You will need that for the next step.

5. Return to your "VirtualBox Manager". It doesn't matter if the firewall is running or not.

6. Click "New" (the blue round star-icon in the top left) again.

7. "Welcome to the New VirtualMachine Wizard", click "Next"

8. "VM Name and OS Type", under "Name", type "Primary"

9. Next to "Operating System", select "Linux"

10. Next to "Version", select "Ubuntu" and Click "Next"

11. "Memory", by default it selects 512 MB. This is fine. 256 MB is the MINIMUM. The more memory you allocate, the better the virtual machine will function. Click "Next"

12. "Virtual Hard Disk", Make sure "Boot Hard Disk" is checked. Make sure "Create new hard disk" is selected. Click "Next"

13. "Welcome to the Create New Virtual Disk Wizard", click "Next"

14. "Hard Disk Storage Type", select "Fixed-size storage" and click "Next"

15. "Virtual Disk Location and Size", to the right of the text box containing "Primary" is a folder icon. Click the folder icon.

16. Now we have to select a file for the new hard disk image file. On the bottom of this dialog it says "Browse Folders", click on that. 

17. Now click on "Computer" in the menu to the left. 

18. Scroll to where you see the drive letter you mounted, and double click on it. Ex: Local Disk (O:) 

19. Now click "Save"

20. By default 8.00 GB are selected. That is fine. If you have enough space on your hidden volume, increase this to 10 GB. Otherwise, 8 is fine.

21. Under "Location", it should say O:Primary.vdi where O: is replaced by whatever drive letter you mounted your TrueCrypt hidden volume to.

22. Click "Next", then click "Finish"

Now we wait for VirtualBox to create the hard drive we asked for. This may take a few minutes.

Keep in mind this entire virtual machine as well as any of its contents are going to reside within the hidden truecrypt container. This ensures extra security.

23. When this is done, you will see a "Summary" window. Click "Finish".

24. Now, right click on "Primary, Powered Off" in your "VirtualBox Manager", and click "Start"

25. Again we are at the "First Run Wizard", click "Next"

26. "Select Installation Media", under "Media Source" is a pull down menu. Click the "folder icon" to the immediate right of that pulldown menu.

27. Locate "ubuntu-10.10-desktop-i386" (or the similarly named file) from your Downloads directory, or wherever you saved it. Click on it, and click "Open"

28. Click "Next"

29. Click "Finish"

Now simply wait. Your Ubuntu virtual machine will be loading up. This may take a few minutes. Don't worry if you see all kinds of strange messages/text. It is normal.

After a few minutes, you should start to see the Ubuntu desktop load. Unlike your firewall, you will notice that you do not have to click the mouse inside the window. It automatically happens. This is going to be much easier than the "Firewall" step.

Once everything has loaded, you will be looking at a window that says "Install" with a button that says "Install Ubuntu". If you cannot see everything, press RCTRL+F (to go full screen). You can return to windowed mode by RCTRL+F again. Any dialogs can be closed, and you can check the box that says "Do not show me this again."

30. Click "Install Ubuntu"

31. Check "Download updates while installing"

32. Check "Install this third-party software". Click "Forward"

33. Ensure "Erase and use entire disk" is selected, and click "Forward". Remember, this is NOT talking about your hard disk. It is talking about the 8-10 gigabyte virtual disk.

34. Click "Install Now"

35. Now you will be guided through a series of installation related screens. The first screen asks you to select your timezone/time. Select your choice and click "Forward"

36. Now keyboard layout, again select your choice and click Forward. If you are unsure, leave it as is or click "Figure out keyboard layout"

37. "Who are you?" For "Your name" type in: mainuser

38. When you type in "mainuser" the other boxes will fill in automatically. Now click in the text box next to "Choose a password".

39. Do NOT use the same password as the firewall. Come up with a different password.

40. Ensure that "Require my password to log in" as well as "Encrypt my home folder" are selected and checked and proceed.

Now simply wait until the installation is finished. The installation may take a while, and it may appear to stall at some points. As long as the ubuntu mouse cursor shows an animation that is turning around in circles, the installation *is* working. Simply wait until it is done. If after an hour or two the progress bar hasn't moved at all, then go ahead and re-start the installation starting from step 24 (after closing the window and powering down the virtual machine). 

Depending on your computer, it could take 2-4 hours. Most likely, it will take about an hour. Once finished, you will see a dialog that says "Installation Complete" with a button that says "Reboot Now". Do NOT press the "Reboot Now" button. Close the 'X' on this window, and Power Down.

41. Now, right click "Primary" and go to "Settings".

42. Click on "Storage" in the left menu. Then click on the "ubuntu-10.10... .iso" under where it says "IDE Controller"

43. To the right it says "Attributes" under that it says "CD/DVD Drive : ..." to the immediate right of that is a cd icon. Click it.

44. Select "Remove disk from virtual drive."

45. Click "Ok"

46. Now, making sure that "Primary" is highlighted, click the "Start" button at the top with the large green arrow.

Now we wait for your newly installed Ubuntu machine to boot up.

47. After a few minutes, you will see a dialog appear that says "mainuser-VirtualBox". Go ahead and click on "mainuser" which has the "person icon" to the left of it.

48. Now it will prompt you for your password. Enter the password you used in the installation process.

49. After a minute or so, you should hear a nice login sound, and you should be fully logged into your virtualmachine.

50. Keep waiting, and a dialog will appear that says "Information avialable" and "Record your encryption passphrase" Click on: "Run this action now"

51. Type in the same password you used to log in. After that window closes, click "Close" in the dialog box.

Congratulations! You have now set up a virtual machine as well as a firewall to protect it. Now we need to finish configuring the primary virtual machine.
 
Next:12. Ubuntu Initial Setup ===
=== 12. Ubuntu Initial Setup ===

Ok, now that we have installed Ubuntu, we need to set it up so that we can use it fully. This also means making sure we can see flash on websites such as youtube. 

1. First, we have to install any updates that are pending. At the bottom of your screen, you should notice where it says "Update Manager". Click on that. 

2. Now, click on "Install Updates". If you did not see "Update Manager", then skip these two steps.

3. Any time an administrative task is required, you will need to type in your password. This is the same password you used to log in.

Now we wait, this is going to download any necessary security updates to make certain we are using the most current/secure setup possible. This may require downloading hundreds of megabytes. Just go ahead and let it do that, and when everything is downloaded and updated, proceed to the next step. While you wait, Ubuntu may go into screensaver mode. If so, just move the mouse and it will ask you for your password. That will leave screensaver mode.

If the updates are more than a hundred megabytes, it will take quite a while. It may take up to 2-3 hours depending on your computer and internet connection. Nonetheless, this step is critical. Do not skip the updates. Besides ensuring that your setup will be secure, the updates also ensure that all of the applications are up to date and thus most likely to function correctly. Just go ahead and watch a movie for a couple hours, and then return and check on it. 

After all of the updates have been downloaded and installed, the "Update Manager" window will now say "Your system is up-to-date" at the top. Further, it will say: "The computer needs to restart to finish installing updates.". Go ahead and press the 'X' in the top right corner of the window, and choose 'Send the shutdown signal". If prompted, click "Shut Down". Once it has fully shut down, the window will disappear and you will be back at the VirtualBox manager. Go ahead and right click on "Primary" and click "Start". This will restart the virtual machine.

If a virtual machine fails to shutdown after 10 minutes or so, then go ahead and close the window again by pressing the 'X' but this time choose "Power down". If it still will not shut down, then VirtualBox may have crashed. If so, just follow these instructions:

( Follow the steps in this mini-section if a virtual machine fails to shutdown, or you need to completely close/restart VirtualBox).

( First, press "Ctrl+Alt+Delete", and then click "Task Manager"). Next, locate the process that is running that starts with "VirtualBox". Right click that process, and click "End Process Tree"
(This should force the window to close).

(Now, restart VirtualBox by going to your start menu, All Programs, Oracle VM VirtualBox VirtualBOx).

Now you will have the VirtualBox manager up again. To restart the Ubuntu machine, simply right click on "Primary" and click "Start". 

Once your Primary vm has rebooted, you will be again at the login screen. Here as before, click on "mainuser" and then enter in your password. Now your primary machine is fully up to date. Remember, be patient. It may take a few minutes before your virtual machine has fully booted. First you will see the background image and a mouse cursor that can move around, next you should hear the login sound play, and finally you will see the menu at the top and bottom of your virtual machine window. Depending on the speed of your computer, this may take 10 minutes or more. Just be patient. Don't worry if your virtual machine appears to be running too slow, we will speed it up.

Now your Virtual Machine is set up and ready for use.

Next:13. Installing Guest Additions ===

















=== 13. Installing Guest Additions ===

In order to ensure that the Virtual Machine runs smoothly as possible, we are going to install some additional software to the virtual machine. 

1. Go to the "Devices" menu at the top of your virtual machine main window (Machine, Devices, Help), and go to "Install Guest Additions"

2. Go to the "Places" menu at the top of your virtual machine (Applications, Places, System), and click on "VBOXADDITIONS_4.0.4_70112" (the number may be different).

3. At the top this new window will be the text "The media has been determined as "UNIX software". Click on "Open Autorun Prompt"

4. A new dialog may appear saying "This medium contains software intended to be automatically started. Would you like to run it?" Click "Run"

5. Enter your administrative password (the one you use to log into Ubuntu) and click "Ok"

6. Now the VirtualBox Guest Additions installer will begin. This may take some time, so just relax and wait. Depending on your computer, this may take 30 minutes or more.

7. When this is finished, you will see the text "Press Return to close this window." Go ahead and do so.

8. Once that window has closed, go ahead and press the 'X' to close the entire virtual machine window. Select "Send the shutdown signal" and click "Ok".

9. A dialog box will appear. Click on "Shut Down", the top most option.

At this stage it is a good idea to further optimise our virtual machine. When you initially installed it, you most likely selected either 256 MB or 512 MB of RAM. If you have enough RAM to spare, then I highly recommend you increase that to at least 1 GB. Here is how to do so:

1. First, right click on "Primary, Powered off" and go to Settings.

2. Select "System" from the menu on the left.

3. Increase the "Base Memory" to either 1024 MB (1 GB), or some higher value you are comfortable with.

It is also a good idea to increase the video memory available to the virtual machine. 

4. Select "Display" from the menu on the left, still inside of "Settings"

5. Increase the "Video Memory" slider to the right as far as you are comfortable with. For example, 128 MB.

6. Check the box "Enable 3D Acceleration".

7. Now click "Ok" at the bottom.

Go ahead and start up Ubuntu again by right clicking "Primary, Powered off" and clicking "Start"

When Ubuntu loads up, go ahead and log in as before using your password. Now wait until Ubuntu is fully booted and the "Applications Places System" menu is visible.

You will probably notice that your virtual machine loads up and runs faster than before.

How well your virtual machine runs depends on how good your computer is. Primarily, RAM and processor speed are the most significant factors. If your computer is modern enough, you should be able to use websites with flash and even watch videos, such as on YouTube, with no problem. If your computer is not as modern, you will still be able to browse websites but may not be able to watch videos. You should still be able to use most flash based websites however.

*** IMPORTANT: Do NOT browse sensitive content YET. At this stage, your virtual machine is not yet configured to use TOR. ***

Next:14. Installing IRC (Optional) ===



















=== 14. Installing IRC (Optional) ===

*** This section is entirely optional. If you are not interested in installing IRC, skip this section. ***

To install IRC on your new virtual machine, follow these steps:

1. Go to the "Applications" menu, and go to "Ubuntu Software Center"

2. Type "kvirc" in the search box field in the top right.

3. When the results return, select the one called: "KDE-based next generation IRC client" or "KV Irc".

4. Click "Install"

5. Enter your password when prompted.

6. While it installs, you will notice a progress bar. This may take a few minutes depending on the speed of your internet connection.

7. Once it is finished installing, the progress bar will go away. Go ahead and close the "Ubuntu Software

fields.title: Cinavia Protection
fields.body:
[url=https://www.cinavia.com/]Cinavia[/url] ([url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinavia]Wikipedia[/url]) copyright protection is a form of uncracked copyright digital rights management (DRM).

Cinavia affects a small number of home theatre playback devices of which the most commonly used is the Playstation 3. Cinavia is not detected in a DTS audio track when using the optical output.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]How Does Cinavia Work?[/b][/size][/color]

Cinavia works in two parts, an audio watermark and watermark detection capable hardware such as the Playstation or many newer Blu-ray players. The copy protection cannot work without both parts being present which is why certain films will not play while others will.

The audio watermark is part of the analog audio stream and is imperceptible to humans. This means that it survives being recorded on a microphone (such as CAM & Screener encodes) as well as surviving compression and re-encoding such as ripping a DVD.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Examples[/b][/size][/color]
[list=circle]
[*] A movie copy made with a camcorder in a theater that contains Cinavia (THEATRICAL_NO_HOME_USE) watermark will stop playing within about 1 minute on a Playstation 3 and display a Message 1.

[*] An unprotected (no AACS) Blu-ray backup of “The Losers” (US release) will mute the audio after about 20 minutes with Message 3 (for not coming from a TRUSTED_SOURCE).

The developers of DVDFab have compiled a list of all films which contain Cinavia protection [url=https://blog.dvdfab.cn/cinavia-protection.html]here[/url].

fields.title: A Guide to Uploading at TC
fields.body:
Planning your first upload to TehConnection? Or did you just notice in the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/log.php?search=]Log[/url], that our DoTs always edit your uploads and wonder why?  Well, get familiar with our [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=88]rules[/url], read through this step-by-step guide, and you'll be on your way to the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/top10.php?type=users&details=numul]Top 10[/url] before you know it!

Let's take a look at the [url=https://tehconnection.eu/upload.php]upload page[/url]:


[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/OIZtp.jpg[/img][/center]

[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]1. The "Do Not Upload" List[/b][/size][/color]

This list shows the currently not allowed content. If it's on this list, do not upload it. Read it carefully and also keep in mind, that this list might be updated in the future. If you are unsure if your proposed upload is covered by this list check with staff FIRST.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]2. Your Personal Announce URL[/b][/size][/color]

Each member has an individual announce url, which is important to identify you, even if you seed from different IP's. Copy/Paste this url into your torrent client, if you create a new torrent. For further information on how to create a torrent, see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=16]here[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]3. Torrent File[/b][/size][/color]

Here you have to place the torrent file. Make sure to check the "Private Torrent" box and also to include your personal tracker announce url, while creating the torrent. Again for further information see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=16]here[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]4. Main Genre[/b][/size][/color]

The best source to find the appropriate genre for a movie is [url=https://www.imdb.com]IMDb[/url], but keep in mind, that not always the first listed genre would be considered as the main genre. So read a synopsis of the movie first, if you're unsure.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]5. Genres[/b][/size][/color]

Add all genres listed on IMDb here, including the previously chosen main genre. IMDb lists only up to 3 genres at the top, so scroll down below the actors to see, if there are more genres available. We also use a few genres different to IMDb, like Foreign for movies with the main language other than English or also Anime, Indie, Political or Stand-Up. You can add them and maybe other genres, which are appropriate, but not listed on IMDb, yourself.



[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/vyIEi.jpg[/img][/center]

[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]6. The IMDb Number[/b][/size][/color]

Here you either have to place the IMDb ID, which you can see in the IMDb url, preceded by "tt" (e.g. 0118799) or the complete url. This is mandatory, since it's necessary for our site features to work properly.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]7. Fetch from IMDb[/b][/size][/color]

After you have entered the IMDb number, fetch the data from IMDb. This will automatically fetch the Film Title, Year and also add a short synopsis to the Film Description. Be careful, if you add a new format to an already existing movie group, since fetching would overwrite the existing information in such a case.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]8. Torrent Without an IMDb Number[/b][/size][/color]

This rarely happens. Almost all allowed content should have an IMDb ID. Only uncheck this, if you're absolutely sure, that this movie is not listed on IMDb. You can always PM a DoT or MOD or ask via Staff PM, if you can't find your movie on IMDb.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]9. Poster Image[/b][/size][/color]

Here you have to place the poster url. Never just copy/paste a link from another site like Wikipedia or IMDb for instance. Always rehost the poster to an imagehost, which allows hotlinking. Our recommendation: [url=www.imgur.com]Imgur[/url].
The Poster image must have a width greater than 238 pixels and the film poster should always be used instead of DVD covers. For foreign movies a poster in the original language is preferred.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]10. Film Title[/b][/size][/color]

The Film title gets auto fetched from IMDb, so usually you don't have to do anything here. One exception would apply to foreign movies, where you should add the original film title to the auto fetched English title like this: La vita è bella (aka The Life is Beautiful).


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]11. Year[/b][/size][/color]

Auto fetched from IMDb, so you don't have to change or add the original release date of the film yourself.



[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/cLCHX.jpg[/img][/center]

[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]12. Format[/b][/size][/color]

The Format drop down menu provides a list of allowed codecs/formats. If you're unsure which one to choose, read our wiki article about [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=122]CODECs & Containers[/url] or check the MediaInfo of your file. You can find a guide about how to use MediaInfo [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=69]here[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]13. Container[/b][/size][/color]

The Container menu shows the allowed containers. For encodes choose the one which corresponds with the file extension of your movie (Matroska = MKV). For untouched sources choose the appropriate one. Again the wiki article about [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=122]CODECs & Containers[/url] might be helpful.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]14. Resolution[/b][/size][/color]

Here you have to choose the resolution of your movie. Encodes very often include the resolution in their file or folder name, but you can also check the MediaInfo and compare the displayed resolution with our wiki article about [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=179]Video Resolutions[/url].


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]15. Source Media[/b][/size][/color]

For untouched sources, well... choose the source. For encodes choose the original source, which is also very often provided in the file or folder name.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]16. Film Description[/b][/size][/color]

This should provide a short synopsis of the movie. Usually our auto fetcher already places a shortened description from IMDb here, but you could replace this with a better one. We recommend to use [url=https://www.allmovie.com/]AllMovie[/url] as source, since they almost always provide a better and more comprehensive description than IMDb.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]17. MediaInfo Output[/b][/size][/color]

For encodes it is mandatory to provide a full [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=69]MediaInfo[/url] output. You're allowed to delete the folder structure, which is displayed in "Complete Name", for privacy reasons. Just make sure, that at least for releases, where the file name differs from the folder name, the folder name is still included (e.g. Scene releases with cryptic names). Other than that, you're not allowed to alter the MediaInfo in any way. 


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]18. Release Description[/b][/size][/color]

Here you should place the NFO file, screenshots and additional information, which might be interesting, like added external subs, a comment by the encoder etc. Make sure you use spoiler tags for the NFO and screenshots for proper display. You can use an editor to prepare your description, but don't copy the NFO file into a txt document, since this would alter the file. So copy the NFO file directly into the upload form instead. For more information how to make a sexy release description check out [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=98]this guide[/url].



[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/qwLE2.jpg[/img][/center]

[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]19. Special Edition[/b][/size][/color]

Check this box for Special Editions, which differ from the original release. Do not check this box for a theatrical release.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]20. Year (of the Special Edition)[/b][/size][/color]

This should provide the year, when the Special Edition was first released. As a side note: The release date for e.g. a Director's Cut might differ for DVD and Blu-Ray in some cases, although it's actually the same cut. That's just because they are not always first released in the same year.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]21. Title (of the Special Edition)[/b][/size][/color]

Here you should place titles like Director's Cut, Extended, Uncut, Unrated, 3D etc. Special releases (e.g. Criterion Collection), which do not differ from the original cut, should only be noted here for untouched sources and never for encodes.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]22. Scene[/b][/size][/color]

Check this box only for Scene releases. If you're not sure, if it's a Scene release, you can search for the group on our [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=147]wiki list[/url] and check one of the pre databases like [url=https://pre.corrupt-net.org/]pre.corrupt-net[/url] or [url=https://www.orlydb.com/]ORLYDB[/url] for instance. If you can't find your group/release in any of these, it's most likely not a Scene release.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]23. Scene (Additional Information)[/b][/size][/color]

Here you should place additional information related to the Scene release like Proper, Repack, Rerip etc. Usually you can see this information in the file or folder name of the release. Do not enter any information about a Special Edition (e.g. Director's Cut) here.


[color=#4682b4][size=4][b]24. Upload Torrent[/b][/size][/color]

Everything looks good and double-checked? Then now you actually just have to hit the upload button and seed for eternity! :D


P.S.: We all started somewhere, so if there are still questions, don't hesitate to PM a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staff.php]DoT[/url] or ask via [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url] for assistance.

fields.title: How to Connect to TehConnection's IRC Network (Textual)
fields.body:
In order to connect to more than #TehConnection, you'll need an IRC client. [url=https://codeux.com/textual/]Textual[/url] is an OS X client which is very popular.

[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Installing Textual[/b][/size][/color]

As with almost all OS X software, after downloading it add it to your [b]Applications[/b] folder to install it.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Configuring Textual[/b][/size][/color]

After installing Textual start it and you will see a window pop up. Click cancel at this initial window then click "Add Server ..." so we can configure your client before we connect.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/b1E07.png[/img][/center]

Configure the window that pops up as shown below. We recommend connecting with SSL but if you choose not to then uncheck the SSL box and change the port to 6667. Leave the password field blank.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/S5DrD.png[/img][/center]

Next, select the Identity tab and fill the fields you see here. Nickname should generally be your site nick but does not necessarily need to be.

Alternatives are for in case your nick is in use already. Usually an underscore is fine.

NickServ Auth is a password to identify you as you to the IRC server. It is a password just for IRC and should under no circumstances be the same as your site password. The good news here is that you can set it and forget it as Textual will automatically send it to the IRC server every time you connect. Chose any password now and we'll configure it with NickServ later.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/o3Inf.png[/img][/center]

After Identity select the Messages tab. Here you are able to give messages you would like Textual to relay to your IRC network(s) when you quit or if your PC goes to sleep.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/Be6eI.png[/img][/center]

Select the Autojoin tab next and click the plus symbol to add a new channel to automatically join.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/3wWMT.png[/img][/center]

You can see a list of channels available to you in your profile. Add as many as you would like to join. You can optionally disable highlights and join/part messages here too.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/phADy.png[/img][/center]

Now select the Connect Commands tab and enter your connect command as described in the image. The text "sitenick" should be the nick you use on TehConnection and the text "irc_key" should be the IRC key set in your profile.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/T80oy.png[/img][/center]

Now click Save to save your settings.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/QCcnr.png[/img][/center]

Right click on the server and click Connect to have Textual connect to TehConnection and begin your chat session.
[br /]
[center][img]https://i.imgur.com/1HyhI.png[/img][/center]


For detailed IRC Network Information and channels available see [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=104]here[/url].

fields.title: Changing your Passkey
fields.body:
Your passkey is a unique identifier that is embedded in the url that your torrent client uses when it sends messages to the site. In this way you are identified (across ip addresses) and your upload and download counted. If other people know your passkey then they can spoof being you. This could result in your account getting associated with rule breaking. So you should not share your .torrent files  or your announce url.

But we are all human. Sometimes you paste your announce url in the wrong place, the reset passkey function is so that you can change your identifying info and stop any leaked url or torrent files from working or identifying with you. Unfortunately this means you have to change all the torrents in your client. Here is an easy way to do it in utorrent:


[indent]
[list=1]
[*] Select all your tehconnection torrents.
[*] Stop them all.
[*] Reset your passkey by editing your profile.
[*] Right click on the selected torrents in utorrentt, and select 'Properties'.
[*] Remove the old tracker url and replace it with your new one (find it on the upload page).
[/list]
[/indent]


This will work much the same way in deluge, transmission and the like. For rtorrent/rutorrent even with the edit torrent rutorrent plugin, this method will not (currently) work. Instead you can use [url=https://code.google.com/p/pyroscope/]pyroscope[/url] from the command line:


[indent]
[list=1]
[*] Stop rtorrent
[*] Make a backup of your *.torrent files (tar cvfz /tmp/metafiles.tgz ./.session ./watch or similar)
[*] Reset your passkey by editing your profile.
[*] chtor -a https://tehconnection..eu:2790/newpasskey/announce watch/*.torrent .session/*.torrent
[*] Restart rtorrent
[/list]
[/indent]


This will automatically only replace the url in tehconnection torrents.

fields.title: Ripping WEB-DL From iTunes Using Requiem
fields.body:
[b]This guide will now work for 1080p and rental titles![/b]

Discuss this article here: https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=5390

Pastebin of the Requiem README: https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=Jm7GkTUV

[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Software Needed[/b][/size][/color]

1. iTunes - To buy and download your Apple products (Versions 10.6.x and 10.7 with the newest Requiem)
2. Requiem - To remove the Apple DRM


[indent]Note: You may need the version of Requiem appropriate for when you downloaded your content, rather than the newest version.


Dropbox links for Requiem 4.1 (as Tor can be unreliable and slow) : [url=https://dl.dropbox.com/u/82224087/requiem-4.0.1-win.zip]Windows[/url], [url=https://dl.dropbox.com/u/82224087/requiem-4.0.1-mac.zip]OSX[/url], [url=https://dl.dropbox.com/u/82224087/requiem-4.0.1-src.zip
]Source[/url][/indent]


3. [url=https://mediainfo.sourceforge.net/en/Download]MediaInfo[/url] - It offers information about the video file
4. [url=https://www.bunkus.org/videotools/mkvtoolnix/downloads.html]MKVmerge[/url] - For remuxing the decrypted file and stripping it of your user information
5. [url=https://www.java.com/en/download/manual.jsp]Java[/url] - Java is java

[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Working Method[/b][/size][/color]

[b]1[/b]. Install iTunes and disable automatic updates. (When a new version of iTunes comes out, don't update until you check to see if Requiem is updated to support that new version)

[b]2[/b]. Unzip Requiem on your HDD.

[b]3[/b]. Install Java.

[b]4[/b]. Buy, download your episodes and close iTunes. Requiem will not work with iTunes on.

[b]5[/b]. Start Requiem and watch it work. It will automatically find DRMed files in your iTunes library and remove the DRM from them. The original DRMed files will be moved to the trash.  Make sure you verify that the songs and videos still work before emptying the trash.

You can also drag & drop files or directories (which will be searched recursively) onto the Requiem application or the Requiem window.

Starting Requiem with the shift key down will disable scanning of the iTunes library. You can use this feature to start requiem with a blank window into which you can drag & drop files to be processed.

Note: There is no progress bar so be patient. (You can check for .tmp files if you are unsure of progress.)


[b]6[/b]. Install MediaInfo (or you can use the portable version). Open MediaInfo and load your decrypted *.m4v to see what audio tracks you have. If you are a more advanced user you don't need to do that, you'll recognize them in mkvmerge.

[b]7[/b]. Install MKVmerge (or you can use the portable version).

[b]8[/b]. Load your decrypted *.m4v file in MKVmerge, set the language for video and audio track, choose the destination folder and press "Start muxing". Remove AAC2.0 if it has both AC-3 DD5.1 and AAC2.0. If you are keen on keeping AAC2.0 too, at least move it to the second position.




[i]Thanks to corleone on BTN for most of this guide![/i]

fields.title: Build a Linux HTPC Seedbox
fields.body:
[center][color=red][b]This is a work in progress.  Please contact me on site or over IRC with suggestions or comments. --hwkns[/b][/color][/center]

[b][size=5]1. What You Will Need[/size][/b]
[indent][list]
[*]A nice TV with HDMI input, and a decent audio system (obviously).
[*]A decent power supply (I recommend [url=https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817151094]SeaSonic[/url]).
[*]A low-end CPU.  Seriously.  You will not need a good one, I promise.
[*]A motherboard that's compatible with your chosen CPU, and has enough SATA ports for all your drives.
[*]A case that will fit your chosen motherboard, and will have enough 3.5" drive bays to hold all your drives.
[*]A decent amount of RAM (I went with 4GB because RAM is quite cheap, but you can definitely get away with 2GB)
[*]A drive for your operating system (I recommend [url=https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820227725]a solid state drive[/url] but any small drive will do just fine).
[*]Data drives (as many as you can afford - these days a [url=https://www.amazon.com/Seagate-Barracuda-3-5-Inch-Internal-ST3000DM001/dp/B005T3GRLY]3TB drive[/url] is pretty cost effective, but keep in mind if you're going to RAID your drives that more density isn't always what you want).
[*]The [url=https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814134138]NVIDIA GT 440 GPU[/url] This beast will play anything you could ever download from TC.  My old setup would get maxed out and start stuttering and dropping frames during 1080p scenes with shoaling fish or flocking birds.  This GPU chews through those scenes with no problem and my low-end CPU stays at about 5% usage.
[*]A CD, DVD, or USB stick to install Ubuntu from (the ISO is about 700 MB).
[/list][/indent]


[b][size=5]2. Getting started[/size][/b]

First, assemble your components into a computer.  Then, [url=https://www.pendrivelinux.com/]make your Ubuntu pendrive[/url], boot from it, and install Ubuntu.  During installation, be sure to create a user account for yourself; using root because it's convenient is a bad idea.  If you don't have a static IP address, I would strongly suggest [url=https://free.domain.name/en.html]setting up a free dynamic DNS service[/url].

Install SSH so you'll be able to access your terminal remotely:


[indent][quote]sudo apt-get install ssh[/quote]
[color=red][b]WARNING:[/b][/color] Doing this allows your system to be compromised fairly easily.  If you don't want to get pwned, [url=https://www.wikihow.com/Use-SSH]learn to secure SSH access with keys instead of passwords[/url].[/indent]

In addition to using keys instead of passwords, you will want to lock down SSH access to only your user account and only a difficult-to-guess port number.  So edit your sshd_config file:


[indent][quote]sudo nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config[/quote][/indent]

Change the following lines (feel free to come up with your own random port number above 20000):


[indent][pre]Port 21376
Protocol 2
PermitRootLogin no
X11Forwarding no[/pre][/indent]

And add these lines to the end of the file:


[indent][pre]UseDNS no
AllowUsers <username>[/pre][/indent]

Of course, replace <username> with your own username.  Hit Ctrl-O to save the file (and [ENTER] to confirm when prompted), then hit Ctrl-X to exit the editor.  Now restart the SSH daemon:


[indent][quote]sudo service ssh reload[/quote][/indent]

From here on out, you can run commands on your HTPC directly in its terminal window, or remotely via SSH from your laptop or any other computer.  Just log in with your credentials, and remember to use the correct port number for your connection.


[b][size=5]3. Installing necessary packages[/size][/b]

First, make sure your software is completely up to date:


[indent][quote]sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get upgrade[/quote][/indent]

Now, make sure the following runs correctly:


[indent][quote]sudo apt-get install apache2 apache2.2-common apache2-utils autoconf automake autotools-dev binutils build-essential bzip2 ca-certificates comerr-dev cpp dpkg-dev file g++ gawk gcc libapache2-mod-php5 libapache2-mod-scgi libapr1 libaprutil1 libc6-dev libcppunit-dev libcurl3 libcurl4-openssl-dev libexpat1 libidn11 libidn11-dev libgssrpc4 libkrb5-dev libmagic1 libncurses5 libncurses5-dev libpcre3 libpq5 libsigc++-2.0-dev libsqlite0 libsqlite3-0 libssl-dev libsvn1 libtool libxml2 linux-libc-dev lynx m4 make mime-support ntp ntpdate openssl patch perl perl-modules php5 php5-cgi php5-cli php5-common php5-curl php5-dev php5-geoip php5-sqlite php5-xmlrpc pkg-config python-scgi screen sqlite ssl-cert subversion ucf unrar zlib1g-dev pkg-config unzip htop screen libwww-perl curl[/quote][/indent]


[b][size=5]4. Configuring Apache[/size][/b]

Configure the apache web server with some useful modules:


[indent][quote]sudo a2enmod ssl; sudo a2enmod auth_digest; sudo a2enmod scgi[/quote][/indent]

Now, to enable ruTorrent to function, we need to enable SCGI support in apache's conf file:


[indent][quote]sudo nano /etc/apache2/apache2.conf[/quote][/indent]

Add these lines to the end of the file:


[indent][pre]SCGIMount /RPC2 127.0.0.1:5000
servername localhost[/pre][/indent]

Hit Ctrl-O to save the file (and hit [ENTER] to confirm when prompted), then hit Ctrl-X to exit the editor.  Now reboot the server:


[indent][quote]sudo reboot[/quote][/indent]

After the reboot, you should be able to visit your server's IP address or domain name in a web browser and see Apache's generic "It works!" message.  Now, you don't want just anyone accessing this address, so you'll want to lock it down as well.  First, create an SSL certificate so you can access your server via https (You will be prompted for lots of information.  Leave all of it blank, except when it asks for your name -- give it the domain name instead):


[indent][quote]sudo openssl req $@ -new -x509 -days 365 -nodes -out /etc/apache2/apache.pem -keyout /etc/apache2/apache.pem
sudo chmod 600 /etc/apache2/apache.pem[/quote][/indent]

Your server now has a self-signed certificate that lasts for one year.  Next you will want to set up password protection:


[indent][quote]sudo htdigest -c /etc/apache2/passwords gods <webusername>[/quote][/indent]

Replace <webusername> with the username you would like to use to access the ruTorrent web UI.  You will be prompted for a password as well.  Feel free to use your system username and password for this, but realize that they are not linked in any way.

Next, edit Apache's default sites-available file:


[indent][quote]cd /etc/apache2/sites-available
sudo mv default default.old 
sudo nano default[/quote][/indent]

[color=white]==========work on this===========[/color]
For starters, paste in the contents of this pastebin: https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=VZsCtLUg
This file simply contains [url=https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/directives.html]Apache directives[/url] for your web server, so feel free to modify them to suit your own purposes.

Edit /etc/apache2/ports.conf removing the conditional stuff at the bottom and changing 80 to 443.
[color=white]==========work on this===========[/color]

Now configure Apache for https, and reload the service:


[indent][quote]sudo a2ensite default-ssl; sudo service apache2 reload[/quote][/indent]

You should now be able to see Apache's generic "It works!" message when visiting your domain or IP address in a web browser using [b]https[/b].


[b][size=5]5. Installing Webmin[/size][/b]

I like to use Webmin for convenient web-based remote administration of my servers.  To install it, first edit your apt sources file:


[indent][quote]sudo nano /etc/apt/sources.list[/quote][/indent]

Add this line to the bottom of the file:


[indent][pre]deb https://download.webmin.com/download/repository sarge contrib[/pre][/indent]

Hit Ctrl-O to save the file (and [ENTER] to confirm when prompted), then hit Ctrl-X to exit the editor.  Now fetch and install the PGP key for this new repository so we're not warned about it later, and then update and install webmin:


[indent][quote]wget https://www.webmin.com/jcameron-key.asc
sudo apt-key add jcameron-key.asc
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install webmin[/quote][/indent]

You can test that it's working by visiting your server's domain or IP address in a web browser at port 10000 (e.g., https://myserver.com:10000 ).  We'll come back to this later to set up your firewall.


[b][size=5]6. Installing rtorrent[/size][/b]

There is an apt package for rtorrent, but it isn’t compiled with xmlrpc-c, which we will need to use with ruTorrent.  So we're going to compile our own version of rtorrent with xmlrpc-c.


[indent][quote]cd /tmp
svn co https://svn.code.sf.net/p/xmlrpc-c/code/advanced/ xmlrpc-c
wget https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/downloads/libtorrent-0.13.2.tar.gz
wget https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/downloads/rtorrent-0.9.2.tar.gz
tar -xvzf libtorrent-0.13.2.tar.gz
tar -xvzf rtorrent-0.9.2.tar.gz
rm *.tar.gz[/quote][/indent]

Now configure and make xmlrpc-c, libtorrent, and rtorrent:


[indent][quote]cd xmlrpc-c
./configure --disable-cplusplus
make
sudo make install

cd ../libtorrent-0.13.2
./autogen.sh
./configure
make
sudo make install

cd ../rtorrent-0.9.2
./autogen.sh
./configure --with-xmlrpc-c
make
sudo make install

sudo ldconfig[/quote][/indent]

Ok, now we've got rtorrent installed, but it needs a config file to run, so create one:


[indent][quote]sudo nano ~/.rtorrent.rc[/quote][/indent]

For starters, paste in the contents of this pastebin: https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=FEB2KQf5
You will need to edit the paths for your own environment (especially if you don't want files downloading onto your tiny OS drive by default).  For further customization, you may find these documents helpful:


[indent][url=https://libtorrent.rakshasa.no/rtorrent/rtorrent.1.html#AEN205].rtorrent.rc settings[/url]
[url=https://fsk141.com/rtorrent-the-complete-guide]rtorrent - The complete guide[/url][/indent]

When you are finished editing, hit Ctrl-O to save the file (and [ENTER] to confirm when prompted), then hit Ctrl-X to exit the editor.

[color=red][b]WARNING:[/b][/color] [i]Make sure all the paths referenced in the .rtorrent.rc file actually exist, and that your user account has write permissions on them, or rtorrent will NOT run[/i].  Check your work:


[indent][quote]rtorrent[/quote][/indent]

If rtorrent starts up, you're good; you can quit by typing Ctrl-Q.  If you get an error instead, fix your .rtorrent.rc file before moving on.

Now we will create a start-up script so rtorrent will run when your server boots up:


[indent][quote]sudo nano /etc/init.d/rtorrent[/quote][/indent]

Paste in the contents of this pastebin: https://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=kRr3utzw
Change <username> on line 34 to your own username, hit Ctrl-O to save the file (and [ENTER] to confirm when prompted), then hit Ctrl-X to exit the editor.  Now set it to run on boot:


[indent][quote]sudo chown root:root /etc/init.d/rtorrent
sudo chmod a+x /etc/init.d/rtorrent
cd /etc/init.d
sudo update-rc.d rtorrent defaults[/quote][/indent]

If you want to test it out, or start it without rebooting, use this:


[indent][quote]sudo /etc/init.d/rtorrent start[/quote][/indent]

Now your rtorrent process should be running inside a screen session named "rtorrent".


[b][size=5]7. Installing ruTorrent[/size][/b]

ruTorrent is really just a set of PHP and HTML files, so we're going to install them to a folder under our web server root.  Just grab the latest files from the subversion repository:


[indent][quote]cd /var/www
sudo svn checkout https://rutorrent.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/rutorrent[/quote][/indent]

Next, download any [url=https://code.google.com/p/rutorrent/wiki/Plugins]ruTorrent plugins[/url] that interest you.  I recommend using the SVN option because it's easy to update everything when new versions are released.  After you finish with that, change ownership of all the ruTorrent files to the web server user, and change their permissions:


[indent][quote]cd /var/www
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data rutorrent
sudo chmod -R 777 rutorrent[/quote][/indent]

You should now be able to visit your server's domain or IP address in a web browser with /rutorrent at the end (e.g., https://myserver.com/rutorrent ).  You will be prompted for the username and password we set up earlier in step 4 (Apache Configuration).  Once you have authenticated, you should see a working ruTorrent interface.  Congrats!  There's just one last thing to do.


[b][size=5]8. Configuring Your Firewall[/size][/b]

All that remains now is to lock down your server so that only the ports you need are open.  Webmin makes this easy, so go ahead and open it up in your web browser (e.g., https://myserver.com:10000 ).  Log in with your system username and password, and on the left hand navigation menu, go to Networking->Linux Firewall.  Under "Incoming packets (INPUT)", set the default action to [b]Drop[/b], and then add a new rule for each of the following:

[color=red][b]WARNING:[/b][/color] The next steps are based on the example port numbers provided in this guide.  You are encouraged to change those port numbers, but don't forget to change the firewall rules along with them.


[indent][b]SSH (e.g., port 21376, found in /etc/ssh/sshd_config)[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals TCP
Destination TCP or UDP port: Equals 21376[/indent]

[b]rtorrent TCP (e.g., ports 55995-56000, found in ~/.rtorrent.rc)[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals TCP
Destination TCP or UDP port: Equals Port range 55995 to 56000[/indent]

[b]rtorrent UDP (e.g., ports 55995-56000, found in ~/.rtorrent.rc)[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals UDP
Destination TCP or UDP port: Equals Port range 55995 to 56000[/indent]

[b]SSL (always port 443)[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals TCP
Destination TCP or UDP port: Equals 443[/indent]

[b]Webmin (always port 10000)[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals TCP
Destination TCP or UDP port: Equals 10000[/indent]

[b]Ping packets[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Network protocol: Equals ICMP[/indent]

[b]Local connections[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Incoming interface: Equals lo[/indent]

[b]Established connections[/b]
[indent]Action: Accept
Connection states: Equals ESTABLISHED,RELATED
(Ctrl-click or click and drag to select both)[/indent][/indent]

That's it!  Be sure to double-check everything ([i]especially[/i] make sure you have allowed TCP connections over port 10000 so you can still access Webmin to fix any other mistakes), and then hit Apply Configuration.  Remember that you will need to add new rules for any additional services you want to run on any given port (e.g., XBMC's web interface).

Maybe add stuff about installing XBMC, skins, add-ons, and the compiz issue: https://forum.xbmc.org/showthread.php?tid=98108

fields.title: Video Stream Resolution
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]480p (Standard Definition)[/b][/size][/color]

480p is defined as having a maximum resolution of 854x480.  Therefore, an encode having a width of 854 pixels or having a height of 480 pixels qualifies it as 480p.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]720p (High Definition)[/b][/size][/color]

720p is defined as having a maximum resolution of 1280x720.  Therefore, an encode having a width of 1280 pixels or having a height of 720 pixels qualifies it as 720p.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]1080p (High Definition)[/b][/size][/color]

1080p is defined as having a maximum resolution of 1920x1080.  Therefore, an encode having a width of 1920 pixels or having a height of 1080 pixels qualifies it as 1080p.

[*]Demotion (user going from Fanatic back to Member when their one upload is deleted does not work.
[*]Autocomplete needs some love. Movies with ô,û characters are not displayed. e.g. Tôkyô nagaremono
[/list]


[u]New Features/Possible TC 3.0 Features[/u]

Shit derekguy would kill for:
[list=circle]
[*] https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=5405
[*] https://tehconnection.eu/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=4997
[/list]

[b]Usenet Reseed Bot[/b]

Backup uploads to usenet (encrypted with no recognisable filenames) via bot and allow automatic reseeding (via request) from usenet.

Would require probably one server to upload and archive and one to reseed from as well as premium usenet account.


[b]Image Host in Upload Page.[/b]

Built in image host in upload page.


[b]New This Week/Month/Year[/b]

Built in to search page. Returns a montage-like view of new IMDb URLs added to the site for a particular time period.

fields.title: uTorrent: Seed all your old downloads on a new computer or fresh OS install
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]1. Gather your .torrent files[/b][/size][/color]

Most trackers provide a place on your profile page to download all the .torrent files you've snatched in a single .zip archive.  Download this, and extract it to a folder somewhere.  For this tutorial, I'll assume you have extracted it to [color=white]C:\Users\noob\Downloads\torrents[/color] if you're a Windows user or [color=white]~/Downloads/torrents[/color] if you're a Mac/Linux user.  If you have multiple .zip archives from multiple trackers, you'll probably want to extract each one to a different folder, but for this tutorial I'll assume you only have one.


[size=4][b]Windows:[/b][/size]
[indent]

Using Windows Explorer, navigate to the folder where you extracted the .zip archive.  You should see a bunch of folders in there, named by month and year (these are used to separate the torrents by when you snatched them).

Hold down the [Shift] key and right-click in the folder.  Then choose "Open command window here" from the context menu.  A command line will appear, and you will type into it:

[pre]for /d %i in (*) do move "%i\*" .[/pre]
[/indent]

[size=4][b]Mac/Linux:[/b][/size]
[indent]

Open Terminal, and type:

[pre]cd ~/Downloads/torrents
mv */*.torrent .[/pre]
[/indent]

Now you have successfully moved all the .torrent files into the same directory.  This will make it super easy to add them all to uTorrent.  You can close the command line / Terminal window.



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]2. Prevent ratio disaster[/b][/size][/color]

[color=red][b]Disconnect your computer from the internet.[/b][/color]  I'm not kidding.  Turn off your WiFi antenna and make sure there's no ethernet cable in your computer.  If you add all these torrents at once and something goes wrong, [i]they will all start downloading and ruining your ratio faster than you can figure out what's happening[/i].  Disconnect your computer from the internet before you continue, and everything will be okay.



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]3. Add torrents[/b][/size][/color]

Open uTorrent, and go to Options, Preferences, Directories.  Check the box for "Put new downloads in:" and select the folder where all your data files are stored (not the .torrent files, but the movies, music, or whatever else you have collected).  If you don't have everything in one place, don't worry -- we'll fix that in the next section.

Now check the box for "Automatically load .torrents from:" and select the folder where the .torrent files are (e.g., [color=white]~/Downloads/torrents[/color]).  Click OK and watch the magic happen!  uTorrent will add all the torrents for you and start hash checking them to see if the data is there.  When it finishes, you'll probably have some torrents that are still at 0%.  That brings us to the final step.



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]4. Clean up[/b][/size][/color]

For each torrent that is stuck at 0%, find out if you have the data somewhere on your computer.

[indent][list]
[*] If you don't have the data and you want to re-download it, keep the torrent.  It will start downloading as soon as you connect to the Internet again.
[*] If you don't have the data and you don't want to re-download it, remove the torrent.
[*] If you do have the data on your computer, you'll need to point uTorrent in the right direction.  Keep reading.
[/list][/indent]

For each torrent you're pointing to a new location, do the following.

[indent][list]
[*] Stop the torrent.
[*] Open the Files tab of the panel at the bottom (if you don't see this panel, go to Options, Show Detailed Info).
[*] Click on one of the files and type Ctrl-A (on Windows/Linux) or Command-A (on Mac).  This will highlight all the files.
[*] Right click one of them and select "Relocate..." -- now browse to the folder on your computer where the data for this torrent is stored.
[color=red]Note:[/color] If the torrent is for a single file, you'll need to browse to the folder that contains that file.  But if the torrent is for a [i]folder[/i] with file(s) in it (e.g., an album from What.CD), you'll need to browse to the folder that contains that folder.
[*] Right click the torrent and select "Force Re-Check".  uTorrent will hash check the file, and if it says "Finished" you can start the torrent and it will seed.
[color=red]Note:[/color] If it still says 0%, either you've given it the wrong location or the files there do not match that torrent.
[/list][/indent]

Finally, when you're okay with the idea that any torrents still at 0% will start downloading immediately, connect to the Internet!

fields.title: General Connection Problems (Torrents Won't Download)
fields.body:
Connection issues and torrent problems are common amongst users. As such, many threads tend to pop up about such topics. This thread was created to provide a common area to help diagnose and fix connection and torrent issues. Please read over this topic and search the thread before posting.

Tracker Status:
Working (Note this is updated if I'm around. But don't take this as 100% truthful,.)

Things to Consider First:
There are a few common causes for many of the connection/torrent issues users experience. Before posting, please read them because chances are they explain your problem.

Is the tracker working? If the tracker isn't working, well, then it isn't working. We most likely know about the issue and will inform you too. To fix this issue, check the IRC to make sure it's up and running normally If it's not, go watch a movie. You won't die, I promise.


Are you using a whitelisted torrent client? You won't be able to seed or leech if you are using a client that is not on the whitelist. If the tracker status says your client is not on the approved client whitelist, then you have this problem! It is commonly caused when you upgrade to a new version before it is approved. To fix this issue, choose an approved client or downgrade to a whitelisted version.


Are you using PeerBlock or similar software/IP lists? PeerBlock and similar programs give you a false sense of security. In the end they do nothing and block the tracker and good peers. If your torrents time out or are unable to reach the tracker, this may be your issue. To fix this issue, STOP using PeerBlock (seriously, it does nothing) or add an exception for PTP's tracker IP [91.217.90.42].


Do you use Malwarebytes? Malwarebytes (pro version) recently began causing problems with PTP's tracker. Specifically, the tracker IP is being blocked by the website filtering. To fix this issue, you need to add PTP's tracker to the ignore list [91.217.90.42]. To do so, make sure website blocking and balloon notifications are enabled. Then visit please.passthepopcorn.me in your browser. A balloon should pop up through which you can add the tracker to the ignore list.


If Not Those, Then What?:
Look at the issues above and make sure you don't have them.
Flush your DNS cache (While we're at it, switch to Google's DNS).
Restarting computers saves lives.
Reset your network if possible.

fields.title: Cropping
fields.body:
All encodes must be properly cropped. This basically means there must be no black bars visible on the top, right, left and bottom of an encode. An encode with poor cropping and black bars left would not be allowed to be uploaded to Teh Connection.


Two examples with one properly cropped encode vs. two poorly cropped encodes:

[spoiler=Example A][img]https://i.imgur.com/SJ7eZF7.png[/img]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/go5ZTLi.png[/img]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/E3uOwoE.png[/img][/spoiler]
[spoiler=Example B][img]https://i.imgur.com/J4QUH7e.png[/img]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/BGzUdAl.png[/img]
[img]https://i.imgur.com/PqW44DI.png[/img][/spoiler]
You could download the screens to better spot the poor cropping, which is also suggested to do when in doubt, if an encode with existing screenshots from another tracker is indeed properly cropped.

fields.title: Hit and Run (HnR)
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What is a Hit and Run?[/b][/size][/color]

A Hit and Run (HnR) is the act of downloading a torrent with the express purpose of not seeding back. This behaviour is not common, but in order to prevent such abuse we have installed a hit and run detection script which enforces a minimum seed time for every torrent downloaded.  Obviously, we hope you'll seed for longer as that is what makes this place great and will assist you in increasing your member class.


[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]What Are the Minimum Requirements?[/b][/size][/color]

You must seed each downloaded torrent for a minimum of 96 hours within two weeks of completing the download.

fields.title: IVTC and Frame Rates
fields.body:
Usually, if mediainfo reports any one of the following frame rates, the video has the correct frame rate for playback:

[list]
[*] 23.976 fps
[*] 24.000 fps
[*] 25.000 fps
[/list]

If mediainfo reports 29.970 fps, the encoder most likely forgot to IVTC the source (usually an NTSC DVD).  You can read more about IVTC here:

https://www.doom9.org/ivtc-tut.htm


There are exceptions and edge cases, of course.  For example, some footage is shot digitally using the NTSC standard, so 29.970 is the proper frame rate.  Some documentaries use footage from various types of sources, so determining their proper frame rate is complicated.  If you are ever in doubt, just send us a [url=https://tehconnection.eu/staffpm.php?action=new]Staff PM[/url] before uploading.

fields.title: Cross-seeding RAR'd Scene Releases With rtorrent
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Cross-seeding RAR'd Scene Releases With rtorrent[/b][/size][/color]
[br /]
On scene trackers like SCC, everything is uploaded as .rar files.  Often, other trackers will not allow rar files to be uploaded.  If you find yourself in this situation; you can do the following:


Stop the active download in rtorrent, using these commands:
Control + D
Control + K

Make a copy of the original directory:
[pre]
cp -R <original dir> <original dir>-copy
cd <original dir>
[/pre]

Unrar the files within the original directory
[pre]
unrar e <name>.rar
[/pre]

Check any sub-directories for rarred files and unrar as necessary
Delete all rar files. Then delete the .sfv file. Delete any other unwanted files.

Then, make the torrent file for the second tracker that you wish to upload to:

[pre]
mktorrent -p -a announce <original dir> -o output.torrent -l 19
[/pre]

Once the newly created torrent has hashed, re-add the original files from <original dir>-copy using:
[pre]
cp -R <original dir>-copy/* <original dir>/
[/pre]

Check all files are in place, then delete the copied directory like so:
[pre]
rm -rf <original dir>-copy
[/pre]

Restart the original torrent using:
Control + S

Finally, proceed with your upload on the non-scene tracker

There is likely a faster way of doing this, if so, your suggestions are welcome

fields.title: Uploader Class
fields.body:
[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Welcome Uploaders![/b][/size][/color]

If you're reading this then you're officially part of the elite uploading team at TehConnection. This is a new member class so we're still ironing out some bugs and polishing some features. As always, ping staff on site or IRC if you have any suggestions or complaints.



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]Uploader Requirements[/b][/size][/color]

[list]
[*] [b]Love the bit stream[/b]: you should only do this if you enjoy it. Uploading can quickly feel like a chore so if you're simply doing it for the 'perks' you might find yourself disheartened.
[/list]
[list]
[*] [b]Communication[/b]: we need you to be in IRC as much as you can. This makes communication much more efficient and will cut down on two or more of you snatching and uploading the same thing.

You have your own channel (#tc.uploaders) and more information on IRC can be found [url=https://tehconnection.eu/wiki.php?action=article&id=104]here[/url].

Since we trump based on quality, we'll have our DoT team and select encoders able to offer opinions on content you may be unsure of.
[/list]
[list]
[*] [b]Contribution[/b]: we're beginning the class out by requiring 25 uploads per month averaged over three months (so you can go on holiday or to war and not be kicked out straight away)

This sounds like a lot, but uploading seven torrents (a week's work) can easily be done in an hour or so. Obviously, you're going to pick your style of uploading and no one will be discriminated against for that. So whether it is better for you to upload one torrent a day or smash out 20+ in one sitting is up to you.

We're going to tweak the number on this if it proves to be unworkable for many but I'm pretty sure it will be OK.
[/list]



[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]The Future[/b][/size][/color]

Some future features. We're building a dynamic stats page which will compile your uploads - total, monthly, and three monthly at this stage - as a basis for some potential competition.

We'll also introduce an automatic demotion script for those who end up not meeting the requirements. This is not in force yet and we'll let you know when it is.

We're also working on some tools which will help to centralise what is a fairly distributed job (multiple sites etc...) through an IRC channel and a potential tool on site.

fields.title: Staff Duties & Code of Conduct
fields.body:
This document is an outline of the duties of a staff member at TehConnection, responsibilities with regard to user data, and some information on conduct expectations.


[size=5][color=#4682b4]Duties[/color][/size]

[b]IRC[/b]
[indent]
As a moderator we expect you to be present in IRC 24/7. This may mean obtaining a BNC if you do not already have one. Setting one up on a seedbox/server is fairly straightforward and assistance with that can be gained from derekguy/GLaDOSDan. Try and check IRC at least once a day for any urgent messages or queries, obviously we're not going to be brutal about enforcing this but randomly disappearing for six months is not acceptable. Just flick an admin a quick PM if you're going to be away for a bit.
[/indent]

[b]#TC.Support[/b]
[indent]
A corollary to IRC presence: all staffers must be present in the IRC support channel. It is mandatory to help out. We know it is boring re-enabling retards but someone has to do it. Also, that channel has been witness to some of the most epic lulz we have ever seen. Join for the comedic value at least. :wink:
[/indent]

[b]Staff PM[/b]
[indent]
The first point of contact for our members is the staff PM. Right now this feature is only available to the mods+ but in the future we'll have a proper ticket-like interface including the DoT team and assignable messages.

We try and aim for a fairly fast turnaround on messages here and for the most part they can all be answered in seconds. For anything you're unsure about ping another staff member for them to look at it.

If you're working on a PM click the link at the top of the interface to let others know it is being worked on.
[/indent]

[b]Reports[/b]
[indent]
Look after any reports as soon as you are able. Feel free to ask for a second opinion on any reports you are unsure of. Even veterans come across weird stuff. If you have sent a PM mark the report as 'In Progress' so others don't send a PM too.
[/indent]

[b]Torrents[/b]
[indent]
You're an important moderator now but the entire staff team still helps out with torrent moderation. This is part of the moderation that is the most time consuming and helping out DoTs in IRC and acting on reports quickly is important.
[/indent]


[size=5][color=#4682b4]User Data[/color][/size]

As site staff we're entrusting you with the ability to perform user support in almost all capacities and this necessitates access to user information including IP and e-mail addresses.

We take the protection of our users' data [b]very[/b] seriously. Both the site code and staff conduct reflect this.

Your responsibility as a staff member is to assist in the protection of that information. This means that no privileged discussion (IRC/forum) or user data should be disclosed outside TC staff circles.

You may, from time to time, be approached via IRC/site PM by users and other tracker staff requesting information about users on site.

Under no circumstances should you disclose this. Even if you're friends with them or think they are legit. We have strict information disclosure procedures and other tracker staff (especially) know that.

If you discover publicly available account information (passkey/username & password/account screenshots etc…) in the first instance you should preserve the public data (links, screenshots, etc…) then ensure the account is disabled. Note the links or screenshots in the staff notes for future use if/when the user visits our IRC support.

Violation of our members' data in any way will be dealt with in the most severe manner possible. If you're unsure about anything regarding user data please contact an Administrator or SiteOp. [url=https://what.cd/forums.php?action=viewthread&threadid=175940]This is an example[/url] of what we want to avoid ever happening.


[size=5][color=#4682b4]Conduct[/color][/size]

We have a minimum code of conduct that we expect all staff to respect while using their staff nicks on site. Your actions on site (forums, etc…) reflect on the site as a whole.

[list]
[*] All members are to be treated with respect at all times. Excessive profanity, bullying, insults, trolling, and other unprofessional shit should be conducted under an alias.
[*] Use your best judgement and if in doubt ask for help.
[*] Don't be afraid to say NO!
    - No matter what your answer is there needs to be a good reason for it, explain it thoroughly to the member but them whining should not affect your decision.
[*] Don't defy another staff member in public, instead send a PM.
    - There may be occasions where an administrator or higher needs to defy another staff member in public to fix a wrong or settle a dispute, a moderator should never defy another moderator in public. If necessary allow an administrator to settle the issue.
[*] Be respectful to one another.
[*] Be tolerant! Give the member(s) a chance to reform.
[*] Try correcting any "off topics" rather then closing a thread.
[*] Move topics rather than locking them if appropriate.
[*] Be tolerant when moderating the 'General' chat section (give them some slack).
[*] Always state a reason (in the comment box) as to why the member is being banned/warned. Include links to evidence of any offence is possible.
[/list]

Please host on [url=https://imgur.com/]imgur[/url] or similar fast image host (not the ones we recommend for screenshots).

Please don't use imgur for (HD)screenshots as they compress the images if they are too large.
Please don't use ptpimage or other site specific hosts as they attempt to block redirects from other sites.

[color=#4682b4][size=5][b]For Scene Releases[/b][/size][/color]
No one resource seems to be complete for scene release info. If you are on a scene tracker that might be as helpful as any of these links.

[url=https://www.srrdb.com/]srrdb[/url] Has the additional files from a scene release such as nfos and samples.
[url=https://pre.corrupt-net.org/]corrupt-net[/url] http search for past scene releases.
[url=https://www.binsearch.info/]binsearch[/url] Usenet search sometimes has nfos.

[url=https://kiwiirc.com/client/irc.rizon.net/ultrapre.talk]#ultrapre.talk on rizon.net[/url] This is a link to an actual irc channel that often has more info on scene releases and has nfos available on command.
